Shcherbatenko et al., “Sub-shot-noise-limited fiber-optic quantum receiver”, Physical Review A 101, (2020) arXiv:1911.08932 DOI].
Photon-number resolving detector [M. T. DiMario and F. E. Becerra, “Robust Measurement for the Discrimination of Binary Coherent States”, Physical Review Letters 121, (2018) arXiv:1807.05199 DOI].
Communication over dephasing [M. T. DiMario et al., “Optimized communication strategies with binary coherent states over phase noise channels”, npj Quantum Information 5, (2019) arXiv:1907.12515 DOI], time-varying phase-noise [M. T. DiMario and F. E. Becerra, “Phase tracking for sub-shot-noise-limited receivers”, Physical Review Research 2, (2020) DOI], and thermal-noise [R. Yuan et al., “Optimally Displaced Threshold Detection for Discriminating Binary Coherent States Using Imperfect Devices”, (2020) arXiv:2007.11109] channels.
Adaptive decoder using displacements and photon detection [M. T. DiMario and F. E. Becerra, “Demonstration of optimal non-projective measurement of binary coherent states with photon counting”, npj Quantum Information 8, (2022) arXiv:2207.12234 DOI].
Superconducting circuits: a bit-flip time of 1s has been achieved for the two-legged cat code in the classical-bit regime [C. Berdou et al., “One Hundred Second Bit-Flip Time in a Two-Photon Dissipative Oscillator”, PRX Quantum 4, (2023) arXiv:2204.09128 DOI].

Unambiguous state discrimination using displacement-based receiver for 4-PSK [F. E. Becerra, J. Fan, and A. Migdall, “Implementation of generalized quantum measurements for unambiguous discrimination of multiple non-orthogonal coherent states”, Nature Communications 4, (2013) DOI].
Multi-stage quantum receivers [F. E. Becerra et al., “Experimental demonstration of a receiver beating the standard quantum limit for multiple nonorthogonal state discrimination”, Nature Photonics 7, 147 (2013) DOI][S. Izumi et al., “Experimental Demonstration of a Quantum Receiver Beating the Standard Quantum Limit at Telecom Wavelength”, Physical Review Applied 13, (2020) arXiv:2001.05902 DOI][F. E. Becerra, J. Fan, and A. Migdall, “Photon number resolution enables quantum receiver for realistic coherent optical communications”, Nature Photonics 9, 48 (2014) DOI][A. R. Ferdinand, M. T. DiMario, and F. E. Becerra, “Multi-state discrimination below the quantum noise limit at the single-photon level”, npj Quantum Information 3, (2017) arXiv:1711.00074 DOI].
Bayesian inference [I. A. Burenkov et al., “Experimental demonstration of time resolving quantum receiver for bandwidth and power efficient communications”, Conference on Lasers and Electro-Optics (2020) DOI].
Time resolving quantum receiver opertaing in the telecom C band [M. V. Jabir et al., “Versatile quantum-enabled telecom receiver”, AVS Quantum Science 5, 015001 (2023) DOI].
Displacements and photon detection [S. Izumi, J. S. Neergaard-Nielsen, and U. L. Andersen, “Adaptive Generalized Measurement for Unambiguous State Discrimination of Quaternary Phase-Shift-Keying Coherent States”, PRX Quantum 2, (2021) arXiv:2009.02558 DOI].
Adaptive decoder using linear-optical elements and photon detection [M. T. DiMario and F. E. Becerra, “Demonstration of optimal non-projective measurement of binary coherent states with photon counting”, npj Quantum Information 8, (2022) arXiv:2207.12234 DOI].

Time-resolving quantum receiver [M. V. Jabir et al., “Energy and bandwidth efficiency optimization of quantum-enabled optical communication channels”, npj Quantum Information 8, (2022) DOI].
Bondurant receiver [M. V. Jabir et al., “Experimental demonstration of the near-quantum optimal receiver”, OSA Continuum 3, 3324 (2020) DOI].
Bayesian inference [I. A. Burenkov et al., “Time-Resolving Quantum Measurement Enables Energy-Efficient, Large-Alphabet Communication”, PRX Quantum 1, (2020) DOI].

Proof-of-principle experiments using Dolinar [R. L. Cook, P. J. Martin, and J. M. Geremia, “Optical coherent state discrimination using a closed-loop quantum measurement”, Nature 446, 774 (2007) DOI] and TES receivers [K. Tsujino et al., “Sub-shot-noise-limit discrimination of on-off keyed coherent signals via a quantum receiver with a superconducting transition edge sensor”, Optics Express 18, 8107 (2010) DOI].

Conditional pulse nulling (CPN) receiver [J. Chen et al., “Optical codeword demodulation with error rates below the standard quantum limit using a conditional nulling receiver”, Nature Photonics 6, 374 (2012) arXiv:1111.4017 DOI].

Quantum enhancement was demonstrated using a polarization-based non-error-correcting c-q encodings [R. J. Chapman et al., “Beating the classical limits of information transmission using a quantum decoder”, Physical Review A 97, (2018) arXiv:1704.07036 DOI].

NMR: Implementation of braiding-based Hamamard gate on two qubits [Y. Fan et al., “Experimental realization of a topologically protected Hadamard gate via braiding Fibonacci anyons”, (2022) arXiv:2210.12145].

Cryptographic applications stemming from the monogamy of entanglement of group GKP code and error words [E. Culf, T. Vidick, and V. V. Albert, “Group coset monogamy games and an application to device-independent continuous-variable QKD”, (2022) arXiv:2212.03935].

A related superconducting circuit has been realized by the Houck group [A. Gyenis et al., “Experimental Realization of a Protected Superconducting Circuit Derived from the 0 – π Qubit”, PRX Quantum 2, (2021) arXiv:1910.07542 DOI].

Signatures of a phase equivalent to the \(G=D_4\) quantum double detected in a 27-qubit trapped-ion device by Quantinuum [M. Iqbal et al., “Creation of Non-Abelian Topological Order and Anyons on a Trapped-Ion Processor”, (2023) arXiv:2305.03766]. Preparation of ground states and braiding of anyons has also been performed. The phase was realized as a gauged \(G=\mathbb{Z}_3^2\) twisted quantum double [B. Yoshida, “Topological phases with generalized global symmetries”, Physical Review B 93, (2016) arXiv:1508.03468 DOI], which is the same topological order as the \(G=D_4\) quantum double [M. de W. Propitius, “Topological interactions in broken gauge theories”, (1995) arXiv:hep-th/9511195][L. Lootens et al., “Mapping between Morita-equivalent string-net states with a constant depth quantum circuit”, Physical Review B 105, (2022) arXiv:2112.12757 DOI].

Parity-syndrome measurement tested [L. Sun et al., “Tracking photon jumps with repeated quantum non-demolition parity measurements”, Nature 511, 444 (2014) arXiv:1311.2534 DOI] and implemented for the four-component (\(S=1\)) cat code [N. Ofek et al., “Demonstrating Quantum Error Correction that Extends the Lifetime of Quantum Information”, (2016) arXiv:1602.04768] in a microwave cavity coupled to a superconducting circuit. The latter work [N. Ofek et al., “Demonstrating Quantum Error Correction that Extends the Lifetime of Quantum Information”, (2016) arXiv:1602.04768] is the first to reach break-even error-correction, where the lifetime of a logical qubit is on par with the cavity lifetime, despite protection against dephasing not being implemented. A fault-tolerant version of parity measurement has also been realized [S. Rosenblum et al., “Fault-tolerant detection of a quantum error”, Science 361, 266 (2018) arXiv:1803.00102 DOI].

Lindbladian-based [Z. Leghtas et al., “Confining the state of light to a quantum manifold by engineered two-photon loss”, Science 347, 853 (2015) arXiv:1412.4633 DOI][S. Touzard et al., “Coherent Oscillations inside a Quantum Manifold Stabilized by Dissipation”, Physical Review X 8, (2018) arXiv:1705.02401 DOI] and Hamiltonian-based 'Kerr-cat' [A. Grimm et al., “Stabilization and operation of a Kerr-cat qubit”, Nature 584, 205 (2020) arXiv:1907.12131 DOI] encodings have been achieved in superconducting circuit devices by the Devoret group; Ref. [S. Touzard et al., “Coherent Oscillations inside a Quantum Manifold Stabilized by Dissipation”, Physical Review X 8, (2018) arXiv:1705.02401 DOI] also demonstrated a displacement-based gate. The Lindbladian-based scheme has further achieved a suppression of bit-flip errors that is exponential in the average photon number up to a bit-flip time of 1ms [R. Lescanne et al., “Exponential suppression of bit-flips in a qubit encoded in an oscillator”, Nature Physics 16, 509 (2020) arXiv:1907.11729 DOI] and later 10 seconds [U. Réglade et al., “Quantum control of a cat-qubit with bit-flip times exceeding ten seconds”, (2023) arXiv:2307.06617], with the latter scheme repurposing a holonomic gate [V. V. Albert et al., “Holonomic Quantum Control with Continuous Variable Systems”, Physical Review Letters 116, (2016) arXiv:1503.00194 DOI] as a measurement.
T4C code realized in a superconducting circuit device by the Wang group [J. M. Gertler et al., “Protecting a bosonic qubit with autonomous quantum error correction”, Nature 590, 243 (2021) arXiv:2004.09322 DOI].

The dual-rail code is ubiquitous in linear optical quantum devices [P. Kok et al., “Linear optical quantum computing with photonic qubits”, Reviews of Modern Physics 79, 135 (2007) arXiv:quant-ph/0512071 DOI].
Superconducting circuit devices: error detection has been demonstrated in 3D cavities in Michel Devoret's group at Yale University [A. Koottandavida et al., “Erasure detection of a dual-rail qubit encoded in a double-post superconducting cavity”, (2023) arXiv:2311.04423] and Amazon Web Services [H. Levine et al., “Demonstrating a long-coherence dual-rail erasure qubit using tunable transmons”, (2023) arXiv:2307.08737] using transmon qubits, following earlier theoretical proposals [J. D. Teoh et al., “Dual-rail encoding with superconducting cavities”, Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences 120, (2023) arXiv:2212.12077 DOI][A. Kubica et al., “Erasure qubits: Overcoming the \(T_1\) limit in superconducting circuits”, (2022) arXiv:2208.05461]. Logical readout in 3D cavities has been demonstrated by Quantum Circuits Inc. [K. S. Chou et al., “Demonstrating a superconducting dual-rail cavity qubit with erasure-detected logical measurements”, (2023) arXiv:2307.03169].
Star-code autonomous correction scheme realized using superconducting circuits [Z. Li et al., “Autonomous error correction of a single logical qubit using two transmons”, (2023) arXiv:2302.06707].

Microwave cavities coupled to superconducting circuits by the Wang group [J. M. Gertler et al., “Experimental Realization and Characterization of Stabilized Pair Coherent States”, (2022) arXiv:2209.11643].

Microwave cavities coupled to superconducting circuits: state transfer between a binomial codeword to another system [C. J. Axline et al., “On-demand quantum state transfer and entanglement between remote microwave cavity memories”, Nature Physics 14, 705 (2018) arXiv:1712.05832 DOI], error-correction protocol nearly reaching break-even [L. Hu et al., “Quantum error correction and universal gate set operation on a binomial bosonic logical qubit”, Nature Physics 15, 503 (2019) arXiv:1805.09072 DOI], and a teleported CNOT gate [Y. Xu et al., “Demonstration of Controlled-Phase Gates between Two Error-Correctable Photonic Qubits”, Physical Review Letters 124, (2020) arXiv:1810.04690 DOI]. A realization of the "0-2-4" encoding is the first to go beyond break-even error-correction and yields a logical lifetime that exceeds the cavity lifetime by \(16\%\) [Z. Ni et al., “Beating the break-even point with a discrete-variable-encoded logical qubit”, Nature 616, 56 (2023) arXiv:2211.09319 DOI] (see also [V. V. Sivak et al., “Real-time quantum error correction beyond break-even”, Nature 616, 50 (2023) arXiv:2211.09116 DOI]). See Ref. [M. Kudra et al., “Robust Preparation of Wigner-Negative States with Optimized SNAP-Displacement Sequences”, PRX Quantum 3, (2022) arXiv:2111.07965 DOI] for another experiment.
Motional degree of freedom of a trapped ion: binomial state preparation for \(S=2\) realized by Tan group [V. G. Matsos et al., “Robust and Deterministic Preparation of Bosonic Logical States in a Trapped Ion”, (2023) arXiv:2310.15546].
One-sided device-independent QKD [E. Culf, T. Vidick, and V. V. Albert, “Group coset monogamy games and an application to device-independent continuous-variable QKD”, (2022) arXiv:2212.03935].
Optical network by the Furusawa group [T. Aoki et al., “Quantum error correction beyond qubits”, (2008) arXiv:0811.3734].

Motional degree of freedom of a trapped ion: square-lattice GKP encoding realized with the help of post-selection by Home group [C. Flühmann et al., “Encoding a qubit in a trapped-ion mechanical oscillator”, Nature 566, 513 (2019) arXiv:1807.01033 DOI][C. Flühmann and J. P. Home, “Direct Characteristic-Function Tomography of Quantum States of the Trapped-Ion Motional Oscillator”, Physical Review Letters 125, (2020) arXiv:1907.06478 DOI], followed by realization of reduced form of GKP error correction, where displacement error syndromes are measured to one bit of precision using an ion electronic state [B. de Neeve et al., “Error correction of a logical grid state qubit by dissipative pumping”, (2020) arXiv:2010.09681]. State preparation also realized by Tan group [V. G. Matsos et al., “Robust and Deterministic Preparation of Bosonic Logical States in a Trapped Ion”, (2023) arXiv:2310.15546].
Microwave cavity coupled to superconducting circuits: reduced form of square-lattice GKP error correction, where displacement error syndromes are measured to one bit of precision using an ancillary transmon [P. Campagne-Ibarcq et al., “Quantum error correction of a qubit encoded in grid states of an oscillator”, Nature 584, 368 (2020) arXiv:1907.12487 DOI]. Subsequent paper by Devoret group [V. V. Sivak et al., “Real-time quantum error correction beyond break-even”, Nature 616, 50 (2023) arXiv:2211.09116 DOI] (see also [D. Lachance-Quirion et al., “Autonomous quantum error correction of Gottesman-Kitaev-Preskill states”, (2023) arXiv:2310.11400]) uses reinforcement learning for error-correction cycle design and is the first to go beyond break-even error-correction, with the lifetime of a logical qubit exceeding the cavity lifetime by about a factor of two (see also [Z. Ni et al., “Beating the break-even point with a discrete-variable-encoded logical qubit”, Nature 616, 56 (2023) arXiv:2211.09319 DOI]). See Ref. [M. Kudra et al., “Robust Preparation of Wigner-Negative States with Optimized SNAP-Displacement Sequences”, PRX Quantum 3, (2022) arXiv:2111.07965 DOI] for another experiment.
GKP states and homodyne measurements have been realized in propagating telecom light by the Furusawa group [S. Konno et al., “Propagating Gottesman-Kitaev-Preskill states encoded in an optical oscillator”, (2023) arXiv:2309.02306].
Single-qubit \(Z\)-gate has been demonstrated in the single-photon subspace of an infinite-mode space [N. Fabre et al., “Generation of a time-frequency grid state with integrated biphoton frequency combs”, Physical Review A 102, (2020) arXiv:1904.01351 DOI], in which time and frequency become bosonic conjugate variables of a single effective bosonic mode.
In signal processing, GKP state position-state wavefunctions are related to Dirac combs [H. G. Feichtinger and T. Strohmer, editors , Gabor Analysis and Algorithms (Birkhäuser Boston, 1998) DOI].

Microwave cavity coupled to superconducting circuits: reduced form of GKP error correction, where displacement error syndromes are measured to one bit of precision using an ancillary transmon [P. Campagne-Ibarcq et al., “Quantum error correction of a qubit encoded in grid states of an oscillator”, Nature 584, 368 (2020) arXiv:1907.12487 DOI].
Public-key quantum communication protocol [J. Conrad, J. Eisert, and J.-P. Seifert, “Good Gottesman-Kitaev-Preskill codes from the NTRU cryptosystem”, (2023) arXiv:2303.02432].

Measurement induced quantum phases have been realized in a trapped-ion processor [C. Noel et al., “Measurement-induced quantum phases realized in a trapped-ion quantum computer”, Nature Physics 18, 760 (2022) arXiv:2106.05881 DOI].
Plaquette stabilizer measurement realized on the IBM Falcon superconducting-qubit device [J. R. Wootton, “Measurements of Floquet code plaquette stabilizers”, (2022) arXiv:2210.13154]
Plaquette stabilizer measurement realized on the IBM Falcon superconducting-qubit device [J. R. Wootton, “Measurements of Floquet code plaquette stabilizers”, (2022) arXiv:2210.13154]

Photonic systems: braiding of defects has been simulated in a device that has a different notion of locality than a bona-fide fermionic system [J.-S. Xu et al., “Simulating the exchange of Majorana zero modes with a photonic system”, Nature Communications 7, (2016) arXiv:1411.7751 DOI].
Superconducting circuits: initialization [K. J. Sung et al., “Simulating Majorana zero modes on a noisy quantum processor”, Quantum Science and Technology 8, 025010 (2023) arXiv:2206.00563 DOI], braiding [N. Harle, O. Shtanko, and R. Movassagh, “Observing and braiding topological Majorana modes on programmable quantum simulators”, Nature Communications 14, (2023) arXiv:2203.15083 DOI] and detection [N. Harle, O. Shtanko, and R. Movassagh, “Observing and braiding topological Majorana modes on programmable quantum simulators”, Nature Communications 14, (2023) arXiv:2203.15083 DOI][X. Mi et al., “Noise-resilient edge modes on a chain of superconducting qubits”, Science 378, 785 (2022) arXiv:2204.11372 DOI] of defects has been simulated in devices that have a different notion of locality than a bona-fide fermionic system.

Trapped-ion devices: 12-qubit device by Quantinuum [C. N. Self, M. Benedetti, and D. Amaro, “Protecting Expressive Circuits with a Quantum Error Detection Code”, (2022) arXiv:2211.06703]. Subsequent experiment performed Bayesian Quantum Phase Estimation on the \(m=3\) code [K. Yamamoto et al., “Demonstrating Bayesian Quantum Phase Estimation with Quantum Error Detection”, (2023) arXiv:2306.16608].

NMR: 3-qubit phase-flip code [D. G. Cory et al., “Experimental Quantum Error Correction”, Physical Review Letters 81, 2152 (1998) arXiv:quant-ph/9802018 DOI][O. Moussa et al., “Demonstration of Sufficient Control for Two Rounds of Quantum Error Correction in a Solid State Ensemble Quantum Information Processor”, Physical Review Letters 107, (2011) arXiv:1108.4842 DOI], with up to two rounds of error correction in liquid-state NMR [J. Zhang et al., “Experimental quantum error correction with high fidelity”, Physical Review A 84, (2011) arXiv:1109.4821 DOI].
Superconducting circuits: 3-qubit phase-flip and bit-flip code by Schoelkopf group [M. D. Reed et al., “Realization of three-qubit quantum error correction with superconducting circuits”, Nature 482, 382 (2012) arXiv:1109.4948 DOI]; 3-qubit bit-flip code [D. Ristè et al., “Detecting bit-flip errors in a logical qubit using stabilizer measurements”, Nature Communications 6, (2015) arXiv:1411.5542 DOI]; 3-qubit phase-flip code up to 3 cycles of error correction [J. Cramer et al., “Repeated quantum error correction on a continuously encoded qubit by real-time feedback”, Nature Communications 7, (2016) arXiv:1508.01388 DOI]; IBM 15-qubit device [J. R. Wootton and D. Loss, “Repetition code of 15 qubits”, Physical Review A 97, (2018) arXiv:1709.00990 DOI]; IBM Rochester device using 43-qubit code [J. R. Wootton, “Benchmarking near-term devices with quantum error correction”, Quantum Science and Technology 5, 044004 (2020) arXiv:2004.11037 DOI]; Google system performing up to 8 error-correction cycles on 5 and 9 qubits [J. Kelly et al., “State preservation by repetitive error detection in a superconducting quantum circuit”, Nature 519, 66 (2015) arXiv:1411.7403 DOI]; Google Quantum AI Sycamore utilizing up to 11 physical qubits and running 50 correction rounds [“Exponential suppression of bit or phase errors with cyclic error correction”, Nature 595, 383 (2021) arXiv:2102.06132 DOI]; Google Quantum AI Sycamore utilizing up to 25 qubits for comparison of logical error scaling with a quantum code [R. Acharya et al., “Suppressing quantum errors by scaling a surface code logical qubit”, (2022) arXiv:2207.06431] (see also [K. C. Miao et al., “Overcoming leakage in scalable quantum error correction”, (2022) arXiv:2211.04728]).
Continuous error correction protocols have been implemented on a 3-qubit superconducting qubit device [W. P. Livingston et al., “Experimental demonstration of continuous quantum error correction”, Nature Communications 13, (2022) arXiv:2107.11398 DOI].
Semiconductor spin-qubit devices: 3-qubit devices at RIKEN [K. Takeda et al., “Quantum error correction with silicon spin qubits”, Nature 608, 682 (2022) arXiv:2201.08581 DOI] and Delft [F. van Riggelen et al., “Phase flip code with semiconductor spin qubits”, (2022) arXiv:2202.11530].
Nitrogen-vacancy centers in diamond: 3-qubit phase-flip code [G. Waldherr et al., “Quantum error correction in a solid-state hybrid spin register”, Nature 506, 204 (2014) arXiv:1309.6424 DOI][T. Nakazato et al., “Quantum error correction of spin quantum memories in diamond under a zero magnetic field”, Communications Physics 5, (2022) DOI] (see also Ref. [T. H. Taminiau et al., “Universal control and error correction in multi-qubit spin registers in diamond”, Nature Nanotechnology 9, 171 (2014) arXiv:1309.5452 DOI]).
Trapped-ion device: 3-qubit phase-flip algorithm implemented in 3 cycles on high fidelity gate operations [P. Schindler et al., “Experimental Repetitive Quantum Error Correction”, Science 332, 1059 (2011) DOI]. Both phase- and bit-flip codes for 31 qubits and their stabilizer measurements have been realized by Quantinuum [S. A. Moses et al., “A Race-Track Trapped-Ion Quantum Processor”, Physical Review X 13, (2023) arXiv:2305.03828 DOI]. Multiple rounds of Steane error correction [L. Postler et al., “Demonstration of fault-tolerant Steane quantum error correction”, (2023) arXiv:2312.09745].

Trapped-ion qubits: state preparation with 98.8(1)% and 98.5(1)% fidelity for state \(|\overline{0}\rangle\) and \(|\overline{1}\rangle\), respectively, by N. Linke group [N. H. Nguyen et al., “Demonstration of Shor Encoding on a Trapped-Ion Quantum Computer”, Physical Review Applied 16, (2021) arXiv:2104.01205 DOI]. Variants of the code to handle coherent noise studied and realized by K. Brown and C. Monroe groups [D. M. Debroy et al., “Optimizing Stabilizer Parities for Improved Logical Qubit Memories”, Physical Review Letters 127, (2021) arXiv:2105.05068 DOI].
Optical systems: quantum teleportation of information implemented by J.-W. Pan group on maximally entangled pair of one physical and one logical qubit with fidelity rate of up to 78.6% [Y.-H. Luo et al., “Quantum teleportation of physical qubits into logical code spaces”, Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences 118, (2021) arXiv:2009.06242 DOI]. All-photonic quantum repeater architecture tested on the same code [R. Zhang et al., “Loss-tolerant all-photonic quantum repeater with generalized Shor code”, Optica 9, 152 (2022) arXiv:2203.07979 DOI].

\([[4,1,2]]\) subcode implemented using four-qubit graph state of photons [B. A. Bell et al., “Experimental demonstration of a graph state quantum error-correction code”, Nature Communications 5, (2014) arXiv:1404.5498 DOI].
Trapped-ion device by IonQ [N. M. Linke et al., “Fault-tolerant quantum error detection”, Science Advances 3, (2017) arXiv:1611.06946 DOI].
Logical state preparation and flag-qubit error correction realized in superconducting-circuit devices by IBM [M. Takita et al., “Experimental Demonstration of Fault-Tolerant State Preparation with Superconducting Qubits”, Physical Review Letters 119, (2017) arXiv:1705.09259 DOI][Quantum Information and Computation 18, (2018) arXiv:1705.08957 DOI][R. Harper and S. T. Flammia, “Fault-Tolerant Logical Gates in the IBM Quantum Experience”, Physical Review Letters 122, (2019) arXiv:1806.02359 DOI][E. H. Chen et al., “Calibrated Decoders for Experimental Quantum Error Correction”, Physical Review Letters 128, (2022) arXiv:2110.04285 DOI].
The subcode \(\{|\overline{00}\rangle,|\overline{10}\rangle\}\) [C. K. Andersen et al., “Repeated quantum error detection in a surface code”, Nature Physics 16, 875 (2020) arXiv:1912.09410 DOI] and \(\{|\overline{00}\rangle,|\overline{01}\rangle\}\) [“Exponential suppression of bit or phase errors with cyclic error correction”, Nature 595, 383 (2021) arXiv:2102.06132 DOI], treated as a planar surface code, has been realized in superconducting-circuit devices.
Logical gates between two copies of the subcode \(\{|\overline{10}\rangle,|\overline{11}\rangle\}\), interpreted as lattice surgery between planar surface codes, realized in superconducting circuits [A. Erhard et al., “Entangling logical qubits with lattice surgery”, Nature 589, 220 (2021) arXiv:2006.03071 DOI].
Logical gates for the \(\{|\overline{00}\rangle,|\overline{11}\rangle\}\) subcode, treated as a planar code, realized in superconducting circuits [J. F. Marques et al., “Logical-qubit operations in an error-detecting surface code”, Nature Physics 18, 80 (2021) arXiv:2102.13071 DOI].
The CZ magic state has been realized on an IBM heavy-hex superconducting circuit device [R. S. Gupta et al., “Encoding a magic state with beyond break-even fidelity”, (2023) arXiv:2305.13581].

NMR: Implementation of perfect error correcting code on 5 spin subsystem of labeled crotonic acid for quantum network benchmarking [E. Knill et al., “Benchmarking Quantum Computers: The Five-Qubit Error Correcting Code”, Physical Review Letters 86, 5811 (2001) arXiv:quant-ph/0101034 DOI]. Single-qubit logical gates [J. Zhang, R. Laflamme, and D. Suter, “Experimental Implementation of Encoded Logical Qubit Operations in a Perfect Quantum Error Correcting Code”, Physical Review Letters 109, (2012) arXiv:1208.4797 DOI]. Magic-state distillation using 7-qubit device [A. M. Souza et al., “Experimental magic state distillation for fault-tolerant quantum computing”, Nature Communications 2, (2011) arXiv:1103.2178 DOI].
Superconducting qubits [M. Gong et al., “Experimental exploration of five-qubit quantum error-correcting code with superconducting qubits”, National Science Review 9, (2021) arXiv:1907.04507 DOI].
Trapped-ion qubits: non-transversal CNOT gate between two logical qubits, including rounds of correction and fault-tolerant primitives such as flag qubits and pieceable fault tolerance, on a 12-qubit device by Quantinuum [C. Ryan-Anderson et al., “Implementing Fault-tolerant Entangling Gates on the Five-qubit Code and the Color Code”, (2022) arXiv:2208.01863]. Real-time magic-state distillation [N. C. Brown et al., “Advances in compilation for quantum hardware -- A demonstration of magic state distillation and repeat-until-success protocols”, (2023) arXiv:2310.12106].
Nitrogen-vacancy centers in diamond: fault-tolerant single-qubit Clifford operations [M. H. Abobeih et al., “Fault-tolerant operation of a logical qubit in a diamond quantum processor”, Nature 606, 884 (2022) arXiv:2108.01646 DOI].

Trapped ions: one-qubit addition algorithm implemented fault-tolerantly on the Quantinuum H1-1 device [Y. Wang et al., “Fault-Tolerant One-Bit Addition with the Smallest Interesting Colour Code”, (2023) arXiv:2309.09893].
Superconducting circuits: fault-tolerant \(CZZ\) gate performed on IBM and IonQ devices [D. H. Menendez, A. Ray, and M. Vasmer, “Implementing fault-tolerant non-Clifford gates using the [[8,3,2]] color code”, (2023) arXiv:2309.08663].
Rydberg atom arrays: Lukin group [Q. Xu et al., “Constant-Overhead Fault-Tolerant Quantum Computation with Reconfigurable Atom Arrays”, (2023) arXiv:2308.08648]. 48 logical qubits, 228 logical two-qubit gates, 48 logical CCZ gates, and error detection peformed in 16 blocks. Circuit outcomes were sampled and cross-entropy (XEB) was calculated to verify quantumness. Logical entanglement entropy was measured [D. Bluvstein et al., “Logical quantum processor based on reconfigurable atom arrays”, Nature (2023) arXiv:2312.03982 DOI].

Trapped-ion qubits: seven-qubit device in Blatt group [D. Nigg et al., “Quantum computations on a topologically encoded qubit”, Science 345, 302 (2014) arXiv:1403.5426 DOI], ten-qubit QCCD device by Quantinuum [C. Ryan-Anderson et al., “Realization of real-time fault-tolerant quantum error correction”, (2021) arXiv:2107.07505] realizing repeated rounds of error correction, real-time look-up-table decoding, and non-fault-tolerant magic-state distillations (see APS Physics Synopsis [P. Ball, “Real-Time Error Correction for Quantum Computing”, Physics 14, (2021) DOI]). Fault-tolerant universal two-qubit gate set by Monz group [L. Postler et al., “Demonstration of fault-tolerant universal quantum gate operations”, Nature 605, 675 (2022) arXiv:2111.12654 DOI]. Logical CNOT gate between two logical qubits, including rounds of correction and fault-tolerant primitives such as flag qubits and pieceable fault tolerance, on a 20-qubit device by Quantinuum [C. Ryan-Anderson et al., “Implementing Fault-tolerant Entangling Gates on the Five-qubit Code and the Color Code”, (2022) arXiv:2208.01863]; logical fidelity interval of the combined preparation-CNOT-measurement procedure was higher than that of the unencoded physical qubits. Multiple rounds of Steane error correction [L. Postler et al., “Demonstration of fault-tolerant Steane quantum error correction”, (2023) arXiv:2312.09745].
Rydberg atom arrays: Lukin group [D. Bluvstein et al., “A quantum processor based on coherent transport of entangled atom arrays”, Nature 604, 451 (2022) arXiv:2112.03923 DOI]; transversal CNOT gate performed on distance \(3\), \(5\), and \(7\) codes, logical ten-qubit GHZ state initialized with break-even fidelity, fault-tolerant logical two-qubit GHZ state initialized [D. Bluvstein et al., “Logical quantum processor based on reconfigurable atom arrays”, Nature (2023) arXiv:2312.03982 DOI].

The \([[m^2,1,m]]\) codes for \(m\leq 7\) have been realized in trapped-ion quantum devices [N. H. Nguyen et al., “Demonstration of Shor Encoding on a Trapped-Ion Quantum Computer”, Physical Review Applied 16, (2021) arXiv:2104.01205 DOI].

Used to obtain explicit lower bounds in the sum-of-squares game [M. Hopkins and T.-C. Lin, “Explicit Lower Bounds Against \(Ω(n)\)-Rounds of Sum-of-Squares”, (2022) arXiv:2204.11469].
States that, on average, achieve small violations of check operators for quantum Tanner codes require a circuit of non-constant depth to make. They are used in the proof [A. Anshu, N. P. Breuckmann, and C. Nirkhe, “NLTS Hamiltonians from Good Quantum Codes”, Proceedings of the 55th Annual ACM Symposium on Theory of Computing (2023) arXiv:2206.13228 DOI] of the No low-energy trivial states (NLTS) conjecture [M. H. Freedman and M. B. Hastings, “Quantum Systems on Non-\(k\)-Hyperfinite Complexes: A Generalization of Classical Statistical Mechanics on Expander Graphs”, (2013) arXiv:1301.1363].

The \([[m^2,1,m]]\) codes for \(m\leq 7\) have been realized in trapped-ion quantum devices [N. H. Nguyen et al., “Demonstration of Shor Encoding on a Trapped-Ion Quantum Computer”, Physical Review Applied 16, (2021) arXiv:2104.01205 DOI].

Fully homomorphic encryption [G. Alagic et al., “Quantum Fully Homomorphic Encryption with Verification”, Advances in Cryptology – ASIACRYPT 2017 438 (2017) arXiv:1708.09156 DOI].
Entanglement purification protocols related to quantum key distribution (QKD) [P. W. Shor and J. Preskill, “Simple Proof of Security of the BB84 Quantum Key Distribution Protocol”, Physical Review Letters 85, 441 (2000) arXiv:quant-ph/0003004 DOI].
Cryptographic applications stemming from the monogamy of entanglement of CSS code and error words [A. Coladangelo et al., “Hidden Cosets and Applications to Unclonable Cryptography”, (2022) arXiv:2107.05692].

Braiding of defects has been demonstrated for a five-qubit version of code [J. R. Wootton, “Demonstrating non-Abelian braiding of surface code defects in a five qubit experiment”, Quantum Science and Technology 2, 015006 (2017) arXiv:1609.07774 DOI].

Superconducting circuits: Distance-five 25-qubit code implemented on a superconducting quantum processor by Google Quantum AI [R. Acharya et al., “Suppressing quantum errors by scaling a surface code logical qubit”, (2022) arXiv:2207.06431]. This code outperformed the average of several instances of the smaller distance-three 9-qubit \(XZZX\) variant of the surface-17 code realized on the same device, both in terms of logical error probability over 25 cycles and in terms of logical error per cycle. This increase in error-correcting capabilities while using more physical qubits supports the notion of an error threshold. Braiding of defects has been demonstrated for the distance-five code [T. I. Andersen et al., “Non-Abelian braiding of graph vertices in a superconducting processor”, (2023) arXiv:2210.10255]. Leakage errors have been handled in a separate work in a distance-three code [K. C. Miao et al., “Overcoming leakage in scalable quantum error correction”, (2022) arXiv:2211.04728].

One cycle of syndrome readout on 19-qubit planar and 24-qubit toric codes realized in two-dimensional Rydberg atomic arrays [D. Bluvstein et al., “A quantum processor based on coherent transport of entangled atom arrays”, Nature 604, 451 (2022) arXiv:2112.03923 DOI]. 
Signatures of corresponding topological phase of matter detected in superconducting circuits [K. J. Satzinger et al., “Realizing topologically ordered states on a quantum processor”, Science 374, 1237 (2021) arXiv:2104.01180 DOI] and two-dimensional Rydberg atomic arrays [G. Semeghini et al., “Probing topological spin liquids on a programmable quantum simulator”, Science 374, 1242 (2021) arXiv:2104.04119 DOI]. 
Ground state of the toric code has been implemented with and without twists, and the non-Abelian braiding behavior of the twists, which realize Ising anyons, has been demonstrated [S. Xu et al., “Digital simulation of projective non-Abelian anyons with 68 superconducting qubits”, Chinese Physics Letters (2023) arXiv:2211.09802 DOI].

Implemented at ETH Zurich by the Wallraff group [S. Krinner et al., “Realizing repeated quantum error correction in a distance-three surface code”, Nature 605, 669 (2022) arXiv:2112.03708 DOI] and on the Zuchongzhi 2.1 superconducting quantum processor [Y. Zhao et al., “Realization of an Error-Correcting Surface Code with Superconducting Qubits”, Physical Review Letters 129, (2022) arXiv:2112.13505 DOI]. Both experimental error rates are above the pseudothreshold for this code relative to a single qubit; see Physics viewpoint for a summary [L. Frunzio and S. Singh, “Error-Correcting Surface Codes Get Experimental Vetting”, Physics 15, (2022) DOI]. Magic state have been created on the latter processor [Y. Ye et al., “Logical Magic State Preparation with Fidelity Beyond the Distillation Threshold on a Superconducting Quantum Processor”, (2023) arXiv:2305.15972].

Trapped-ion qubits: state preparation, logical measurement, and stabilizer measurement for nine-qubit Bacon-Shor code demonstrated on a 13-qubit device by M. Cetina and C. Monroe groups [L. Egan et al., “Fault-Tolerant Operation of a Quantum Error-Correction Code”, (2021) arXiv:2009.11482].

Logical state preparation and flag-qubit error correction realized in superconducting-circuit devices (specifically, fixed-frequency transmon qubit architectures) by IBM for \(d=2\) [M. Takita et al., “Experimental Demonstration of Fault-Tolerant State Preparation with Superconducting Qubits”, Physical Review Letters 119, (2017) arXiv:1705.09259 DOI][E. H. Chen et al., “Calibrated Decoders for Experimental Quantum Error Correction”, Physical Review Letters 128, (2022) arXiv:2110.04285 DOI] and \(d=3\) [N. Sundaresan et al., “Demonstrating multi-round subsystem quantum error correction using matching and maximum likelihood decoders”, Nature Communications 14, (2023) arXiv:2203.07205 DOI].

relations_cousins_detail: The antipode and anticode construcions are morally similar [J. H. Conway and N. J. A. Sloane, Sphere Packings, Lattices and Groups (Springer New York, 1999) DOI].

BW lattice codes are lattice analogues of RM codes in that both can be constructed recursively via a \(|u|u+v|\) construction [E. L. Cusack, “Error control codes for QAM signalling”, Electronics Letters 20, 62 (1984) DOI][G. D. Forney, “Coset codes. I. Introduction and geometrical classification”, IEEE Transactions on Information Theory 34, 1123 (1988) DOI].
The RM\((1,4)\) code can be used to obtain the \(\Lambda_{16}\) Barnes-Wall lattice code [T. Ericson, and V. Zinoviev, eds. Codes on Euclidean spheres. Elsevier, 2001.; Ex. 10.7.2].

The \(\Lambda_{24}\) Leech lattice can be obtained by lifting the Golay code to \(\mathbb{Z}_4\) [A. R. Hammons et al., “The Z/sub 4/-linearity of Kerdock, Preparata, Goethals, and related codes”, IEEE Transactions on Information Theory 40, 301 (1994) DOI], appending a parity check, and applying construction \(A_4\) [A. Bonnecaze and P. Solé, “Quaternary constructions of formally self-dual binary codes and unimodular lattices”, Algebraic Coding 194 (1994) DOI] (see also [J. H. Conway and N. J. A. Sloane, Sphere Packings, Lattices and Groups (Springer New York, 1999) DOI]). Half of the lattice can be obtained in a different construction [T. Ericson, and V. Zinoviev, eds. Codes on Euclidean spheres. Elsevier, 2001.; Ex. 10.7.3].
Several spherical sharp configrations are derived from the \(\Lambda_{24}\) Leech lattice [H. Cohn and A. Kumar, “Universally optimal distribution of points on spheres”, Journal of the American Mathematical Society 20, 99 (2006) arXiv:math/0607446 DOI].

Each binary code yields a sphere packing under Construction \(A\).
Every binary linear code yields a lattice code under Construction \(A\).
The hexacode can be used to obtain the Coxeter-Todd \(K_{12}\) lattice code [T. Ericson, and V. Zinoviev, eds. Codes on Euclidean spheres. Elsevier, 2001.; Ex. 10.5.6].

The bcc and fcc lattices are dual to each other.
The bcc and fcc lattices are dual to each other.
Dual lattices are lattice analogues of dual codes.

Unimodular lattices are lattice analogues of self-dual codes. There are several parallels between (doubly-even) self-dual binary codes and (even) unimodular lattices [J. H. Conway and N. J. A. Sloane, Sphere Packings, Lattices and Groups (Springer New York, 1999) DOI][Self-Dual Codes and Invariant Theory (Springer-Verlag, 2006) DOI].
There are parallels between self-dual additive codes over \(\mathbb{Z}_{2k}\) and even unimodular lattices [E. Bannai et al., “Type II codes, even unimodular lattices, and invariant rings”, IEEE Transactions on Information Theory 45, 1194 (1999) DOI].

Niemeier lattice codes can be constructed from ternary self-dual codes of length 24 [P. S. Montague, “A new construction of lattices from codes over GF(3)”, Discrete Mathematics 135, 193 (1994) DOI].
Niemeier lattice codes can be constructed from quaternary codes over \(\mathbb{Z}_4\) via Construction \(A_4\) [A. Bonnecaze et al., “Niemeier lattices and Type II codes over Z4”, Discrete Mathematics 205, 1 (1999) DOI].
The octacode can be used to construct a Niemeier lattice code via Construction \(A_4\) [A. Bonnecaze et al., “Niemeier lattices and Type II codes over Z4”, Discrete Mathematics 205, 1 (1999) DOI].
The four-bit repetition code yields the \(D_4\) hyper-diamond lattice code via the mod-two lattice construction.
\([n,n-1,2]\) SPC codes yield \(D_n\) checkerboard lattice codes via the mod-two lattice construction [T. Ericson, and V. Zinoviev, eds. Codes on Euclidean spheres. Elsevier, 2001.; Ex. 10.5.1].

The \([8,4,4]\) extended Hamming code yields the \(E_8\) Gosset lattice code via the mod-two lattice construction [T. Ericson, and V. Zinoviev, eds. Codes on Euclidean spheres. Elsevier, 2001.; Ex. 10.5.2].
The octacode yields the \(E_8\) Gosset lattice code via Construction \(A_4\) [A. Bonnecaze and P. Solé, “Quaternary constructions of formally self-dual binary codes and unimodular lattices”, Algebraic Coding 194 (1994) DOI][A. Bonnecaze, P. Sole, and A. R. Calderbank, “Quaternary quadratic residue codes and unimodular lattices”, IEEE Transactions on Information Theory 41, 366 (1995) DOI].
The \([4,2,3]_3\) ternary Hamming code can be used to obtain the \(E_8\) Gosset lattice code [T. Ericson, and V. Zinoviev, eds. Codes on Euclidean spheres. Elsevier, 2001.; Ex. 10.5.5].
The \([8,1,8]\) repetition code can be used to obtain the \(E_8\) Gosset lattice code [T. Ericson, and V. Zinoviev, eds. Codes on Euclidean spheres. Elsevier, 2001.; Ex. 10.7.1].
Several spherical sharp configrations are derived from the \(E_8\) Gosset lattice code [H. Cohn and A. Kumar, “Universally optimal distribution of points on spheres”, Journal of the American Mathematical Society 20, 99 (2006) arXiv:math/0607446 DOI].

The \([7,4,3]\) Hamming code yields the \(E_7^{\perp}\) root lattice code via the mod-two lattice construction [J. H. Conway and N. J. A. Sloane, “On the Voronoi Regions of Certain Lattices”, SIAM Journal on Algebraic Discrete Methods 5, 294 (1984) DOI]. The \([7,3,4]\) little Hamming code yields the \(E_7\) root lattice code via the same construction [J. H. Conway and N. J. A. Sloane, “On the Voronoi Regions of Certain Lattices”, SIAM Journal on Algebraic Discrete Methods 5, 294 (1984) DOI][T. Ericson, and V. Zinoviev, eds. Codes on Euclidean spheres. Elsevier, 2001.; Ex. 10.5.3].
The \([3,1,3]_3\) ternary repetition code can be used to obtain the \(E_6\) root lattice code [T. Ericson, and V. Zinoviev, eds. Codes on Euclidean spheres. Elsevier, 2001.; Ex. 10.5.4].
The Voronoi cell of the hexagonal lattice is the hexagon.

The hypercubic lattice is the \(m=1\) BW lattice.
The generator matrix of a lattice-based code serves as a linear transformation that can be applied to the hypercubic lattice to obtain said code [T. Ericson, and V. Zinoviev, eds. Codes on Euclidean spheres. Elsevier, 2001.; Ch. 10].

QAM encodings often consist of lattice constellations, i.e., finite sets of points scooped out of an infinite 2D lattice.
Finite-energy GKP codes are quantum analogues of lattice-based QAM codes in that both use a subset of points on a lattice.
2D Gray codes are often concatenated with \(n=1\) lattice-based QAM codes so that the Hamming distance between the bitstrings encoded into the points is a discretized version of the Euclidean distance between the points.

The hexagonal lattice code is universally optimal among all lattices, but has not been proven to be optimal over all periodic packings [H. L. Montgomery, “Minimal theta functions”, Glasgow Mathematical Journal 30, 75 (1988) DOI].
Binary group-orbit codes can be mapped into Slepian group-orbit codes via various mappings [T. Ericson, and V. Zinoviev, eds. Codes on Euclidean spheres. Elsevier, 2001.; Ch. 8].

Linear binary codes with distances \(\frac{1}{2}n-\sqrt{t n}\) for some \(t\) are called almost-orthogonal and are locally testable with query complexity of order \(O(t)\) [T. Kaufman and S. Litsyn, “Almost Orthogonal Linear Codes are Locally Testable”, 46th Annual IEEE Symposium on Foundations of Computer Science (FOCS’05) DOI]. This was later improved to codes with distance \(\frac{1}{2}n-O(n^{1-\gamma})\) for any positive \(\gamma\) [T. Kaufman and M. Sudan, “Sparse Random Linear Codes are Locally Decodable and Testable”, 48th Annual IEEE Symposium on Foundations of Computer Science (FOCS’07) (2007) DOI], provided that the number of codewords is polynomial in \(n\).

Designs can be constructed from \(q\)-ary codes by taking the supports of a subset of codewords of constant weight.
The supports of all fixed-weight codewords of a \(q\)-ary cyclic code support a combinatorial \(1\)-design [V. D. Tonchev, "Codes and designs." Concise Encyclopedia of Coding Theory (Chapman and Hall/CRC, 2021) DOI; Corr. 5.2.4].
Fixed-weight RM codewords of weight less than \(2^m\) support combinatorial 3-designs [V. D. Tonchev, "Codes and designs." Concise Encyclopedia of Coding Theory (Chapman and Hall/CRC, 2021) DOI; Ex. 5.2.7].
Weight-three and weight-four codewords of the \([7,4,3]\) Hamming code support combinatorial \(2-(7,3,1)\) and \(2-(7,4,2)\) designs, respectively [V. D. Tonchev, "Codes and designs." Concise Encyclopedia of Coding Theory (Chapman and Hall/CRC, 2021) DOI; Ex. 5.2.5].
Weight-three codewords of the \([2^r-1,2^r-r-1, 3]\) Hamming code support the Steiner system \(S(2,3,2^r-1)\) [10.1007/978-1-4757-6568-7; pg. 89].
Weight-four codewords of the \([2^r,2^r-r-1, 4]\) extended Hamming code support the Steiner system \(S(3,4,2^r)\) [10.1007/978-1-4757-6568-7; pg. 89].
The supports of the weight-seven (weight-eight) codewords of the (extended) Golay code support the Steiner system \(S(4,7,23)\) (\(S(5,6,12)\)) [10.1007/978-1-4757-6568-7; pg. 89]. Its blocks are called octads.
The supports of the weight-five (weight-six) codewords of the (extended) ternary Golay code support the Steiner system \(S(4,5,11)\) (\(S(5,6,12)\)) [10.1007/978-1-4757-6568-7; pg. 89]. Its blocks are called hexads.
Perfect codes and combinatorial designs are related [E. F. Assmus, Jr. and H. F. Mattson, Jr., “Coding and Combinatorics”, SIAM Review 16, 349 (1974) DOI].
Linear codes and their duals are related to combinatorial designs via the Assmus-Mattson theorem [E. F. Assmus Jr. and H. F. Mattson Jr., “New 5-designs”, Journal of Combinatorial Theory 6, 122 (1969) DOI] (see [V. D. Tonchev, "Codes and designs." Concise Encyclopedia of Coding Theory (Chapman and Hall/CRC, 2021) DOI; Sec. 5.4]).
Self-dual extremal codes yield combinatorial \(\leq 5\)-designs using the Assmus-Mattson theorem [E. F. Assmus Jr. and H. F. Mattson Jr., “New 5-designs”, Journal of Combinatorial Theory 6, 122 (1969) DOI] (see [V. D. Tonchev, "Codes and designs." Concise Encyclopedia of Coding Theory (Chapman and Hall/CRC, 2021) DOI; Sec. 5.4]). See [C. J. Colbourn, editor , CRC Handbook of Combinatorial Designs (CRC Press, 2010) DOI; Table 1.61, pg. 683] for a table of combinatorial designs obtained from self-dual codes.
Some Steiner systems can be used to construct Gallager codes [D. J. C. MacKay and M. C. Davey, “Evaluation of Gallager Codes for Short Block Length and High Rate Applications”, Codes, Systems, and Graphical Models 113 (2001) DOI].
Combinatorial designs can be used to construct explicit LDPC codes [S. J. Johnson and S. R. Weller, “Regular low-density parity-check codes from combinatorial designs”, Proceedings 2001 IEEE Information Theory Workshop (Cat. No.01EX494) DOI][S. J. Johnson and S. R. Weller, “Construction of low-density parity-check codes from Kirkman triple systems”, GLOBECOM’01. IEEE Global Telecommunications Conference (Cat. No.01CH37270) DOI][S. J. Johnson and S. R. Weller, “Resolvable 2-designs for regular low-density parity-check codes”, IEEE Transactions on Communications 51, 1413 (2003) DOI].

Only double error-correcting BCH codes \([2^m-1,n-2m,5]\) are quasi-perfect [D. Gorenstein, W. W. Peterson, and N. Zierler, “Two-error correcting Bose-Chaudhuri codes are quasi-perfect”, Information and Control 3, 291 (1960) DOI][T. Helleseth, “No primitive binary&lt;tex&gt;t&lt;/tex&gt;-error-correcting BCH code with&lt;tex&gt;t &gt; 2&lt;/tex&gt;is quasi-perfect (Corresp.)”, IEEE Transactions on Information Theory 25, 361 (1979) DOI] (see also Ref. [F. J. MacWilliams and N. J. A. Sloane. The theory of error correcting codes. Elsevier, 1977.], Ch. 9).
The \([15,5,7]\) BCH code extended with a parity check saturates the Griesmer bound ([J. Bierbrauer, Introduction to Coding Theory (Chapman and Hall/CRC, 2016) DOI], pg. 157).

Cyclic linear codes cannot be \(c^3\)-LTCs [L. Babai, A. Shpilka, and D. Stefankovic, “Locally Testable Cyclic Codes”, IEEE Transactions on Information Theory 51, 2849 (2005) DOI]. Codeword symmetries are in general an obstruction to achieving such LTCs [M. Sudan, “Invariance in Property Testing”, Property Testing 211 (2010) DOI].

The self-dual \([48,24,12]\) extended quadratic residue code is a group-algebra code [I. McLoughlin, “A group ring construction of the [48,24,12] type II linear block code”, Designs, Codes and Cryptography 63, 29 (2011) DOI][W. Willems, "Codes in Group Algebras." Concise Encyclopedia of Coding Theory (Chapman and Hall/CRC, 2021) DOI; Ex. 16.5.1].
Extended binary quadratic residue codes of length \(8m\) are self-dual doubly-even codes [J. H. Conway and N. J. A. Sloane, Sphere Packings, Lattices and Groups (Springer New York, 1999) DOI; pg. 82].

The extended Golay code is nearly perfect.
The extended Golay code is self-dual.
The extended Golay code is a group-algebra code for various groups [I. McLoughlin and T. Hurley, “A Group Ring Construction of the Extended Binary Golay Code”, IEEE Transactions on Information Theory 54, 4381 (2008) DOI][S. T. Dougherty et al., “Group rings, G-codes and constructions of self-dual and formally self-dual codes”, Designs, Codes and Cryptography 86, 2115 (2017) DOI][F. Bernhardt, P. Landrock, and O. Manz, “The extended golay codes considered as ideals”, Journal of Combinatorial Theory, Series A 55, 235 (1990) DOI][W. Willems, "Codes in Group Algebras." Concise Encyclopedia of Coding Theory (Chapman and Hall/CRC, 2021) DOI; Ex. 16.5.1].
The Golay code and several of its extended, shortened, and punctured versions are LP universally optimal codes [H. Cohn and Y. Zhao, “Energy-Minimizing Error-Correcting Codes”, IEEE Transactions on Information Theory 60, 7442 (2014) arXiv:1212.1913 DOI].

Simplex codes are used to make gold codes. The dual of a Gold code is the interesection of the duals of the simplex codes used to construct it [M. des Noes et al., “Iterative decoding of Gold sequences”, 2015 IEEE International Conference on Communications (ICC) (2015) DOI].

Gold and Kasami codes are both constructed by picking a set of cyclically unrelated sequences of binary linear codes with low crosscorrelation [D. V. Sarwate and M. B. Pursley, “Crosscorrelation properties of pseudorandom and related sequences”, Proceedings of the IEEE 68, 593 (1980) DOI][T. Helleseth, C. Li, "Pseudo-Noise Sequences." Concise Encyclopedia of Coding Theory (Chapman and Hall/CRC, 2021) DOI].
Kasami codes satisfy the Griesmer bound for certain parameters [T. Helleseth and P. Vijay Kumar, “The weight hierarchy of the Kasami codes”, Discrete Mathematics 145, 133 (1995) DOI].
The even-weight subcode of the Melas code can be lifted to a code over \(\mathbb{Z}_4\) [A. Alahmadi et al., “On the lifted Melas code”, Cryptography and Communications 8, 7 (2015) DOI].

The Hadamard code is the dual of the extended Hamming Code. Conversely, the shortened Hadamard code is the dual of the Hamming Code.
The shortened Hadamard code is the dual of the Hamming Code.
The Hadamard code is the dual of the extended Hamming Code.
The augmented Hadamard code is the RM\((1,m)\) code.
The shortened Hadamard code maps to a \((2^m,2^m+1)\) simplex spherical code under the antipodal mapping [Forney, G. D. (2003). 6.451 Principles of Digital Communication II, Spring 2003.; Sec. 6.5.2][T. Ericson, and V. Zinoviev, eds. Codes on Euclidean spheres. Elsevier, 2001.; pg. 18].
The augmented Hadamard code maps to a \((2^m,2^{m+1})\) biorthogonal spherical code under the antipodal mapping [G. D. Forney and G. Ungerboeck, “Modulation and coding for linear Gaussian channels”, IEEE Transactions on Information Theory 44, 2384 (1998) DOI][Forney, G. D. (2003). 6.451 Principles of Digital Communication II, Spring 2003.; Sec. 6.4][T. Ericson, and V. Zinoviev, eds. Codes on Euclidean spheres. Elsevier, 2001.; pg. 19].
Hadamard codes for \(q=4r\) are sharp configurations [P. Boyvalenkov, D. Danev, "Linear programming bounds." Concise Encyclopedia of Coding Theory (Chapman and Hall/CRC, 2021) DOI; Table 12.1].
Several punctured versions of Hadamard codes are LP universally optimal codes [H. Cohn and Y. Zhao, “Energy-Minimizing Error-Correcting Codes”, IEEE Transactions on Information Theory 60, 7442 (2014) arXiv:1212.1913 DOI].
The Hadamard code is the first code to be identified as locally testable [M. Blum, M. Luby, and R. Rubinfeld, “Self-testing/correcting with applications to numerical problems”, Journal of Computer and System Sciences 47, 549 (1993) DOI].

Several extended Hamming codes are LP universally optimal codes [H. Cohn and Y. Zhao, “Energy-Minimizing Error-Correcting Codes”, IEEE Transactions on Information Theory 60, 7442 (2014) arXiv:1212.1913 DOI].
Shortened Hamming codes \([2^r-2,2^r-r-2,3]\) are nearly perfect ([F. J. MacWilliams and N. J. A. Sloane. The theory of error correcting codes. Elsevier, 1977.], pg. 533).

The \([7,4,3]\) Hamming code parity-check matrix corresponds to points in the Fano plane \(PG_2(2)\) [C. A. Kelley, "Codes over Graphs." Concise Encyclopedia of Coding Theory (Chapman and Hall/CRC, 2021) DOI; Ex. 21.4.2].
The Hamming code can be extended by a parity-check bit to yield the \([8,4,4]\) extended Hamming code, the smallest doubly-even self-dual code.
The Steane code is constructed from the \([7,4,3]\) classical Hamming code.
Starting with the \([6,3,3]\) shortened Hamming code and applying the \((u|u+v)\) construction recursively using the repetition code yields a family of \([2^m,m+1,2^{m-1}]\) codes for \(m\geq1\) that saturate the Griesmer bound [J. Bierbrauer, Introduction to Coding Theory (Chapman and Hall/CRC, 2016) DOI; pg. 90].
The extended Hamming code code is the smallest double-even self-dual code.

The PPM code is an continuous analogue of the one-hot code.
The PPM c-q code is an continuous analogue of the one-hot code designed for transmission through quantum channels.

Binary SPCs and repetition codes are dual to each other.
Any \([n,k,d]\) code with odd distance can be extended to an \([n+1,k,d+1]\) code by adding a bit storing the sum of codeword coordinates.
Concatenated SPCs are LDGM [T. R. Oenning and Jaekyun Moon, “A low-density generator matrix interpretation of parallel concatenated single bit parity codes”, IEEE Transactions on Magnetics 37, 737 (2001) DOI].

Repetition codes are perfect for odd \(n\).
The triple repetition code \([3,1,3]\) is the smallest Hamming code.

There are proposals [M. Asteris and A. G. Dimakis, “Repairable Fountain Codes”, (2014) arXiv:1401.0734][M. G. Luby et al., “Liquid Cloud Storage”, (2017) arXiv:1705.07983] adapting fountain codes to distributed storage systems.
Tornado codes, which can be used as a pre-code for raptor codes, also use a multi-layer approach where redundant symbols are created by one code for another code to use as input.

Tornado codes, the precursor to fountain codes, are much slower to encode and decode in the low-rate regime applicable to scalable data transmission [Joshi, G., Rhim, J. B., Sun, J., & Wang, D. (2010). Fountain codes. In Global telecommunications conference (GLOBECOM 2010) (pp. 7–12). IEEE.][A. Shokrollahi, “Raptor codes”, IEEE Transactions on Information Theory 52, 2551 (2006) DOI].
Tornado codes are similar to LDPC codes, but they use a highly irregular weight distribution for the underlying graphs [A. Shokrollahi, “Raptor codes”, IEEE Transactions on Information Theory 52, 2551 (2006) DOI].

An RS code is the outer code of Justesen codes.
Wozencraft ensemble forms the inner codes of Justesen codes.
The required inner codes are obtained by random sampling from the Wozencraft ensemble, whose length scales logarithmically with \(n\).
Using more general BCH codes instead of RS codes can improve the parameters of the Justesen codes [E. J. Weldon, “Justesen’s construction--The low-rate case (Corresp.)”, IEEE Transactions on Information Theory 19, 711 (1973) DOI].

Left-right Cayley complex codewords for a fixed graph vertex are codewords of a tensor code.
Left-right Cayley complex codes can be viewed as Tanner-like codes on expander graphs [S. Hoory, N. Linial, and A. Wigderson, “Expander graphs and their applications”, Bulletin of the American Mathematical Society 43, 439 (2006) DOI], but with bits defined on squares and constraints on edges (as opposed to edges and vertices, respectively, for expander codes). Expander codes are also typically not locally testable [E. Ben-Sasson, P. Harsha, and S. Raskhodnikova, “Some 3CNF properties are hard to test”, Proceedings of the thirty-fifth annual ACM symposium on Theory of computing (2003) DOI].
Left-right Cayley complexes can be obtained via a balanced product of \(G\)-graphs [I. Dinur et al., “Locally Testable Codes with constant rate, distance, and locality”, (2021) arXiv:2111.04808].
Applying the CSS construction to two left-right Cayley complex codes yields quantum Tanner codes, and one can simultaneously prove a linear distance for the quantum code and local testability for one of its constituent classical codes [A. Leverrier and G. Zémor, “Quantum Tanner codes”, (2022) arXiv:2202.13641].

Several anticode (e.g., [B. I. Belov, V. N. Logachev, V. P. Sandimirov, “Construction of a Class of Linear Binary Codes Achieving the Varshamov-Griesmer Bound”, Probl. Peredachi Inf., 10:3 (1974), 36–44; Problems Inform. Transmission, 10:3 (1974), 211–217][R. Hill, "Optimal Linear Codes in: C. Mitchell (Ed.) Crytography and Coding." (1992): 75-104.]) and related [B. I. Belov, "A conjecture on the Griesmer bound." Optimization Methods and Their Applications,(Russian), Sibirsk. Energet. Inst. Sibirsk. Otdel. Akad. Nauk SSSR, Irkutsk 182 (1974): 100-106.] constructions saturate the Griesmer bound; see Refs. [J. Bierbrauer, Introduction to Coding Theory (Chapman and Hall/CRC, 2016) DOI][I. N. Landjev, “Linear codes over finite fields and finite projective geometries”, Discrete Mathematics 213, 211 (2000) DOI][F. J. MacWilliams and N. J. A. Sloane. The theory of error correcting codes. Elsevier, 1977.] for more details.

Kerdock codes can be seen, via the Gray map, as extended linear cyclic codes over \(\mathbb{Z}_4\), where the appended bit is a zero sum check [A. R. Hammons et al., “The Z/sub 4/-linearity of Kerdock, Preparata, Goethals, and related codes”, IEEE Transactions on Information Theory 40, 301 (1994) DOI][A. R. Hammons Jr. et al., “The Z_4-Linearity of Kerdock, Preparata, Goethals and Related Codes”, (2002) arXiv:math/0207208].
Kerdock codes can be seen, via the Gray map, as extended linear cyclic codes over \(\mathbb{Z}_4\), where the appended bit is a zero sum check [A. R. Hammons et al., “The Z/sub 4/-linearity of Kerdock, Preparata, Goethals, and related codes”, IEEE Transactions on Information Theory 40, 301 (1994) DOI][A. R. Hammons Jr. et al., “The Z_4-Linearity of Kerdock, Preparata, Goethals and Related Codes”, (2002) arXiv:math/0207208].
Kerdock code is a subcode of a second-order RM Code [F. J. MacWilliams and N. J. A. Sloane. The theory of error correcting codes. Elsevier, 1977.; pg. 457]. It consists of a number of cosets of RM\((2,m)\) created by quotienting with RM\((1,m)\).
Preparata codes are dual to Kerdock codes in the sense of the MacWilliams weight distribution [W. Kantor, “On the inequivalence of generalized Preparata codes”, IEEE Transactions on Information Theory 29, 345 (1983) DOI]. However, the two codes are images of a pair of mutually dual linear codes over \(\mathbb{Z}_4\) under the Gray map [W. C. Huffman, J.-L. Kim, and P. Solé, Concise Encyclopedia of Coding Theory (Chapman and Hall/CRC, 2021) DOI; Sec. 6.3].
Kerdock codes can be obtained by Hensel-lifting Hamming codes to \(\mathbb{Z}_4\) [A. R. Hammons et al., “The Z/sub 4/-linearity of Kerdock, Preparata, Goethals, and related codes”, IEEE Transactions on Information Theory 40, 301 (1994) DOI].
Kerdock codes can be used to form a subset of stabilizer states, and the corresponding Clifford-group automorphisms of this set form a particular group [A. Calderbank et al., “Z\({}_{\text{4}}\) -Kerdock Codes, Orthogonal Spreads, and Extremal Euclidean Line-Sets”, Proceedings of the London Mathematical Society 75, 436 (1997) DOI] that is a unitary two-design [T. Can et al., “Kerdock Codes Determine Unitary 2-Designs”, IEEE Transactions on Information Theory 66, 6104 (2020) arXiv:1904.07842 DOI].
Kerdock codes are asymptotically universally optimal [W. C. Huffman, J.-L. Kim, and P. Solé, Concise Encyclopedia of Coding Theory (Chapman and Hall/CRC, 2021) DOI; Exam. 12.3.25].
The 24-cell is a special case of a family of codes for real projective planes, constructed using Kerdock codes [Levenshtein, V. I. (1982). Bounds on the maximal cardinality of a code with bounded modulus of the inner product. In Soviet Math. Dokl (Vol. 25, No. 2, pp. 526-531).] (cf. [H. Cohn, A. Kumar, and G. Minton, “Optimal simplices and codes in projective spaces”, Geometry & Topology 20, 1289 (2016) arXiv:1308.3188 DOI]).
The augmented Hadamard and Levenshtein codes are both constructed using Hadamard matrices.

Preparata codes can be seen, via the Gray map, as linear codes over \(\mathbb{Z}_4\) [A. R. Hammons et al., “The Z/sub 4/-linearity of Kerdock, Preparata, Goethals, and related codes”, IEEE Transactions on Information Theory 40, 301 (1994) DOI][A. R. Hammons Jr. et al., “The Z_4-Linearity of Kerdock, Preparata, Goethals and Related Codes”, (2002) arXiv:math/0207208].
Preparata codes can be seen, via the Gray map, as linear codes over \(\mathbb{Z}_4\) [A. R. Hammons et al., “The Z/sub 4/-linearity of Kerdock, Preparata, Goethals, and related codes”, IEEE Transactions on Information Theory 40, 301 (1994) DOI][A. R. Hammons Jr. et al., “The Z_4-Linearity of Kerdock, Preparata, Goethals and Related Codes”, (2002) arXiv:math/0207208].
Punctured Preparata codes are quasi-perfect [F. J. MacWilliams and N. J. A. Sloane. The theory of error correcting codes. Elsevier, 1977.; pg. 475].
A Preparata code can be written as a union of a linear subcode \(\mathcal{C}\) of RM\((m-2,m)\) and the \(2^{m-1}-1\) representatives of coset formed by \(\mathcal{C}\) in RM\((m-2,m)\). The coset representatives are given by \(|1|x^j|0|x^{j}\theta_{1}|\), where \(1\leq j \leq 2^{m-1}-1\). \(\mathcal{C}\) comprises of codewords of the form \(|g(1)|g(x)(1+\theta_{1})|f(1)+g(1)|g(x)(1+\theta_{1})+f(x)(1+\theta_{1}+\theta_{3})|\), where \(f(x)\) and \(g(x)\) are arbitrary, and where \(\theta_{1}\) and \(\theta_{3}\) denote the primitive idempotents corresponding to cyclotomic cosets \(C_1\) and \(C_3\) respectively.
Preparata codes contain twice as many code words as the double-error-correcting BCH codes of the same length, which is the largest number of code words possible for given length and distance [F. P. Preparata, “A class of optimum nonlinear double-error-correcting codes”, Information and Control 13, 378 (1968) DOI].
Preparata codes can be obtained by Hensel-lifting Hamming codes to \(\mathbb{Z}_4\) [A. R. Hammons et al., “The Z/sub 4/-linearity of Kerdock, Preparata, Goethals, and related codes”, IEEE Transactions on Information Theory 40, 301 (1994) DOI]. The union of the dual a Preparata code and some of its translates forms a Hamming code [F. J. MacWilliams and N. J. A. Sloane. The theory of error correcting codes. Elsevier, 1977.; pg. 475].

Using Construction \(A\), the Best code yields \(P_{10c}\), a non-lattice sphere packing in 10 dimensions that is the densest known [J. Leech and N. J. A. Sloane, “Sphere Packings and Error-Correcting Codes”, Canadian Journal of Mathematics 23, 718 (1971) DOI][J. H. Conway and N. J. A. Sloane, Sphere Packings, Lattices and Groups (Springer New York, 1999) DOI; pg. 140].
Using Construction \(A\), the Best code yields \(P_{10c}\), a non-lattice sphere packing in 10 dimensions that is the densest known [J. Leech and N. J. A. Sloane, “Sphere Packings and Error-Correcting Codes”, Canadian Journal of Mathematics 23, 718 (1971) DOI][J. H. Conway and N. J. A. Sloane, Sphere Packings, Lattices and Groups (Springer New York, 1999) DOI; pg. 140].
Codewords of the Best code can be obtained by applying the Gray map to the pentacode [J. H. Conway and N. J. A. Sloane, “Quaternary constructions for the binary single-error-correcting codes of Julin, Best and others”, Designs, Codes and Cryptography 4, 31 (1994) DOI; Sec. 2].

Using Construction \(A\), the Julin-Golay codes yield non-lattice sphere-packings that hold records in 9 and 11 dimensions.
Using Construction \(A\), the Julin-Golay codes yield non-lattice sphere-packings that hold records in 9 and 11 dimensions.
Julin codes can be obtained from simple nonlinear codes over \(\mathbb{Z}_4\) using the Gray map [J. H. Conway and N. J. A. Sloane, “Quaternary constructions for the binary single-error-correcting codes of Julin, Best and others”, Designs, Codes and Cryptography 4, 31 (1994) DOI].
Julin codes can be obtained from simple nonlinear codes over \(\mathbb{Z}_4\) using the Gray map [J. H. Conway and N. J. A. Sloane, “Quaternary constructions for the binary single-error-correcting codes of Julin, Best and others”, Designs, Codes and Cryptography 4, 31 (1994) DOI].

By adapting a construction of Tenengolts [G. M. Tenengolts, Class of codes correcting bit loss and errors in the preceding bit (translated to English), Automation and Remote Control, 37(5), 797–802 (1976).], binary VT codes can be modified to yield slightly longer linear codes [N. J. A. Sloane, “On Single-Deletion-Correcting Codes”, (2002) arXiv:math/0207197].

RM codes rely on the same generator matrix, but place message bits in different coordinates. There are families interpolating between the two codes [M. Mondelli, S. H. Hassani, and R. L. Urbanke, “From Polar to Reed-Muller Codes: A Technique to Improve the Finite-Length Performance”, IEEE Transactions on Communications 62, 3084 (2014) DOI].
Quantum-classical polar codes generalize polar codes for transmission through channels with quantum output.
Fractal liquid codewords form the ground-state space of a class of spin-glass models with three-body interactions.
The Fibonacci code is designed to mimic the fractal properties of (quantum) Haah cubic code so that studying the former can help us toward the development of an efficient algorithm for the latter.

A family of homology codes saturate the asymptotic Hamming bound [H. Bombin and M. A. Martin-Delgado, “Homological error correction: Classical and quantum codes”, Journal of Mathematical Physics 48, (2007) arXiv:quant-ph/0605094 DOI].
Graph homology (classical) codes were inspired by homology-based quantum code constructions.
Newman-Moore codewords form the ground-state space of a class of exactly solvable spin-glass models with three-body interactions.

RM\(^*(r,m)\) codes are equivalent to subcodes of BCH codes of designed distance \(2^{m-r}-1\) while RM\((r,m)\) are subcodes of extended BCH codes of the same designed distance [F. J. MacWilliams and N. J. A. Sloane. The theory of error correcting codes. Elsevier, 1977.; Ch. 13].
RM codes are images of linear quaternary codes over \(\mathbb{Z}_4\) under the Gray map [S. T. Dougherty, "Codes over rings." Concise Encyclopedia of Coding Theory (Chapman and Hall/CRC, 2021) DOI; Sec. 6.3].
RM codes are images of linear quaternary codes over \(\mathbb{Z}_4\) under the Gray map [S. T. Dougherty, "Codes over rings." Concise Encyclopedia of Coding Theory (Chapman and Hall/CRC, 2021) DOI; Sec. 6.3].
The codes RM\((r,m)\) and RM\((m-r-1,m)\) are dual to each other.
Certain punctured RM codes such as RM\(^*(2,5)\) are duadic; see Ref. [W. C. Huffman and V. Pless, Fundamentals of Error-Correcting Codes (Cambridge University Press, 2003) DOI], Table 6.2.
Punctured RM codes are cyclic ([F. J. MacWilliams and N. J. A. Sloane. The theory of error correcting codes. Elsevier, 1977.], Ch. 13, Thm. 11), making RM codes extended cyclic codes. RM codes with nonzero evaluation points are cyclic ([M. A. Tsfasman and S. G. Vlăduţ, Algebraic-Geometric Codes (Springer Netherlands, 1991) DOI], pg. 52).
RM codes can be LTCs in the low- [N. Alon et al., “Testing Reed–Muller Codes”, IEEE Transactions on Information Theory 51, 4032 (2005) DOI][T. Kaufman and D. Ron, “Testing Polynomials over General Fields”, SIAM Journal on Computing 36, 779 (2006) DOI] and high-error [A. Samorodnitsky, “Low-degree tests at large distances”, (2006) arXiv:math/0604353] regimes.
The RM\((1,m)\) maps to a \((2^m,2^{m+1})\) biorthogonal spherical code under the antipodal mapping [G. D. Forney and G. Ungerboeck, “Modulation and coding for linear Gaussian channels”, IEEE Transactions on Information Theory 44, 2384 (1998) DOI][Forney, G. D. (2003). 6.451 Principles of Digital Communication II, Spring 2003.; Sec. 6.4][T. Ericson, and V. Zinoviev, eds. Codes on Euclidean spheres. Elsevier, 2001.; pg. 19].
Ta-Shma codes are \(\epsilon\)-balanced.
The multi-edge code construction generalizes generalizes several of the original examples of irregular LDPC codes.

Some deterministic protograph LDPC codes [C. A. Kelley, “On codes designed via algebraic lifts of graphs”, 2008 46th Annual Allerton Conference on Communication, Control, and Computing (2008) DOI] can be obtained from the theory of voltage graphs [C. A. Kelley and J. L. Walker, “LDPC codes from voltage graphs”, 2008 IEEE International Symposium on Information Theory (2008) DOI][L. W. Beineke et al., editors , Topics in Topological Graph Theory (Cambridge University Press, 2009) DOI].

IRA codes replace the outer 1-in-3 repetition encoding step in RA codes with an LDGM code.
MN-LDPC and IRA codes intersect for certain parameters [Henry D. Pfister, private communication, 2022].

There exist quasi-cyclic versions of RA codes [M. R. Tanner, "On quasi-cyclic repeat-accumulate codes." PROCEEDINGS OF THE ANNUAL ALLERTON CONFERENCE ON COMMUNICATION CONTROL AND COMPUTING. Vol. 37. The University; 1998, 1999.].

Tensor products of random LDPC codes are robustly testable [I. Dinur, M. Sudan, and A. Wigderson, “Robust Local Testability of Tensor Products of LDPC Codes”, Approximation, Randomization, and Combinatorial Optimization. Algorithms and Techniques 304 (2006) DOI][E. Ben-Sasson and M. Viderman, “Tensor Products of Weakly Smooth Codes Are Robust”, Lecture Notes in Computer Science 290 (2008) DOI].
The dual of an LDPC code has a sparse generator matrix and is called an LDGM code.
LDPC codes are often constructed non-determinisitically.

AB-LDPC codes are constructed from certain classes of B-codes. B-codes can be viewed as binary codes by mapping their ring elements to permutation matrices (cf. lifting). The resulting codes turn out to be LDPC [J. L. Fan, “Array Codes as LDPC Codes”, Constrained Coding and Soft Iterative Decoding 195 (2001) DOI].

QC-LDPC codes can be unwrapped to obtain LDPC-CCs by expressing each circulant matrix block as a power of some generating circulant matrix and replacing that generating matrix by the shift operator of the convolutional code [R. M. Tanner et al., “LDPC Block and Convolutional Codes Based on Circulant Matrices”, IEEE Transactions on Information Theory 50, 2966 (2004) DOI].

HA-LDPC codes are a concatenation of an LDPC and an LDGM code.
HA-LDPC codes are a concatenation of an LDPC and an LDGM code.

\((l,r,1\))-MN-LDPC codes are LDGM [K. KASAI and K. SAKANIWA, “Spatially-Coupled MacKay-Neal Codes and Hsu-Anastasopoulos Codes”, IEICE Transactions on Fundamentals of Electronics, Communications and Computer Sciences E94-A, 2161 (2011) arXiv:1102.4612 DOI].

Many FG-LDPC codes can be put into quasi-cyclic form [Y. Kou, S. Lin, and M. P. C. Fossorier, “Low-density parity-check codes based on finite geometries: a rediscovery and new results”, IEEE Transactions on Information Theory 47, 2711 (2001) DOI][Heng Tang et al., “Codes on finite geometries”, IEEE Transactions on Information Theory 51, 572 (2005) DOI][Latin Squares and Their Applications (Elsevier, 2015) DOI; pg. 286].
The parity-check matrix of a PG-LDPC code is the incidence matrix of points and hyperplanes in a projective space.
Infinite-block versions of SC-LDPC are LDPC-CCs.

The rank-modulation Gray code is an extension of the original binary Gray code to a code on the permutation group [Anxiao Jiang et al., “Rank Modulation for Flash Memories”, IEEE Transactions on Information Theory 55, 2659 (2009) DOI].
RS codes can be used to design rank modulation codes [A. Mazumdar, A. Barg, and G. Zemor, “Constructions of rank modulation codes”, 2011 IEEE International Symposium on Information Theory Proceedings (2011) DOI].
Binary permutation-based codes also encode messages into permutations but protect against errors with the Hamming distance.

The first matrix multiplication code encoded each entry of the matrices to be multiplied into an MDS code [K. Lee et al., “Speeding Up Distributed Machine Learning Using Codes”, IEEE Transactions on Information Theory 64, 1514 (2018) arXiv:1512.02673 DOI].

B-codes can be interpreted as RS codes over polynomials whose symbols lie in Galois rings [M. Blaum and R. M. Roth, “New array codes for multiple phased burst correction”, IEEE Transactions on Information Theory 39, 66 (1993) DOI][J. L. Fan, “Array Codes as LDPC Codes”, Constrained Coding and Soft Iterative Decoding 195 (2001) DOI].

Gabidulin codes over \(GF(q^N)\) with maximum rank-distance, when expressed as matrices over \(GF(q)\), are MRD codes.
Gabidulin codes over \(GF(q^N)\), when expressed as vectors over \(GF(q^N)\), are linear \(q\)-ary codes.

LRPC codes are rank-metric analogues of LDPC codes [Gaborit, P., Murat, G., Ruatta, O., & Zemor, G. (2013, April). Low rank parity check codes and their application to cryptography. In Proceedings of the Workshop on Coding and Cryptography WCC (Vol. 2013).].

MRD codes are matrix-code analogues of MDS codes.
MRD rank-metric codes can be thought of as matrix analogues of MDS Reed-Solomon codes as both constructions utilize a Vandermonde matrix [R. Koetter and F. R. Kschischang, “Coding for Errors and Erasures in Random Network Coding”, IEEE Transactions on Information Theory 54, 3579 (2008) DOI].

Constant-weight codes are classical analogues of qubit constant-excitation codes.
See [V. I. Levenshtein, “Designs as maximum codes in polynomial metric spaces”, Acta Applicandae Mathematicae 29, 1 (1992) DOI; Table 8.4] for constant-weight universally optimal \(q\)-ary codes.
Codes whose codewords have a constant weight of \(m\) are automatically \(m\)-divisible. However, divisible codes are linear by definition while constant-weight codes do not have to be.

A quasi group-algebra code for \(G\) being the cyclic group is a quasi-cyclic \(q\)-ary linear code.
Quasi-cyclic codes can be unwrapped to obtain convolutional codes [G. D. Forney, Jr., “Why quasi cyclic codes are interesting,” unpublished note, 1970.][G. Solomon and H. C. A. Tilborg, “A Connection Between Block and Convolutional Codes”, SIAM Journal on Applied Mathematics 37, 358 (1979) DOI][R. Michael Tanner, “Error-correcting coding system,” U.S. Patent 4295218, 1981.][R. Michael Tanner. Convolutional codes from quasi-cyclic codes: A link between the theories of block and convolutional codes. University of California, Santa Cruz, Computer Research Laboratory, 1987.][“Generalized tail-biting convolutional codes,” Ph.D. dissertation, Univ. of Massachusetts, Amherst, 1985.][Y. Levy and J. Costello, Jr., “An algebraic approach to constructing convolutional codes from quasi-cyclic codes,” DIMACS Ser. Discr. Math. and Theor. Comp. Sci., vol. 14, pp. 189–198, 1993.][M. Esmaeili et al., “A link between quasi-cyclic codes and convolutional codes”, IEEE Transactions on Information Theory 44, 431 (1998) DOI].
Quasi-cyclic binary code parity-check matrices can be used as sub-matrices to define a 1D SC-QLDPC code [M. Hagiwara et al., “Spatially Coupled Quasi-Cyclic Quantum LDPC Codes”, (2011) arXiv:1102.3181].

The 12 sets of antipodal pairs of the 24-cell code form a sharp configuration in the projective space \(\mathbb{R}P^3\) [H. Cohn and A. Kumar, “Universally optimal distribution of points on spheres”, Journal of the American Mathematical Society 20, 99 (2006) arXiv:math/0607446 DOI].
The 36 sets of antipodal pairs of the smallest \(E_6\) lattice shell form a sharp configuration in the projective space \(\mathbb{R}P^5\) [H. Cohn and A. Kumar, “Universally optimal distribution of points on spheres”, Journal of the American Mathematical Society 20, 99 (2006) arXiv:math/0607446 DOI].
The 63 sets of antipodal pairs of the smallest \(E_7\) lattice shell form a sharp configuration in the projective space \(\mathbb{R}P^6\) [H. Cohn and A. Kumar, “Universally optimal distribution of points on spheres”, Journal of the American Mathematical Society 20, 99 (2006) arXiv:math/0607446 DOI].

There are relations between LDCs and LTCs [T. Kaufman and M. Viderman, “Locally Testable vs. Locally Decodable Codes”, Approximation, Randomization, and Combinatorial Optimization. Algorithms and Techniques 670 (2010) DOI].

Near MDS \([n,k,d]_{GF(p^m)}\) AG codes exist when \(n,p,m\) satisfy certain relations according to the Tsfasman-Vladut bound [M. A. Tsfasman and S. G. Vlăduţ, Algebraic-Geometric Codes (Springer Netherlands, 1991) DOI][I. N. Landjev, “Linear codes over finite fields and finite projective geometries”, Discrete Mathematics 213, 211 (2000) DOI].

The degree of the divisor for evaluation AG codes is restricted to be less than \(n\). When there is no restriction, any \(q\)-ary linear code can be formulated as an evaluation AG code [R. Pellikan, B.-Z. Shen, and G. J. M. van Wee, “Which linear codes are algebraic-geometric?”, IEEE Transactions on Information Theory 37, 583 (1991) DOI].

Elliptic codes can be MDS [A. Couvreur, H. Randriambololona, "Algebraic Geometry Codes and Some Applications." Concise Encyclopedia of Coding Theory (Chapman and Hall/CRC, 2021) DOI; Ex. 15.5.3][M. A. Tsfasman and S. G. Vlăduţ, Algebraic-Geometric Codes (Springer Netherlands, 1991) DOI; pg. 310][M. Tsfasman, S. Vlǎduţ, and D. Nogin. Algebraic geometric codes: basic notions. Vol. 139. American Mathematical Society, 2022.; Sec. 4.4.2].

Some Hermitian codes are group-algebra codes [Hansen, Johan P. Group codes on algebraic curves. Universität zu Göttingen. SFB Geometrie und Analysis, 1987.][W. Willems, "Codes in Group Algebras." Concise Encyclopedia of Coding Theory (Chapman and Hall/CRC, 2021) DOI; Remark 16.4.14].
Some Klein-quartic codes are group-algebra codes [W. Willems, "Codes in Group Algebras." Concise Encyclopedia of Coding Theory (Chapman and Hall/CRC, 2021) DOI; Remark 16.4.14].
Some Suzuki-curve codes are group-algebra codes [W. Willems, "Codes in Group Algebras." Concise Encyclopedia of Coding Theory (Chapman and Hall/CRC, 2021) DOI; Remark 16.4.14].

Evaluation AG codes are evaluation codes on algebraic curves. Polynomial evaluation codes are evaluation codes of polynomials. Evaluation AG codes of polynomials are equivalent to polynomial evaluation codes on algebraic curves.

Evaluation codes on varieties can also be considered AG codes since they use algebraic geometry in quantifying code bounds. However, early AG constructions all used only one-dimensional varieties, i.e., algebraic curves.

GRM codes with nonzero evaluation points are cyclic ([M. A. Tsfasman and S. G. Vlăduţ, Algebraic-Geometric Codes (Springer Netherlands, 1991) DOI], pg. 52).
GRM codes for \(r<q\) can be LTCs in the low- [L. Babai et al., “Checking computations in polylogarithmic time”, Proceedings of the twenty-third annual ACM symposium on Theory of computing - STOC ’91 (1991) DOI][S. Arora et al., “Proof verification and the hardness of approximation problems”, Journal of the ACM 45, 501 (1998) DOI] and high-error [R. Raz and S. Safra, “A sub-constant error-probability low-degree test, and a sub-constant error-probability PCP characterization of NP”, Proceedings of the twenty-ninth annual ACM symposium on Theory of computing - STOC ’97 (1997) DOI][S. Arora and M. Sudan, “Improved low-degree testing and its applications”, Proceedings of the twenty-ninth annual ACM symposium on Theory of computing - STOC ’97 (1997) DOI] regimes.
