They admit weakly stable presentations of their correspoding groups [M. Chapman, T. Vidick, and H. Yuen, “Efficiently stable presentations from error-correcting codes”, (2023) arXiv:2311.04681].
GRM codes over prime-power fields are group-algebra codes [S. D. Berman, “On the theory of group codes”, Cybernetics 3, 25 (1969) DOI][Charpin, Pascale. Codes idéaux de certaines algèbres modulaires. Diss. 1982.][P. Landrock and O. Manz, “Classical codes as ideals in group algebras”, Designs, Codes and Cryptography 2, 273 (1992) DOI][W. Willems, "Codes in Group Algebras." Concise Encyclopedia of Coding Theory (Chapman and Hall/CRC, 2021) DOI; Ex. 16.4.11].

Nonzero codewords of minimum weight of a \(r\)th-order \(q\)-ary projective RM code correspond to algebraic hypersurfaces of degree \(r\) having the largest number of points in the projective space \(PG(n,q)\) [L. Storme, "Coding Theory and Galois Geometries." Concise Encyclopedia of Coding Theory (Chapman and Hall/CRC, 2021) DOI; Thm. 14.3.3].
PRM codes for \(r=1\) attain the Griesmer bound for all \(m\) [J. B. Little, “Algebraic geometry codes from higher dimensional varieties”, (2008) arXiv:0802.2349].
Goppa codes are locally testable [T. Kaufman and S. Litsyn, “Almost Orthogonal Linear Codes are Locally Testable”, 46th Annual IEEE Symposium on Foundations of Computer Science (FOCS’05) DOI].

Columns of parity-check matrices of triply extended RS codes consist of points of a hyperoval [J. Bierbrauer, Introduction to Coding Theory (Chapman and Hall/CRC, 2016) DOI; Prop. 17.5].
A GRS code can be extended to an MDS code ([W. C. Huffman and V. Pless, Fundamentals of Error-Correcting Codes (Cambridge University Press, 2003) DOI], Thm. 5.3.4). Extended and doubly extended narrow-sense RS codes are MDS ([W. C. Huffman and V. Pless, Fundamentals of Error-Correcting Codes (Cambridge University Press, 2003) DOI], Thms. 5.3.2 and 5.3.4), and there is an equivalence between the two for odd prime \(q\) [S. Ball, “On sets of vectors of a finite vector space in which every subset of basis size is a basis”, Journal of the European Mathematical Society 733 (2012) DOI].

GRS codes have distance \(n-k+1\), saturating the Singleton bound.
GRS codes are used in various cloud storage systems [H. Dau et al., “Repairing Reed-Solomon Codes With Multiple Erasures”, IEEE Transactions on Information Theory 64, 6567 (2018) arXiv:1612.01361 DOI].

The specific relations imposed on the polynomials of PV codes allow for them to be expressed in a similar way as FRS codes, but with more redundancy. Folded RS codes can be list-decoded up to a higher fraction of errors.

RS codes have distance \(n-k+1\), saturating the Singleton bound. If \(k \leq p\), then all linear MDS codes \( [n,k,n-k+1]_{p^m} \) are RS codes [S. Ball, “On sets of vectors of a finite vector space in which every subset of basis size is a basis”, Journal of the European Mathematical Society 733 (2012) DOI].
Narrow-sense RS codes are BCH codes [A. Couvreur, H. Randriambololona, "Algebraic Geometry Codes and Some Applications." Concise Encyclopedia of Coding Theory (Chapman and Hall/CRC, 2021) DOI; Remark 15.3.21][W. C. Huffman and V. Pless, Fundamentals of Error-Correcting Codes (Cambridge University Press, 2003) DOI; Thms. 5.2.1 and 5.2.3]. Their minimal distance is equal to their designed distance [J. H. Conway and N. J. A. Sloane, Sphere Packings, Lattices and Groups (Springer New York, 1999) DOI; pg. 81]. Moreover, an RS code can be represented as a union of cosets, with each coset being an interleaver of several binary BCH codes [A. Vardy and Y. Be’ery, “Bit-level soft-decision decoding of Reed-Solomon codes”, IEEE Transactions on Communications 39, 440 (1991) DOI].
If the length divides \(q-1\), then it is possible to construct a cyclic RS code.
Tensor codes constructed from RS codes are robustly testable [A. Polishchuk and D. A. Spielman, “Nearly-linear size holographic proofs”, Proceedings of the twenty-sixth annual ACM symposium on Theory of computing - STOC ’94 (1994) DOI].
RS codes can be used to construct LTCs encoding \(k\) bits with length \(k \text{polylog}(k)\) and query complexity \(\text{polylog}(k)\) [E. Ben-Sasson and M. Sudan, “Short PCPs with Polylog Query Complexity”, SIAM Journal on Computing 38, 551 (2008) DOI].

The binary Grassmannian \([35,6,16]\) code, whose points lie on the Grassmannian \({\mathbb{G}(2,4)}\), attains the Griesmer bound [J. B. Little, “Algebraic geometry codes from higher dimensional varieties”, (2008) arXiv:0802.2349].
Hermitian-hypersurface codes reduce to Hermitian codes of polynomials when the hypersurface is a curve.
Schubert varieties are subvarieties of Grassmannians, and Schubert codes were initially constructed as a generalization of Grassmannian codes.

Convolutional codes for finite block size are \(q\)-ary codes.
Convolutional codes are often used in concatenation with Reed-Solomon codes for communication [T. Halonen, J. Romero, and J. Melero, editors , “GSM, GPRS and EDGE Performance”, (2003) DOI].
LDPC-CCs are convolutional analogues of LDPC codes.

A linear binary or \(q\)-ary \([n,k,n-k+1]\) code is MDS if and only if its dual \([n,n-k,k+1]\) is MDS [W. C. Huffman, J.-L. Kim, and P. Solé, "Basics of coding theory." Concise Encyclopedia of Coding Theory (Chapman and Hall/CRC, 2021) DOI; Thm. 1.9.13].
A linear code is MDS (almost MDS) if and only if columns of its parity-check matrix form an \(n\)-arc (\(n\)-track) in projective space [S. M. Dodunekov and I. N. Landgev, “On near-MDS codes”, Proceedings of 1994 IEEE International Symposium on Information Theory DOI][J. W. P. Hirschfeld and L. Storme, “The Packing Problem in Statistics, Coding Theory and Finite Projective Spaces: Update 2001”, Developments in Mathematics 201 (2001) DOI]. The dual of a MDS code is an MDS code, so MDS codes are projective.
Different inner products are typically used to define duals of linear and additive codes.
The Pless symmetry code for \(p=5\) is the extended ternary Golay code.

Binary self-dual codes are singly-even and binary self-orthogonal codes that are not doubly-even are singly-even [S. Bouyuklieva, "Self-dual codes." Concise Encyclopedia of Coding Theory (Chapman and Hall/CRC, 2021) DOI; Def. 4.1.6]. The minimum distance of doubly-even binary self-dual codes asymptotically satisfies \(d\leq0.1664n+o(n)\) [I. Krasikov and S. Litsyn, “Linear programming bounds for doubly-even self-dual codes”, IEEE Transactions on Information Theory 43, 1238 (1997) DOI].
The difference between the definitions of dual linear and dual additive codes is in the trace used in the inner product.

There exists a \(5-(12, 6, 3)\) design in the dodecacode, and a \(3-(11, 5, 4)\) design in the shortened dodecacode [J. Kim and V. Pless, Designs, Codes and Cryptography 30, 187 (2003) DOI].
The dodecacode corresponds to a \([[12,0,6]]\) quantum code in the \(GF(4)\) representation [A. R. Calderbank et al., “Quantum Error Correction via Codes over GF(4)”, (1997) arXiv:quant-ph/9608006]. The \([[11,1,5]]\) quantum dodecacode code corresponds to the shortened dodecacode [A. J. Scott, “Probabilities of Failure for Quantum Error Correction”, Quantum Information Processing 4, 399 (2005) DOI]. A pure \([[10,1,4]]\) quantum code can be obtained from the doubly punctured dodecacode [A. J. Scott, “Probabilities of Failure for Quantum Error Correction”, Quantum Information Processing 4, 399 (2005) DOI]. These codes are not obtained from the Hermitian construction since none of the classical codes are linear.

The only other inequivalent \([10,5,6]_9\) code is a Reed-Solomon code, which is the unique Euclidean self-dual code for its parmaters, and which is not Hermitian self-dual [T. Baicheva, I. Bouyukliev, S. Dodunekov, and W. Willems, “On the [10; 5; 6] Reed-Solomon and Glynn codes,” Mathematica Balkanica, New Series, vol. 18, pp. 67–78, 200][T. A. Gulliver, J.-L. Kim, and Y. Lee, “New MDS or Near-MDS Self-Dual Codes”, IEEE Transactions on Information Theory 54, 4354 (2008) DOI][M. Grassl and T. A. Gulliver, “On circulant self-dual codes over small fields”, Designs, Codes and Cryptography 52, 57 (2009) DOI].
Applying the Hermitian construction to the Glynn code yields a \([[10,0,6]]_3\) quantum code [M. Grassl and M. Rotteler, “Quantum MDS codes over small fields”, 2015 IEEE International Symposium on Information Theory (ISIT) (2015) arXiv:1502.05267 DOI][S. Ball, “Some constructions of quantum MDS codes”, (2021) arXiv:1907.04391]. The \([[9,1,5]]_3\) quantum Glynn code can be obtained by applying the Hermitian construction to the shortened Glynn code [M. Grassl and M. Rotteler, “Quantum MDS codes over small fields”, 2015 IEEE International Symposium on Information Theory (ISIT) (2015) arXiv:1502.05267 DOI; Corr. 4] (cf. [S. Ball and R. Vilar, “The geometry of Hermitian self-orthogonal codes”, (2021) arXiv:2108.08088; Exam. 7]).

The hexacode is an extended ternary Hamming code [W. C. Huffman and V. Pless, Fundamentals of Error-Correcting Codes (Cambridge University Press, 2003) DOI; Exer. 578].
Applying the qubit Hermitian construction to the hexacode yields a \([[6,0,4]]\) quantum code [A. J. Scott, “Multipartite entanglement, quantum-error-correcting codes, and entangling power of quantum evolutions”, Physical Review A 69, (2004) arXiv:quant-ph/0310137 DOI] corresponding to the six-qubit perfect state. The five-qubit code can be obtained either by applying the qubit Hermitian construction to the shortened hexacode or by tracing out a qubit of the \([[6,0,4]]\) code [F. Pastawski et al., “Holographic quantum error-correcting codes: toy models for the bulk/boundary correspondence”, Journal of High Energy Physics 2015, (2015) arXiv:1503.06237 DOI; Appx. A].
Extended Golay codewords can be obtained from hexacodewords [J. H. Conway and N. J. A. Sloane, Sphere Packings, Lattices and Groups (Springer New York, 1999) DOI]. The hexacode can be used to decode the extended Golay code [V. Pless, “Decoding the Golay codes”, IEEE Transactions on Information Theory 32, 561 (1986) DOI]. There is also a connection between automoprhisms of the even Golay code and the holomorph of the hexacode [J. A. Harvey and G. W. Moore, “Moonshine, superconformal symmetry, and quantum error correction”, Journal of High Energy Physics 2020, (2020) arXiv:2003.13700 DOI].
The shortened hexacode is perfect [W. C. Huffman and V. Pless, Fundamentals of Error-Correcting Codes (Cambridge University Press, 2003) DOI; Exer. 578].

Columns of a Hamming parity-check matrix correspond to one-dimensional subspaces of \(GF(q)^n\).
Hamming codes are equivalent to cyclic codes when \(q\) and \(r\) are relatively prime ([F. J. MacWilliams and N. J. A. Sloane. The theory of error correcting codes. Elsevier, 1977.], pg. 194).
Some narrow sense BCH codes of length \(n=(q^r-1)/(q-1)\) such that \(\text{gcd}(r,q-1)=1\) are \(q\)-ary Hamming codes ([W. C. Huffman and V. Pless, Fundamentals of Error-Correcting Codes (Cambridge University Press, 2003) DOI], Thm. 5.1.4).
Hamming codes are dual to first-order GRM codes ([M. A. Tsfasman and S. G. Vlăduţ, Algebraic-Geometric Codes (Springer Netherlands, 1991) DOI], pg. 45).

Concatenated \(q\)-ary parity-check codes are LDGM [T. R. Oenning and Jaekyun Moon, “A low-density generator matrix interpretation of parallel concatenated single bit parity codes”, IEEE Transactions on Magnetics 37, 737 (2001) DOI].

The extended ternary Golay code is self-dual.
The extended ternary Golay code admits a projective geometric construction ([J. Bierbrauer, Introduction to Coding Theory (Chapman and Hall/CRC, 2016) DOI], pg. 296).
Extended ternary Golay code is 3-divisible ([J. Bierbrauer, Introduction to Coding Theory (Chapman and Hall/CRC, 2016) DOI], pg. 296).
The ternary Golay code and several of its extended, shortened, and punctured versions are LP universally optimal codes [H. Cohn and Y. Zhao, “Energy-Minimizing Error-Correcting Codes”, IEEE Transactions on Information Theory 60, 7442 (2014) arXiv:1212.1913 DOI].
The dual of the ternary Golay code is a projective two-weight code [A. E. Brouwer, "Two-weight Codes." Concise Encyclopedia of Coding Theory (Chapman and Hall/CRC, 2021) DOI; Ex. 19.3.2].

Extended ternary Golay codewords can be obtained from tetracodewords [J. H. Conway and N. J. A. Sloane, Sphere Packings, Lattices and Groups (Springer New York, 1999) DOI]. The tetracode can be used to decode the extended ternary Golay code [V. Pless, “Decoding the Golay codes”, IEEE Transactions on Information Theory 32, 561 (1986) DOI].

Narrow-sense BCH codes are Goppa codes with \(L=\{1,\alpha^{-1},\cdots,\alpha^{1-n}\}\) and \(G(x)=x^{\delta-1}\) ([W. C. Huffman and V. Pless, Fundamentals of Error-Correcting Codes (Cambridge University Press, 2003) DOI], pg. 522).
Duals of BCH codes are locally testable [T. Kaufman and S. Litsyn, “Almost Orthogonal Linear Codes are Locally Testable”, 46th Annual IEEE Symposium on Foundations of Computer Science (FOCS’05) DOI].

Cyclic linear codes cannot be \(c^3\)-LTCs [L. Babai, A. Shpilka, and D. Stefankovic, “Locally Testable Cyclic Codes”, IEEE Transactions on Information Theory 51, 2849 (2005) DOI]. Codeword symmetries are in general an obstruction to achieving such LTCs [M. Sudan, “Invariance in Property Testing”, Property Testing 211 (2010) DOI].
See Refs. [Yan Jia, San Ling, and Chaoping Xing, “On Self-Dual Cyclic Codes Over Finite Fields”, IEEE Transactions on Information Theory 57, 2243 (2011) DOI][S. Jitman et al., “Abelian Codes in Principal Ideal Group Algebras”, IEEE Transactions on Information Theory 59, 3046 (2013) DOI] for tables of cyclic self-dual codes.

Several shortened and punctured versions of the ovoid code are LP universally optimal codes [H. Cohn and Y. Zhao, “Energy-Minimizing Error-Correcting Codes”, IEEE Transactions on Information Theory 60, 7442 (2014) arXiv:1212.1913 DOI].

Denniston codes for \(i=1\) are based on hyperovals in \(PG(2,2^a)\) [Rudolf Schürer and Wolfgang Ch. Schmid. “Denniston Codes.” From MinT—the database of optimal net, code, OA, and OOA parameters. Version: 2015-09-03. http://mint.sbg.ac.at/desc_CDenniston.html].

If a \(p\)-ary Griesmer code with \(p\) prime is such that a power of \(p\) divides the distance, then the code is divisible by that power [H. N. Ward, “Divisibility of Codes Meeting the Griesmer Bound”, Journal of Combinatorial Theory, Series A 83, 79 (1998) DOI].

Hill projective-cap codes for \(n=56\) and \(78\) are \(q\)-ary sharp configurations [P. Boyvalenkov, D. Danev, "Linear programming bounds." Concise Encyclopedia of Coding Theory (Chapman and Hall/CRC, 2021) DOI; Table 12.1].

Codes based on hyperovals in \(PG_{2}(q)\) are \(q\)-ary sharp configurations [P. Boyvalenkov, D. Danev, "Linear programming bounds." Concise Encyclopedia of Coding Theory (Chapman and Hall/CRC, 2021) DOI; Table 12.1].
Codes based on hyperovals in \(PG_{2}(q)\) with even \(q\) are projective two-weight codes [A. E. Brouwer, "Two-weight Codes." Concise Encyclopedia of Coding Theory (Chapman and Hall/CRC, 2021) DOI; Exam. 19.2.1].

Codewords of an evaluation code of multivariate polynomials up to degree one evaluated at points in projective space yields a projective code.
Columns of parity-check matrices of doubly extended narrow-sense RS codes consist of points of a normal rational curve [L. Storme, "Coding Theory and Galois Geometries." Concise Encyclopedia of Coding Theory (Chapman and Hall/CRC, 2021) DOI; Def. 14.2.6].
Acrs corresponding to Griesmer codes are called Griesmer arcs [I. N. Landjev, “The Geometric Approach to Linear Codes”, Developments in Mathematics 247 (2001) DOI; pg. 248]. There is a one-to-one correspondence between Griesmer codes and minihypers [N. Hamada and M. Deza, “A characterization of νμ + 1 + ε, νμ; t, q-min.hypers and its applications to error-correcting codes and factorial designs”, Journal of Statistical Planning and Inference 22, 323 (1989) DOI][N. Hamada, Characterization of minihypers in a finite projective geometry and its applications to error-correcting codes, Bull. Osaka Women's Univ. 24 (1987), 1-24.]; see [J. W. P. Hirschfeld and L. Storme, “The Packing Problem in Statistics, Coding Theory and Finite Projective Spaces: Update 2001”, Developments in Mathematics 201 (2001) DOI][L. Storme, "Coding Theory and Galois Geometries." Concise Encyclopedia of Coding Theory (Chapman and Hall/CRC, 2021) DOI; Sec. 14.2.4] for more details.
There is a relation between anticodes and minihypers ([J. Bierbrauer, Introduction to Coding Theory (Chapman and Hall/CRC, 2016) DOI], pg. 295).

\(S(2,k)\) is an extended RS code [Rudolf Schürer and Wolfgang Ch. Schmid. “Simplex Code.” From MinT—the database of optimal net, code, OA, and OOA parameters. Version: 2015-09-03. http://mint.sbg.ac.at/desc_CSimplex.html].
\(S(2,1)\) reduces to the repetition code.
Hamming and simplex codes are dual to each other.
Binary simplex codes are \([2^m-1,m,2^{m-1}]\) shortened Hadamard codes.
Binary simplex codes map to simplex spherical codes under the antipodal mapping [Forney, G. D. (2003). 6.451 Principles of Digital Communication II, Spring 2003.; Sec. 6.5.2][T. Ericson, and V. Zinoviev, eds. Codes on Euclidean spheres. Elsevier, 2001.; pg. 18]. In other words, simplex (simplex spherical) codes form simplices in Hamming (Euclidean) space.
Binary simplex codes can be constructed from the generator matrix of RM\((1,k)\) by removing first the all-ones row, and then the all-zero column. Punctured RM codes and simplex codes are interconvertible via expurgation and augmentation ([F. J. MacWilliams and N. J. A. Sloane. The theory of error correcting codes. Elsevier, 1977.], pg. 31).

Linear \(q\)-ary codes with distances \(\frac{1}{2}n-\sqrt{t n}\) for some \(t\) are called almost-orthogonal and are locally testable with query complexity of order \(O(t)\) [T. Kaufman and S. Litsyn, “Almost Orthogonal Linear Codes are Locally Testable”, 46th Annual IEEE Symposium on Foundations of Computer Science (FOCS’05) DOI]. This was later improved to codes with distance \(\frac{1}{2}n-O(n^{1-\gamma})\) for any positive \(\gamma\) [T. Kaufman and M. Sudan, “Sparse Random Linear Codes are Locally Decodable and Testable”, 48th Annual IEEE Symposium on Foundations of Computer Science (FOCS’07) (2007) DOI], provided that the number of codewords is polynomial in \(n\).
The dual of a \(q\)-ary LDPC code has a sparse generator matrix and is called a \(q\)-ary LDGM code.

Starting with the \([6,3,3]\) shortened Hamming code and applying the \((u|u+v)\) construction recursively using the repetition code yields a family of \([2^m,m+1,2^{m-1}]\) codes for \(m\geq1\) that saturate the Griesmer bound [J. Bierbrauer, Introduction to Coding Theory (Chapman and Hall/CRC, 2016) DOI; pg. 90].
The \((u|u+v)\) construction can be used to obtain nonlinear binary quadratic residue codes [N. Sloane and D. Whitehead, “New family of single-error correcting codes”, IEEE Transactions on Information Theory 16, 717 (1970) DOI].

Random low-rate unbiased linear codes are LTCs [S. Kopparty and S. Saraf, “Local list-decoding and testing of random linear codes from high error”, Proceedings of the forty-second ACM symposium on Theory of computing (2010) DOI].

Two-weight codes are \(m\)-divisible, where \(m\) is the greatest common factor of their two possible weights.
There are several correpondences between projective and two-weight codes [A. E. Brouwer and M. van Eupen, Designs, Codes and Cryptography 11, 261 (1997) DOI][R. Calderbank and W. M. Kantor, “The Geometry of Two-Weight Codes”, Bulletin of the London Mathematical Society 18, 97 (1986) DOI][D. Jungnickel and V. D. Tonchev, “The classification of antipodal two-weight linear codes”, Finite Fields and Their Applications 50, 372 (2018) DOI].
Codewords of two-weight codes have one of two possible Hamming weights, while those of weight-two codes have Hamming weight two.

The octacode is the smallest Kerdock code, when the latter is thought of as a code over \(\mathbb{Z}_4\).
The octacode is the smallest Preparata code, when the latter is thought of as a code over \(\mathbb{Z}_4\).
The octacode can be obtained by Hensel-lifting the \([7,4,3]\) Hamming code to \(\mathbb{Z}_4\) [A. R. Hammons et al., “The Z/sub 4/-linearity of Kerdock, Preparata, Goethals, and related codes”, IEEE Transactions on Information Theory 40, 301 (1994) DOI].
The octacode reduces modulo-two to the \([8,4,4]\) extended Hamming code [Self-Dual Codes and Invariant Theory (Springer-Verlag, 2006) DOI].

Codewords of the Best code can be obtained by applying the Gray map to the pentacode [J. H. Conway and N. J. A. Sloane, “Quaternary constructions for the binary single-error-correcting codes of Julin, Best and others”, Designs, Codes and Cryptography 4, 31 (1994) DOI; Sec. 2].

The automorphism group of BW lattices is a subgroup of index 2 of a real Clifford group [V. M. Sidelnikov, On a finite group of matrices and codes on the Euclidean sphere (in Russian), Probl. Peredach. Inform. 33 (1997), 35–54 (1997); English translation in Problems Inform. Transmission 33 (1997), 29–44][V. M. Sidelnikov, “On a finite group of matrices generating orbit codes on Euclidean sphere”, Proceedings of IEEE International Symposium on Information Theory DOI] (see [G. Nebe, E. M. Rains, and N. J. A. Sloane, “The invariants of the Clifford groups”, (2000) arXiv:math/0001038] for an explanation).

Any length-\(n\) binary linear code can be used to define a diagonal subgroup of \(n\)-dimensional rotation matrices with \(\pm 1\) on the diagonals via the antipodal mapping \(0\to+1\) and \(1\to-1\). The orbit of this subgroup yields the corresponding Slepian group-orbit code; see [T. Ericson, and V. Zinoviev, eds. Codes on Euclidean spheres. Elsevier, 2001.; Thm. 8.5.2].
Any length-\(n\) binary linear code can be used to define a diagonal subgroup of \(n\)-dimensional rotation matrices with \(\pm 1\) on the diagonals via the antipodal mapping \(0\to+1\) and \(1\to-1\). The orbit of this subgroup yields the corresponding Slepian group-orbit code; see [T. Ericson, and V. Zinoviev, eds. Codes on Euclidean spheres. Elsevier, 2001.; Thm. 8.5.2].
Any finite-group code can be mapped to a Slepian group-orbit code by representing the group using orthogonal matrices [H.-A. Loeliger, “Signal sets matched to groups”, IEEE Transactions on Information Theory 37, 1675 (1991) DOI].
\(D_4\) \(2m\)-shell codes can form spherical designs [M. Hirao, H. Nozaki, and K. Tasaka, “Spherical designs and modular forms of the \(D_4\) lattice”, (2023) arXiv:2303.09000].

Lattice-shell codes consists of lattice points that have been normalized.
Lattice-shell codewords are often permutations of a particular set of reference vectors, meaning that a cyclic permutation of a codeword yields another codeword.
Nonempty \(2m\)-shell codes of extremal even unimodular lattices in \(n\) dimensions form spherical \(t\)-designs with \(t=11\) (\(t=7\), \(t=3\)) if \(n \equiv 0\) (\(n \equiv 8\), \(n\equiv 16\)) modulo 24 [B. B. Venkov. Even unimodular extremal lattices, algebraic geometry and its applications. Trudy Mat. Inst. Steklov., 165:43–48, 1984.][B. Venkov. Réseaux et designs sphériques. In Réseaux euclidiens, designs sphériques et formes modulaires, volume 37 of Monogr. Enseign. Math., pages 10–86. Enseignement Math., Geneva, 2001.].

Smallest-shell \((24,196560,1)\) code is a spherical sharp configuration [Andreev, N. N. Location of points on a sphere with minimal energy. (Russian) Tr. Mat. Inst. Steklova 219 (1997), Teor. Priblizh. Garmon. Anal., 27–31; translation in Proc. Steklov Inst. Math. 1997, no. 4(219), 20–24][H. Cohn and A. Kumar, “Universally optimal distribution of points on spheres”, Journal of the American Mathematical Society 20, 99 (2006) arXiv:math/0607446 DOI].
Smallest-shell \((24,196560,1)\) code is a tight and unique spherical 11-design [J. H. Conway and N. J. A. Sloane, Sphere Packings, Lattices and Groups (Springer New York, 1999) DOI; Ch. 3].

BPSK for real \(\alpha\) is the simplest non-trivial PAM encoding.
Concatenating binary linear codes with BPSK yields a standard way of digitizing the analog AGWN channel [A. Lapidoth, A Foundation in Digital Communication (Cambridge University Press, 2017) DOI; Ch. 29].
BPSK (two-component cat) codes are used to transmit classical (quantum) information using (superpositions of) antipodal coherent states over classical (quantum) channels.
BPSK concatenated with quantum-classical polar codes achieves the Holevo capacity for the pure-loss channel [S. Guha and M. M. Wilde, “Polar coding to achieve the Holevo capacity of a pure-loss optical channel”, 2012 IEEE International Symposium on Information Theory Proceedings (2012) arXiv:1202.0533 DOI].

1D Gray codes are often concatenated with PSKs so that the Hamming distance between the bitstrings encoded into the points is a discretized version of the Euclidean distance between the points.
PSK (cat) codes are used to transmit classical (quantum) information using (superpositions of) single-mode coherent states distributed on a circle over classical (quantum) channels.

The 24-cell code is not universally optimal [H. Cohn et al., “TheD\({}_{\text{4}}\)Root System Is Not Universally Optimal”, Experimental Mathematics 16, 313 (2007) arXiv:math/0607447 DOI], but comes quite close [P. Boyvalenkov, D. Danev, "Linear programming bounds." Concise Encyclopedia of Coding Theory (Chapman and Hall/CRC, 2021) DOI; Ex. 12.4.29].
Cubeoctahedron codewords form the minimal shell of the \(D_3\) face-centered cubic (fcc) lattice.
The disphenoidal 288-cell code is a group-orbit code with the group being the real Clifford group in \(4\) dimensions.

The 27 Hessian polyhedron codewords are intimately related to the \(E_6\) Lie group [L. Manivel, “Configurations of lines and models of Lie algebras”, (2005) arXiv:math/0507118].
Double Hessian polyhedron codewords form the minimal lattice-shell code of the \(E_6^{\perp}\) lattice.

The (rectified) Hessian polyhedron is an analogue of a (octahedron) tetrahedron in 3D complex space, while the double Hessian polyhedron is the analogue of a cube [H. S. M. Coxeter. Regular Complex Polytopes. Cambridge University Press, 1991.; pg. 127]. The rectified and double Hessian polyhedra are dual to each other, just like the octahedron and cube. Moreover, the double Hessian consists of two Hessians, just like the cube can be constructed with two tetrahedra.
The parity bits of the extended Golay code can be visualized to lie on the vertices of the icosahedron; see post by J. Baez for more details.

An RM\((1,m)\) code maps to a \((2^m,2^{m+1})\) biorthogonal signal set under the antipodal mapping [G. D. Forney and G. Ungerboeck, “Modulation and coding for linear Gaussian channels”, IEEE Transactions on Information Theory 44, 2384 (1998) DOI][Forney, G. D. (2003). 6.451 Principles of Digital Communication II, Spring 2003.; Sec. 6.4]. This set is equivalent to the biorthogonal code since all such codes are unique up to equivalence [T. Ericson, and V. Zinoviev, eds. Codes on Euclidean spheres. Elsevier, 2001.; pg. 19].
Vertices of a 24-cell can be split up into vertices of three 16-cells, which are biorthogonal spherical codes for \(n=4\) [H. S. M. Coxeter. Regular polytopes. Courier Corporation, 1973.].
Biorthogonal codewords form the minimal shell of the \(\mathbb{Z}^n\) hypercubic lattice.

A binary simplex code (also known as a shortened Hadamard code) to a \((2^m,2^m+1)\) simplex signal set under the antipodal mapping [Forney, G. D. (2003). 6.451 Principles of Digital Communication II, Spring 2003.; Sec. 6.5.2]. This set is equivalent to the simplex code since all such codes are unique up to equivalence [T. Ericson, and V. Zinoviev, eds. Codes on Euclidean spheres. Elsevier, 2001.; pg. 18]. Simplex (simplex spherical) codes form simplices in Hamming (Euclidean) space.
Vertices of a dodecahedron can be split up into vertices of five tetrahedra, which are simplex spherical codes for \(n=3\) [H. S. M. Coxeter. Regular polytopes. Courier Corporation, 1973.].

The \(q(S+1)\)-component cat coherent-state constellation forms the vertices of a \(q(S+1)\)-gon.
The PSK coherent-state constellation forms the vertices of a \(q\)-gon.

A binary antipodal code can be thought of as a concatenation of a binary outer code with a BPSK inner code.
Binary antipodal codes are spherical codes obtained from binary codes.

Binary balanced spherical codes are obtained from constant-weight binary codes.
A binary balanced spherical code can be thought of as a concatenation of a constant-weight binary outer code with a shifted and scaled BPSK-like inner code.

Kerdock spherical codes can be obtained from Kerdock codes using the binary antipodal mapping [T. Ericson, and V. Zinoviev, eds. Codes on Euclidean spheres. Elsevier, 2001.; pg. 157].
Kerdock spherical codes are almost universally optimal [P. G. Boyvalenkov et al., “Universal upper and lower bounds on energy of spherical designs”, (2015) arXiv:1509.07837].

Polyphase codes are spherical codes that can be obtained from \(q\)-ary codes.
Polyphase codes are spherical codes that can be obtained from \(q\)-ary codes over rings \(\mathbb{Z}_q\).
Simplex spherical codes for dimension \(n=(p-1)/2\) with \(p\) an odd prime admit a polyphase realization [T. Ericson, and V. Zinoviev, eds. Codes on Euclidean spheres. Elsevier, 2001.; Sec. 7.7].
Biorthogonal spherical codes for dimension \(n=p\) with \(p\) an odd prime admit a polyphase realization [T. Ericson, and V. Zinoviev, eds. Codes on Euclidean spheres. Elsevier, 2001.; Sec. 7.7].
CSG isotropic subspace codes are constructed from incidence matrices of \(PG_5(q)\) [T. Ericson, and V. Zinoviev, eds. Codes on Euclidean spheres. Elsevier, 2001.; Ex. 9.4.5].

The Smith spherical code is conjectured to be a global minimum of completely monotonic potential functions [B. Ballinger et al., “Experimental Study of Energy-Minimizing Point Configurations on Spheres”, Experimental Mathematics 18, 257 (2009) arXiv:math/0611451 DOI].

Slepian group-orbit codes can form spherical designs [E. BANNAI, “Spherical t-designs which are orbits of finite groups”, Journal of the Mathematical Society of Japan 36, (1984) DOI][P. de la Harpe and C. Pache, “Spherical designs and finite group representations (some results of E. Bannai)”, European Journal of Combinatorics 25, 213 (2004) DOI]. Polynomial invariants of a discrete subgroup \(G\) of the orthogonal group can be used to determine the design strength of orbits of \(G\) [S. L. Sobolev, “Cubature Formulas on the Sphere Invariant under Finite Groups of Rotations”, Selected Works of S.L. Sobolev 461 DOI]. Let \(t+1\) be the degree of the lowest-degree \(G\)-invariant polynomial that is not a polynomial in the norm \(\left\Vert x\right\Vert^2\). Then, any orbit under \(G\) forms a Slepian group-orbit code that is also a spherical \(t\)-design.
Bosonic c-q codes are bosonic codes designed to transmit classical information.

Coherent-state c-q codes encode classical alphabets into constellations of coherent states, while coherent-state constellation codes encode quantum information into superpositions of coherent states.
Coherent-state c-q codes are modulation schemes to transmission of classical information over quantum analog channels.

The Niset-Andersen-Cerf code encodes two coherent states at a time with arbitrary complex values, making it analogous to a two-point QAM code. The code does not encode any quantum information since superpositions of the coherent states are not stored. However, analysis of the code is done via a quantum treatment.

BPSK (BPSK c-q) codes are used to transmit classical information using antipodal coherent states over classical (quantum) channels.
BPSK c-q (two-component cat) codes are used to transmit classical (quantum) information using (superpositions of) antipodal coherent states over quantum channels.

The Hadamard BPSK c-q code can be thought of as a concatenation of the Hadamard binary linear code with BPSK for the purposes of transmission of classical information over quantum channels.
The Hadamard BPSK c-q code can be thought of as a concatenation of the Hadamard binary linear code with BPSK for the purposes of transmission of classical information over quantum channels.

PSK (PSK c-q) codes are used to transmit classical information using single-mode coherent states distributed on a circle over classical (quantum) channels.
PSK c-q (cat) codes are used to transmit classical (quantum) information using (superpositions of) single-mode coherent states distributed on a circle over quantum channels.
OOK c-q codewords are related to BPSK c-q codewords by a displacement in phase space.
Qubit c-q codes are qubit codes designed to transmit classical information.
Some groupiod toric code models admit fracton-like features such as extensive ground-state degeneracy and excitations with restricted mobility.

The Walker-Wang model is a generalization of the 3D version of the Levin-Wen model [M. A. Levin and X.-G. Wen, “String-net condensation: A physical mechanism for topological phases”, Physical Review B 71, (2005) arXiv:cond-mat/0404617 DOI; Sec. 5], which realizes gauge theories coupled with bosons and fermions.

EA QECCs utilize additional ancillary subsystems in a pre-shared entangled state, but reduce to QECCs when said subsystems are interpreted as noiseless physical subsystems.
Pure modular-qudit codes can be used to make EA-QECCs with the same distance and dimension; see Thm. 10 of Ref. [M. Grassl, F. Huber, and A. Winter, “Entropic Proofs of Singleton Bounds for Quantum Error-Correcting Codes”, IEEE Transactions on Information Theory 68, 3942 (2022) arXiv:2010.07902 DOI].
Any linear binary code can be used to construct an EAQECC.
Any linear \(q\)-ary code can be used to construct an EAQECC.

The four group-qudit code can be extended to the \([[2m,2m-2,2]]_{G}\) group-qudit code [P. Faist et al., “Continuous Symmetries and Approximate Quantum Error Correction”, Physical Review X 10, (2020) arXiv:1902.07714 DOI; Sec. VIII]. The latter reduces to the \([[2m,2m-2,2]]\) error-detecting code for \(G=\mathbb{Z}_2\).

Group GKP codes are stabilized by \(X\)-type Pauli matrices representing \(H\) and all \(Z\)-type operators that are constant on \(K\). However, the \(Z\)-type operators are not unitary for non-Abelian groups.
The group-GKP construction encompasses all bosonic CSS codes. A single-mode qubit GKP code corresponds to the \(2\mathbb{Z}\subset\mathbb{Z}\subset\mathbb{R}\) group construction, and multimode GKP codes can be similarly described. An \([[n,k,d]]_{\mathbb{R}}\) analog stabilizer code corresponds to the \(\mathbb{R}^{ k_1} \subseteq \mathbb{R}^{ k_2} \subset \mathbb{R}^{n}\) group construction, where \(k=k_2/k_1\). GKP stabilizer codes for \(n\) modes correspond to subgroups \(\mathbb{Z}^m\) for \(m<n\).
Cluster states can be generalized to finite groups [C. G. Brell, “Generalized cluster states based on finite groups”, New Journal of Physics 17, 023029 (2015) arXiv:1408.6237 DOI].
Category quantum codes whose physical spaces are constructed using a finite group as the category are group codes.

Current-mirror code phase gates utilize ancillary osillators in square-lattice GKP states [A. Kitaev, “Protected qubit based on a superconducting current mirror”, (2006) arXiv:cond-mat/0609441][P. Brooks, A. Kitaev, and J. Preskill, “Protected gates for superconducting qubits”, Physical Review A 87, (2013) arXiv:1302.4122 DOI].

Zero-pi code phase gates utilize ancillary osillators in square-lattice GKP states [A. Kitaev, “Protected qubit based on a superconducting current mirror”, (2006) arXiv:cond-mat/0609441][P. Brooks, A. Kitaev, and J. Preskill, “Protected gates for superconducting qubits”, Physical Review A 87, (2013) arXiv:1302.4122 DOI].
The five-rotor code is a rotor analogue of the five-qudit code.

GKP (rotor GKP) codes protect against shifts in linear (angular) degrees of freedom.
The rotor GKP code can be thought of as a concatenation of a homological rotor code and a modular-qudit GKP code [Y. Xu, Y. Wang, and V. V. Albert, “Clifford operations and homological codes for rotors and oscillators”, (2023) arXiv:2311.07679; Fig. 3].
A rotor stabilizer code admitting a set of generators such that each generator consists of either angular position or angular momentum operators is a CSS code.

Generalized color-code Hamiltonians should be expressable in terms of \(X\)- and \(Z\)-type operators of group-GKP codes; see [V. V. Albert et al., “Spin chains, defects, and quantum wires for the quantum-double edge”, (2021) arXiv:2111.12096; Sec. 3.3].
Generalized color code for group \(G\) on the 4.8.8 lattice is equivalent to a \(G\) quantum double model and another \(G/[G,G]\) quantum double model defined using the Abelianization of \(G\).

A subsystem code reduces to an ordinary error-correcting code when the gauge subsystem is trivial, \(\mathsf{B} = \mathbb{C}\). Conversely, any QECC with a tensor-product logical subspace can be turned into a subsystem code by treating a logical tensor factor as a gauge subsystem.
The \(2T\)-qutrit code reduces to the two-mode "0-2-4" binomial code as \(\alpha\to 0\).

In the limit as \(N,S \to \infty\), phase measurement in the cat code has vanishing variance, just like in a number-phase code [A. L. Grimsmo, J. Combes, and B. Q. Baragiola, “Quantum Computing with Rotation-Symmetric Bosonic Codes”, Physical Review X 10, (2020) arXiv:1901.08071 DOI].

Clifford group-orbit QSCs are quantum analogues of real Clifford subgroup-orbit codes.
Logical constellations of the Clifford subgroup-orbit code for \(r=2\) form vertices of Witting polytopes.
Logical constellations of the Clifford subgroup-orbit code for \(r=1\) form vertices of 24-cells when mapped into the real sphere, while code constellations form vertices of a disphenoidal 288-cell.
Logical constellations of the Clifford subgroup-orbit code for \(r=1\) form vertices of 24-cells when mapped into the real sphere, while code constellations form vertices of a disphenoidal 288-cell.

Coherent-state constellation codes consisting of points from a Gaussian quadrature rule can be concatenated with quantum polar codes to achieve the Gaussian coherent information of the thermal noise channel [F. Lacerda, J. M. Renes, and V. B. Scholz, “Coherent-state constellations and polar codes for thermal Gaussian channels”, Physical Review A 95, (2017) arXiv:1603.05970 DOI][F. Lacerda, J. M. Renes, and V. B. Scholz, “Coherent state constellations for Bosonic Gaussian channels”, 2016 IEEE International Symposium on Information Theory (ISIT) (2016) DOI].
Coherent-state constellation codes consisting of points from a Gaussian quadrature rule can be concatenated with quantum polar codes to achieve the Gaussian coherent information of the thermal noise channel [F. Lacerda, J. M. Renes, and V. B. Scholz, “Coherent-state constellations and polar codes for thermal Gaussian channels”, Physical Review A 95, (2017) arXiv:1603.05970 DOI][F. Lacerda, J. M. Renes, and V. B. Scholz, “Coherent state constellations for Bosonic Gaussian channels”, 2016 IEEE International Symposium on Information Theory (ISIT) (2016) DOI].
Coherent-state constellation codes are quantum versions of modulation schemes in that their codewords are superpositions of points in a constellation. Additionally, analog codes that achieve AGWN capacity [Y. Wu and S. Verdu, “The impact of constellation cardinality on Gaussian channel capacity”, 2010 48th Annual Allerton Conference on Communication, Control, and Computing (Allerton) (2010) DOI] can be used to develop capacity-achieving concatenations of coherent-state constellation codes with quantum polar codes [F. Lacerda, J. M. Renes, and V. B. Scholz, “Coherent-state constellations and polar codes for thermal Gaussian channels”, Physical Review A 95, (2017) arXiv:1603.05970 DOI][F. Lacerda, J. M. Renes, and V. B. Scholz, “Coherent state constellations for Bosonic Gaussian channels”, 2016 IEEE International Symposium on Information Theory (ISIT) (2016) DOI].
The Hessian QSC is the quantum generalization of the classical Hessian polyhedron code.

QSCs are quantum analogues of spherical and constant-energy codes because they store information in quantum superpositions of points on a sphere in quantum phase space.
QSCs are quantum analogues of spherical and constant-energy codes because they store information in quantum superpositions of points on a sphere in quantum phase space.
Single-spin codes whose codewords are expressed in terms of discrete sets of spin-coherent states may also be interpreted as QSCs.
Pair-cat codes are QSCs embedded into the configuration space of pair-coherent states.
CSS codes concatenated with two-component cat codes form QSCs which have a weight-based notion of distance.
CSS codes concatenated with two-component cat codes form QSCs which have a weight-based notion of distance.
CSS codes concatenated with two-component cat codes form QSCs which have a weight-based notion of distance.
RG cat codes approximately protect against displacements that represent ultraviolet coherent operators.

The two-legged cat code forms the ground-state subspace of a Kerr Hamiltonian [S. Puri, S. Boutin, and A. Blais, “Engineering the quantum states of light in a Kerr-nonlinear resonator by two-photon driving”, npj Quantum Information 3, (2017) arXiv:1605.09408 DOI].
Two-legged cat and quantum repetition codes can be thought of as classical codes because they protect against only one type of noise. Two-legged cat codes (quantum repetition) codes suppress cavity dephasing (bit-flip) noise exponentially with \(|\alpha|^2\) (\(n\)). The stability offered by cat codes has been linked to several favorable properties of phases of matter associated with the repetition-code Hamiltonian [F. Minganti et al., “Spectral theory of Liouvillians for dissipative phase transitions”, Physical Review A 98, (2018) arXiv:1804.11293 DOI][S. Lieu et al., “Symmetry Breaking and Error Correction in Open Quantum Systems”, Physical Review Letters 125, (2020) arXiv:2008.02816 DOI].
Two-component cat codes can be thought of as coherent-state c-q codes because they protect against only one type of noise and thus only reliably store classical information.
A concatenation of the repetition code with the two-component cat code is a candidate for a memory that may be self-correcting, but only in the limit of infinite energy per mode [S. Lieu, Y.-J. Liu, and A. V. Gorshkov, “Candidate for a passively protected quantum memory in two dimensions”, (2023) arXiv:2205.09767].
EA bosonic codes utilize additional ancillary modes in a pre-shared entangled state, but reduce to ordinary bosonic codes when said modes are interpreted as noiseless physical modes.
The one-hot quantum code is the quantum version of the one-hot code.

Two-mode binomial codes [M. Y. Niu, I. L. Chuang, and J. H. Shapiro, “Hardware-efficient bosonic quantum error-correcting codes based on symmetry operators”, Physical Review A 97, (2018) arXiv:1709.05302 DOI; Eqs. (90-91)] are closely related to three-mode \(\chi^2\) binomial codes [M. Y. Niu, I. L. Chuang, and J. H. Shapiro, “Hardware-efficient bosonic quantum error-correcting codes based on symmetry operators”, Physical Review A 97, (2018) arXiv:1709.05302 DOI; Eqs. (61-62)].

VSLQ decoder utilizes two ancillary oscillators.
Parts of the VSLQ codewords resemble the two-qubit phase-flip repetition code, though the code cannot correct phase errors. Unlike the phase-flip code, the VSLQ code can correct for single photon loss because it uses the second excited state in the construction, which remains distinct from the vacuum even after photon loss.

Fock-state code distance is a natural extension of Hamming distance between binary strings.
Fock-state code whose codewords are finite superpositions of Fock states with maximum occupation \(N\) can be mapped into a qubit code with \(n\geq\log_2 N\) by performing a binary expansion of the Fock-state labels \(n\) and treating each binary digit as an index for a qubit state. Pauli operators for the constituent qubits can be expressed in terms of bosonic raising and lowering operators [Victor V. Albert, private communication, 2016]. However, noise models for the two code families induce different notions of locality and thus qualitatively different physical interpretations [S. M. Girvin, “Introduction to quantum error correction and fault tolerance”, SciPost Physics Lecture Notes (2023) arXiv:2111.08894 DOI].

Homological number-phase codes are mappings of homological rotor codes into harmonic oscillators, so they are based on the rotor version of the qubit CSS-to-homology correspondence.
Homological number-phase codes are mappings of homological rotor codes into harmonic oscillators. Codewords of both codes are right eigenstates of powers of Susskind–Glogower phase operators and bosonic rotation operators, with the semigroup of the former (latter) continuous (discrete).
Homological number-phase codewords span the joint right eigenspace of powers of Susskind–Glogower phase operators and bosonic rotation operators.
Homological number-phase codes and number-phase codes are both manifestations of certain rotor codes, namely, the homological rotor codes and rotor GKP codes, respectively.
Matrix-model codes are similar to self-correcting memories in the sense that memory time becomes infinite in the thermodynamic limit, but with corrections being polynomial in \(N\).

Numerically optimizing GKP code lattices yields codes for three, seven, and nine modes with larger distances and fidelities than known GKP codes [M. Lin, C. Chamberland, and K. Noh, “Closest Lattice Point Decoding for Multimode Gottesman-Kitaev-Preskill Codes”, PRX Quantum 4, (2023) arXiv:2303.04702 DOI].

Cat (pair-cat) codewords are superpositions of coherent (pair-coherent) states. Many cat-code protocols have analogues for the two-mode pair-cat codes.
Two-legged pair-cat codewords form ground-state subspace of a multimode Kerr Hamiltonian.

For a fixed \(S\), binomial codes with \(N \to \infty\) coincide with cat codes as \(\alpha \to \infty\) [M. H. Michael et al., “New Class of Quantum Error-Correcting Codes for a Bosonic Mode”, Physical Review X 6, (2016) arXiv:1602.00008 DOI].
In the limit as \(N,S \to \infty\), phase measurement in the binomial code has vanishing variance, just like in a number-phase code [A. L. Grimsmo, J. Combes, and B. Q. Baragiola, “Quantum Computing with Rotation-Symmetric Bosonic Codes”, Physical Review X 10, (2020) arXiv:1901.08071 DOI].

Random bosonic rotation codes can outperform cat and binomial codes when loss rate is large relative to dephasing rate [S. Totey et al., “The performance of random bosonic rotation codes”, (2023) arXiv:2311.16089].

Chebyshev codes resemble binomial codes, and a class of binomial codes have similar error-correcting properties [D. Layden et al., “Ancilla-Free Quantum Error Correction Codes for Quantum Metrology”, Physical Review Letters 122, (2019) arXiv:1811.01450 DOI].

Number-phase codes are a manifestation of planar-rotor GKP codes in an oscillator. Both codes protect against small shifts in angular degrees of freedom.
Number-phase codewords span the joint right eigenspace of the \(N\)th power of the Susskind–Glogower phase operator and the bosonic rotation operator [A. L. Grimsmo, J. Combes, and B. Q. Baragiola, “Quantum Computing with Rotation-Symmetric Bosonic Codes”, Physical Review X 10, (2020) arXiv:1901.08071 DOI]. These operators no longer form a group since the phase operator is not unitary.
Square-lattice GKP codes utilize translational symmetry in phase space, while number-phase codes utilize rotational symmetry. The two are related via a mapping [A. D. C. Tosta, T. O. Maciel, and L. Aolita, “Grand Unification of continuous-variable codes”, (2022) arXiv:2206.01751].
Hybrid code with \(n_1=0\).

Approximate QEC techniques of finding the entanglement fidelity can be adapted to bosonic codes with a finite-dimensional codespace [V. V. Albert et al., “Performance and structure of single-mode bosonic codes”, Physical Review A 97, (2018) arXiv:1708.05010 DOI].

Analog stabilizer codes protect logical modes against arbitrarily large displacements on a few modes, while GKP-stabilizer codes protect a finite-dimensional logical space against sufficiently small displacements in any number of modes. Encoding in analog-stabilizer (GKP-stabilizer) codes can be done by a Gaussian operation acting on a tensor product of an arbitrary state in the first mode and position states (GKP states) on the remaining modes. Protection of logical modes against small displacements cannot be done using only Gaussian resources [C. Vuillot et al., “Quantum error correction with the toric Gottesman-Kitaev-Preskill code”, Physical Review A 99, (2019) arXiv:1810.00047 DOI][J. Eisert, S. Scheel, and M. B. Plenio, “Distilling Gaussian States with Gaussian Operations is Impossible”, Physical Review Letters 89, (2002) arXiv:quant-ph/0204052 DOI][J. Niset, J. Fiurášek, and N. J. Cerf, “No-Go Theorem for Gaussian Quantum Error Correction”, Physical Review Letters 102, (2009) arXiv:0811.3128 DOI], so GKP-stabilizer codes can be thought of as analog stabilizer encodings utilizing non-Gaussian GKP resource states.
Prime-qudit stabilizer codes can be converted into analog stabilizer codes whose distance is at least as large as that of the original code [L. G. Gunderman, “Stabilizer Codes with Exotic Local-dimensions”, (2023) arXiv:2303.17000].

The analog surface code realizes a straightforward extension of the modular-qudit surface code to infinite local dimension, \(q\to\infty\). There are two types of anyons, \(e\) and \(m\), with each type being valued in \(U(1)\) as opposed to \(\mathbb{Z}_q\) for the qudit surface code.
The analog surface code realizes a straightforward extension of the modular-qudit surface code to infinite local dimension, \(q\to\infty\). There are two types of anyons, \(e\) and \(m\), with each type being valued in \(U(1)\) as opposed to \(\mathbb{Z}_q\) for the qudit surface code.
The Braunstein five-mode code is a bosonic analogue of the five-qudit code.

EA analog stabilizer codes utilize additional ancillary modes in a pre-shared entangled state, but reduce to ordinary analog stabilizer codes when said modes are interpreted as noiseless physical modes.

Homological CV codes utilize chain complexes in code construction, but the complexes have trivial homology.
The Niset-Andersen-Cerf code can be viewed as a scheme to replicate quantum information in multiple regions [P. Hayden et al., “Spacetime replication of continuous variable quantum information”, New Journal of Physics 18, 083043 (2016) arXiv:1601.02544 DOI].
Homological CV codes have been considered in the context of spacetime replication of quantum data [P. Hayden and A. May, “Summoning information in spacetime, or where and when can a qubit be?”, Journal of Physics A: Mathematical and Theoretical 49, 175304 (2016) arXiv:1210.0913 DOI][P. Hayden et al., “Spacetime replication of continuous variable quantum information”, New Journal of Physics 18, 083043 (2016) arXiv:1601.02544 DOI], while STCs are designed to replicate classical data.
The Lloyd-Slotine nine-mode code is a bosonic analogue of Shor's code.

The \(D_4\) hyper-diamond GKP code can be seen as a concatenation of a rotated square-lattice GKP code with a repetition code [B. Royer, S. Singh, and S. M. Girvin, “Encoding Qubits in Multimode Grid States”, PRX Quantum 3, (2022) arXiv:2201.12337 DOI]. This is related to the fact that the four-bit repetition code yields the \(D_4\) hyper-diamond lattice code via the mod-two lattice construction.
The \(D_4\) hyper-diamond GKP code can be seen as a concatenation of a rotated square-lattice GKP code with a repetition code [B. Royer, S. Singh, and S. M. Girvin, “Encoding Qubits in Multimode Grid States”, PRX Quantum 3, (2022) arXiv:2201.12337 DOI]. This is related to the fact that the four-bit repetition code yields the \(D_4\) hyper-diamond lattice code via the mod-two lattice construction.

GKP-stabilizer oscillator-into-oscillator codes concantenated with GKP qubit-into-mode codes can outperform the more conventional concatenations of GKP codes with qubit stabilizer codes [Y. Xu et al., “Qubit-Oscillator Concatenated Codes: Decoding Formalism and Code Comparison”, PRX Quantum 4, (2023) arXiv:2209.04573 DOI].
\(D_4\) hyper-diamond GKP codes may be optimal for GKP stabilizer codes utilizing two ancilla modes [J. Wu, A. J. Brady, and Q. Zhuang, “Optimal encoding of oscillators into more oscillators”, Quantum 7, 1082 (2023) arXiv:2212.11970 DOI].
Hexagonal GKP codes may be optimal for GKP stabilizer codes utilizing one ancilla mode [J. Wu, A. J. Brady, and Q. Zhuang, “Optimal encoding of oscillators into more oscillators”, Quantum 7, 1082 (2023) arXiv:2212.11970 DOI].

Square-lattice GKP codes approximately protect against photon loss [B. M. Terhal and D. Weigand, “Encoding a qubit into a cavity mode in circuit QED using phase estimation”, Physical Review A 93, (2016) arXiv:1506.05033 DOI][V. V. Albert et al., “Performance and structure of single-mode bosonic codes”, Physical Review A 97, (2018) arXiv:1708.05010 DOI][K. Noh, V. V. Albert, and L. Jiang, “Quantum Capacity Bounds of Gaussian Thermal Loss Channels and Achievable Rates With Gottesman-Kitaev-Preskill Codes”, IEEE Transactions on Information Theory 65, 2563 (2019) arXiv:1801.07271 DOI].
Because square-lattice GKP error states are parameterized by two modular (i.e., periodic) variables of position and momentum, measuring one of the GKP stabilizers constrains the oscillator Hilbert space into that of a rotor.
GKP codewords, when written in terms of coherent states, form a square lattice in phase space.

Approximate error-correction offered by GKP codes yields achievable rates that are a constant away from the capacity of Guassian loss channels [J. Harrington and J. Preskill, “Achievable rates for the Gaussian quantum channel”, Physical Review A 64, (2001) arXiv:quant-ph/0105058 DOI][K. Sharma et al., “Bounding the energy-constrained quantum and private capacities of phase-insensitive bosonic Gaussian channels”, New Journal of Physics 20, 063025 (2018) arXiv:1708.07257 DOI][M. Rosati, A. Mari, and V. Giovannetti, “Narrow bounds for the quantum capacity of thermal attenuators”, Nature Communications 9, (2018) arXiv:1801.04731 DOI][K. Noh, V. V. Albert, and L. Jiang, “Quantum Capacity Bounds of Gaussian Thermal Loss Channels and Achievable Rates With Gottesman-Kitaev-Preskill Codes”, IEEE Transactions on Information Theory 65, 2563 (2019) arXiv:1801.07271 DOI].
Several NTRU lattices come from randomized constructions, yielding asymptotically good GKP code families.

Quantum lattice codes can be thought of as quantum lattice codes because they store information in quantum superpositions of points on a lattice in quantum phase space.
Quantum lattice codes defined on rectangular lattices are CSS codes. There is no known relation to chain complexes for such codes. More general lattices, obtained from rectangular lattices by Gaussian transformations, yield non-CSS codes.
An oscillator stabilizer code admitting a set of generators such that each generator consists of either position or momentum operators is a CSS code.

Normalizable constructions of infinite-dimensional \(G\)-covariant codes for continuous \(G\) are approximately error-correcting.
Quantum RM codes are approximately covariant and nearly saturate certain covariance-performance bounds [Z.-W. Liu and S. Zhou, “Quantum error correction meets continuous symmetries: fundamental trade-offs and case studies”, (2023) arXiv:2111.06360].
ETH codes consisting of Dicke states are approximately \(U(1)\)-covariant and nearly saturate certain covariance-performance bounds [P. Faist et al., “Continuous Symmetries and Approximate Quantum Error Correction”, Physical Review X 10, (2020) arXiv:1902.07714 DOI][Z.-W. Liu and S. Zhou, “Quantum error correction meets continuous symmetries: fundamental trade-offs and case studies”, (2023) arXiv:2111.06360].
Random \(U(d)\)-covariant almost exactly error-correcting codes exist [P. Faist et al., “Continuous Symmetries and Approximate Quantum Error Correction”, Physical Review X 10, (2020) arXiv:1902.07714 DOI][L. Kong and Z.-W. Liu, “Near-Optimal Covariant Quantum Error-Correcting Codes from Random Unitaries with Symmetries”, PRX Quantum 3, (2022) arXiv:2112.01498 DOI].
Group-GKP codes corresponding to the \(G^{k_1} \subseteq G^{k_2} \subset G^{n}\) group construction admit \(X\)-type transversal Pauli gates that represent the group \(G\), and are thus \(G\)-covariant [P. Faist et al., “Continuous Symmetries and Approximate Quantum Error Correction”, Physical Review X 10, (2020) arXiv:1902.07714 DOI].

Metrologically optimal codes can be thought of as being entanglement-assisted because they require error-free ancillas for optimal local parameter estimation, and the estimation procedure uses an entangling gate.
Metrologically optimal codes admit a \(U(1)\) set of gates generated by a signal Hamiltonian \(H\), meaning that there exists a basis of codewords that are eigenstates of the \(H\).
The five-qubit code can be used to construct an approximate code that is also covariant with respect to the unitary group.

Quantum MDS codes can be constructed from \(q\)-ary cyclic codes using the Hermitian construction [G. G. La Guardia, “New Quantum MDS Codes”, IEEE Transactions on Information Theory 57, 5551 (2011) DOI].
Many MDS codes are constructed from Hermitian self-orthogonal codes over \(GF(q^2)\) using the Hermitian construction [M. GRASSL, T. BETH, and M. RÖTTELER, “ON OPTIMAL QUANTUM CODES”, International Journal of Quantum Information 02, 55 (2004) arXiv:quant-ph/0312164 DOI][R. Li and Z. Xu, “Construction of[[n,n−4,3]]qquantum codes for odd prime powerq”, Physical Review A 82, (2010) arXiv:0906.2509 DOI][X. He, L. Xu, and H. Chen, “New \(q\)-ary Quantum MDS Codes with Distances Bigger than \(\frac{q}{2}\)”, (2015) arXiv:1507.08355][L. Lu et al., “New Quantum MDS codes constructed from Constacyclic codes”, (2018) arXiv:1803.07927], in particular from cyclic [G. G. La Guardia, “New Quantum MDS Codes”, IEEE Transactions on Information Theory 57, 5551 (2011) DOI], constacyclic [X. Kai, S. Zhu, and P. Li, “Constacyclic Codes and Some New Quantum MDS Codes”, IEEE Transactions on Information Theory 60, 2080 (2014) DOI][B. Chen, S. Ling, and G. Zhang, “Application of Constacyclic Codes to Quantum MDS Codes”, IEEE Transactions on Information Theory 61, 1474 (2015) DOI][L. Lu et al., “New Quantum MDS codes constructed from Constacyclic codes”, (2018) arXiv:1803.07927] and negacyclic [X. Kai and S. Zhu, “New Quantum MDS Codes From Negacyclic Codes”, IEEE Transactions on Information Theory 59, 1193 (2013) DOI] codes.
Many MDS codes are constructed from Hermitian self-orthogonal codes over \(GF(q^2)\) using the Hermitian construction from constacyclic codes [X. Kai, S. Zhu, and P. Li, “Constacyclic Codes and Some New Quantum MDS Codes”, IEEE Transactions on Information Theory 60, 2080 (2014) DOI][B. Chen, S. Ling, and G. Zhang, “Application of Constacyclic Codes to Quantum MDS Codes”, IEEE Transactions on Information Theory 61, 1474 (2015) DOI][L. Lu et al., “New Quantum MDS codes constructed from Constacyclic codes”, (2018) arXiv:1803.07927].
Many MDS codes are constructed from Hermitian self-orthogonal codes over \(GF(q^2)\) using the Hermitian construction [M. GRASSL, T. BETH, and M. RÖTTELER, “ON OPTIMAL QUANTUM CODES”, International Journal of Quantum Information 02, 55 (2004) arXiv:quant-ph/0312164 DOI][R. Li and Z. Xu, “Construction of[[n,n−4,3]]qquantum codes for odd prime powerq”, Physical Review A 82, (2010) arXiv:0906.2509 DOI][X. He, L. Xu, and H. Chen, “New \(q\)-ary Quantum MDS Codes with Distances Bigger than \(\frac{q}{2}\)”, (2015) arXiv:1507.08355][L. Lu et al., “New Quantum MDS codes constructed from Constacyclic codes”, (2018) arXiv:1803.07927], in particular from cyclic codes [G. G. La Guardia, “New Quantum MDS Codes”, IEEE Transactions on Information Theory 57, 5551 (2011) DOI].

A classical (quantum) perfect code saturates the classical (quantum) Hamming bound.
The only perfect qubit codes are the stabilizer code family \([[(4^r-1)/3, (4^r-1)/3 - 2r, 3]]\) for \(r \geq 2\), obtained from Hamming codes over \(GF(4)\) via the Hermitian construction [D. Gottesman, “Pasting Quantum Codes”, (1996) arXiv:quant-ph/9607027][A. R. Calderbank et al., “Quantum Error Correction via Codes over GF(4)”, (1997) arXiv:quant-ph/9608006].
The presence of an energy barrier (i.e., confinement) is sufficient for a code to be single shot, and is also conjectured to be necessary for a code to be a self-correcting memory.

Quantum Lego codes codes whose encoders are tensor networks discretizing hyperbolic space can be thought of as holographic codes. More generally, tensor-network codes are types of LEGO codes made from stabilizer codes where logical and physical legs are pre-assigned and logical legs are not contracted. In other words, logical legs resulting from the conversion of codes to tensors must remain logical in the final tensor network, and the same for physical. Contracting logical legs is another word for gluing two logical legs together.
Universal subspace approximate error correction is used to model black holes [P. Hayden and G. Penington, “Learning the Alpha-bits of black holes”, Journal of High Energy Physics 2019, (2019) arXiv:1807.06041 DOI].
Properties of holographic codes are often quantified in the Heisenberg picture, i.e., in terms of operator algebras [A. Almheiri, X. Dong, and D. Harlow, “Bulk locality and quantum error correction in AdS/CFT”, Journal of High Energy Physics 2015, (2015) arXiv:1411.7041 DOI][F. Pastawski and J. Preskill, “Code Properties from Holographic Geometries”, Physical Review X 7, (2017) arXiv:1612.00017 DOI].

Fracton phases can be understood as topological defect networks, meaning that they can be described in the language of topological quantum field theory with defects [D. Aasen et al., “Topological defect networks for fractons of all types”, Physical Review Research 2, (2020) arXiv:2002.05166 DOI][Z. Song et al., “Topological Defect Network Representations of Fracton Stabilizer Codes”, PRX Quantum 4, (2023) arXiv:2112.14717 DOI].

Codespace of a topological code is typically the ground-state or low-energy subspace of a geometrically local Hamiltonian admitting a topological phase. Logical qubits can also be created via lattice defects or by appropriately scheduling measurements of gauge generators (see Floquet codes).

Topological order can be generated in 2D monitored random circuits [A. Lavasani, Y. Alavirad, and M. Barkeshli, “Topological Order and Criticality in (2+1)D Monitored Random Quantum Circuits”, Physical Review Letters 127, (2021) arXiv:2011.06595 DOI].

Stabilizer LTCs are QLDPC. More general QLTCs are not defined using Pauli strings, but the codespace is the ground-state subspace of a local Hamiltonian. In this sense, QLTCs are QLDPC codes.
The notion of an energy barrier in a self-correcting memory is intimately related to the soundness of a QLTC.
A qubit CSS code defined by \(H_{Z}\) and \(H_{X}\) is glocally testable with some soundness iff the constituent codes \(\ker H_{Z}\) and \(\ker H_{X}\) are locally testable with the same soundness [L. Eldar and A. W. Harrow, “Local Hamiltonians Whose Ground States Are Hard to Approximate”, 2017 IEEE 58th Annual Symposium on Foundations of Computer Science (FOCS) (2017) arXiv:1510.02082 DOI; Fact 17].
Distance balancing is useful for constructing QLTCs. Scaling of the soundness of a given code family is proven in [M. B. Hastings, “Weight Reduction for Quantum Codes”, (2016) arXiv:1611.03790; Lemma 7] for the original distance balancing scheme and in [A. Wills, T.-C. Lin, and M.-H. Hsieh, “General Distance Balancing for Quantum Locally Testable Codes”, (2023) arXiv:2305.00689; Thm. 1.1] for the generalized scheme [S. Evra, T. Kaufman, and G. Zémor, “Decodable quantum LDPC codes beyond the \(\sqrt{n}\) distance barrier using high dimensional expanders”, (2020) arXiv:2004.07935].

3D translationally-invariant qubit stabilizer code families with constant \(k\) support logical string operators and thus cannot be self-correcting [B. Yoshida, “Feasibility of self-correcting quantum memory and thermal stability of topological order”, Annals of Physics 326, 2566 (2011) arXiv:1103.1885 DOI]. For non-constant \(k\), such families can support at most a logarithmic energy barrier [J. Haah, “Local stabilizer codes in three dimensions without string logical operators”, Physical Review A 83, (2011) arXiv:1101.1962 DOI].
The 4D toric code is a self-correcting quantum memory [E. Dennis et al., “Topological quantum memory”, Journal of Mathematical Physics 43, 4452 (2002) arXiv:quant-ph/0110143 DOI][R. Alicki et al., “On thermal stability of topological qubit in Kitaev’s 4D model”, (2008) arXiv:0811.0033].
The 3D welded solid code is partially self-correcting with a power-law energy barrier [K. P. Michnicki, “3D Topological Quantum Memory with a Power-Law Energy Barrier”, Physical Review Letters 113, (2014) arXiv:1406.4227 DOI]. The 3D toric code is a classical self-correcting memory, whose protected bit admits a membrane-like logical operator [O. Landon-Cardinal et al., “Perturbative instability of quantum memory based on effective long-range interactions”, Physical Review A 91, (2015) arXiv:1501.04112 DOI], but it is not a quantum self-correcting memory [Y. Li et al., “Phase diagram of the three-dimensional subsystem toric code”, (2023) arXiv:2305.06389].
The 6D color code is a self-correcting quantum memory [H. Bombin et al., “Self-Correcting Quantum Computers”, (2012) arXiv:0907.5228].
Cubic code 1 is partially self-correcting with a logarithmic energy barrier [S. Bravyi and J. Haah, “Quantum Self-Correction in the 3D Cubic Code Model”, Physical Review Letters 111, (2013) arXiv:1112.3252 DOI].
The bit-flip repetition code associated with the 2D classical Ising model is a self-correcting classical memory [B. J. Brown et al., “Quantum memories at finite temperature”, Reviews of Modern Physics 88, (2016) arXiv:1411.6643 DOI; Sec. V.A].
The repetition code associated with the 2D classical Ising model is a self-correcting classical memory [B. J. Brown et al., “Quantum memories at finite temperature”, Reviews of Modern Physics 88, (2016) arXiv:1411.6643 DOI; Sec. V.A].
3D Bacon-Shor codes were conjectured to be self-correcting [D. Bacon, “Operator quantum error-correcting subsystems for self-correcting quantum memories”, Physical Review A 73, (2006) arXiv:quant-ph/0506023 DOI], but there remain issues to be resolved in order to validate this conjecture (see [B. J. Brown et al., “Quantum memories at finite temperature”, Reviews of Modern Physics 88, (2016) arXiv:1411.6643 DOI; Sec. IX.B]).

Error-corrected sensing codes are required to satisfy the Knill-Laflamme conditions, while metrological codes need only satisfy the conditions partially.
Any time-covariant QECC, i.e., a code admitting a continuous-parameter \(U(1)\) family of gates, is automatically a metrological code.
A joint \(+1\) and \(-1\) eigenstate of a set of stabilizer can form a metrological stabilizer code [P. Faist et al., “Time-Energy Uncertainty Relation for Noisy Quantum Metrology”, PRX Quantum 4, (2023) arXiv:2207.13707 DOI].

Error-correction conditions can similarly be formulated for classical codes [B. Yoshida, “Decoding the Entanglement Structure of Monitored Quantum Circuits”, (2021) arXiv:2109.08691; Sec. 3], although they are not as widely as used as those for quantum codes.
Metrological codes are logical-qubit codes that satisfy the Knill-Laflamme conditions conditions only partially, and codes that satisfy them fully are QECCs.

QETCs are stabilizer codes: \(\mathsf{C}\) is the subspace stabilised by an abelian subgroup \(\mathsf{S} \subset \mathcal{G}_n\) of the Pauli group on \(n\) qubits.
QETCs are quantum codes which satisfy a generalisation of the Knill-Laflamme conditions. QETCs for which the admissible logical error set consists solely of the identity are QECCs.
Metrological codes are also codes which satisfy a generalisation of the Knill-Laflamme conditions, albeit a different one.

Concatenations of block quantum codes can be expressed as quantum Lego codes.
A holographic code whose encoding circuit is arranged in a tree geometry reduces to a concatenated code.

Chain complexes describing some good QLDPC codes can be 'lifted' into higher-dimensional manifolds admitting some notion of geometric locality [M. Freedman and M. B. Hastings, “Building manifolds from quantum codes”, (2021) arXiv:2012.02249]. Applying this procedure to good QLDPC codes yiels geometrically local \([[n,n^{1-2/D},n^{1-1/D}]]\) codes in \(D\) spatial dimensions, up to corrections poly-logarithmic in \(n\) [E. Portnoy, “Local Quantum Codes from Subdivided Manifolds”, (2023) arXiv:2303.06755].

Topological codes are not generally defined using Pauli strings. However, for appropriate tesselations, the codespace is the ground-state subspace of a geometrically local Hamiltonian. In this sense, topological codes are QLDPC codes. On the other hand, chain complexes describing some QLDPC codes can be 'lifted' into higher-dimensional manifolds admitting some notion of geometric locality [M. Freedman and M. B. Hastings, “Building manifolds from quantum codes”, (2021) arXiv:2012.02249]. This opens up the possibility that some QLDPC codes, despite not being geometrically local, can in fact be associated with a geometrically local theory described by a category.
QLDPC codes can arise from a dynamical process [M. Ippoliti et al., “Entanglement Phase Transitions in Measurement-Only Dynamics”, Physical Review X 11, (2021) arXiv:2004.09560 DOI].
QLDPC code Hamiltonians can be simulated by two-dimensional Hamiltonians with non-commuting terms whose interactions scale with \(n\) [H. Apel and N. Baspin, “Simulating LDPC code Hamiltonians on 2D lattices”, (2023) arXiv:2308.13277].
Qubit QLDPC codes satisfying linear confinement are single shot [A. O. Quintavalle et al., “Single-Shot Error Correction of Three-Dimensional Homological Product Codes”, PRX Quantum 2, (2021) arXiv:2009.11790 DOI]. Any code that admits a local greedy decoder also satisfies linear confinement, and so is single shot [Q. Xu et al., “Constant-Overhead Fault-Tolerant Quantum Computation with Reconfigurable Atom Arrays”, (2023) arXiv:2308.08648].

A family of approximate non-stabilizer QLWC codes with linear distance and rate has been constructed [C. Nirkhe, U. Vazirani, and H. Yuen, “Approximate Low-Weight Check Codes and Circuit Lower Bounds for Noisy Ground States”, Schloss Dagstuhl - Leibniz-Zentrum fuer Informatik GmbH, Wadern/Saarbruecken, Germany (2018) arXiv:1802.07419 DOI] using unary codes that arise from the Feynman-Kitaev clock construction [A. Kitaev, A. Shen, and M. Vyalyi, Classical and Quantum Computation (American Mathematical Society, 2002) DOI].
A family of approximate non-stabilizer QLWC codes with linear distance and rate has been constructed [C. Nirkhe, U. Vazirani, and H. Yuen, “Approximate Low-Weight Check Codes and Circuit Lower Bounds for Noisy Ground States”, Schloss Dagstuhl - Leibniz-Zentrum fuer Informatik GmbH, Wadern/Saarbruecken, Germany (2018) arXiv:1802.07419 DOI] using unary codes that arise from the Feynman-Kitaev clock construction [A. Kitaev, A. Shen, and M. Vyalyi, Classical and Quantum Computation (American Mathematical Society, 2002) DOI].

Modular-qudit stabilizer codes can be thought of as translationally-invariant stabilizer codes for dimension \(D = 0\), with the lattice consisting of a single site with some number of qudits.
Translation-invariant 2D qubit topological stabilizer codes are equivalent to several copies of the Kitaev surface code via a local constant-depth Clifford circuit [H. Bombin, G. Duclos-Cianci, and D. Poulin, “Universal topological phase of two-dimensional stabilizer codes”, New Journal of Physics 14, 073048 (2012) arXiv:1103.4606 DOI][H. Bombín, “Structure of 2D Topological Stabilizer Codes”, Communications in Mathematical Physics 327, 387 (2014) arXiv:1107.2707 DOI][J. Haah, “Algebraic Methods for Quantum Codes on Lattices”, Revista Colombiana de Matemáticas 50, 299 (2017) arXiv:1607.01387 DOI].
Translation-invariant 2D prime-qudit topological stabilizer codes are equivalent to several copies of the prime-qudit surface code via a local constant-depth Clifford circuit [J. Haah, “Classification of translation invariant topological Pauli stabilizer codes for prime dimensional qudits on two-dimensional lattices”, Journal of Mathematical Physics 62, (2021) arXiv:1812.11193 DOI].
Translationally-invariant stabilizer codes can realize 2D modular gapped Abelian bosonic topological orders [T. D. Ellison et al., “Pauli topological subsystem codes from Abelian anyon theories”, Quantum 7, 1137 (2023) arXiv:2211.03798 DOI]. Conversely, Abelian TQD codes need not be translationally invariant, and can realize multiple topological phases on one lattice.
Translationally-invariant stabilizer codes can realize fracton orders. Conversely, fracton codes need not be translationally invariant, and can realize multiple phases on one lattice.
2D topological stabilizer codes admit a bulk-boundary correspondence similar to that of holographic codes, namely, the boundary Hilbert space of the former cannot be realized via local degrees of freedom [T. Schuster et al., “A holographic view of topological stabilizer codes”, (2023) arXiv:2312.04617].

Crystalline-circuit codes can be thought of as random-circuit codes with symmetries.
Projective measurements can be included in crystalline-circuit codes in a spacetime translation-invariant fashion, turning such codes into monitored crystalline-circuit codes. However, the unit cell of measurements must be large enough to avoid purification.

The parent topological phase of the 2D DA color code is realized by two copies of the 2D color code.
The parent topological phase of the 3D DA color code is realized by two copies of the 3D color code.
One of the instantaneous stabilizer codes of the 2D DA color code are stacks of toric/surface codes
Useful measurement sequences of DA Floquet codes can be extracted from topological quantum field theory [M. Davydova et al., “Quantum computation from dynamic automorphism codes”, (2023) arXiv:2307.10353].

This code can be viewed as a subsystem stabilizer code, albeit one with less logical qubits.
Both Floquet and monitored random circuit codes can have an instantaneous stabilizer group which evolves through unitary evolution and measurements. However, Floquet codewords are generated via a specific sequence of measurements, while random-circuit codes maintain a stabilizer group after any measurement. Floquet codes have the additional capability of detecting errors induced during the measurement process; see Appx. A of Ref. [M. B. Hastings and J. Haah, “Dynamically Generated Logical Qubits”, Quantum 5, 564 (2021) arXiv:2107.02194 DOI].
Floquet codes are viable candidates for storage in Majorana-qubit devices [A. Paetznick et al., “Performance of Planar Floquet Codes with Majorana-Based Qubits”, PRX Quantum 4, (2023) arXiv:2202.11829 DOI].

The parent topological phase of the Floquet color code is the \(\mathbb{Z}_2\times\mathbb{Z}_2\) 2D color-code phase.
The ISG of the Floquet color code is the stabilizer group of one of nine realizations of the \(\mathbb{Z}_2\) 2D surface code.

The dynamically generated logical qubit of the honeycomb Floquet code is generated by appropriately scheduling measurements of the gauge generators of the \(\mathbb{Z}_{q=2}^{(1)}\) subsystem stabilizer code corresponding to the Kitaev honeycomb model. However, since this subsystem code has zero logical qubits, the instantaneous stabilizer codes of the honeycomb code cannot be interpreted as gauge-fixed versions of this subsystem code.
Measurement of each check operator of the honeycomb Floquet code involves two qubits and projects the state of the two qubits to a two-dimensional subspace, which we regard as an effective qubit. These effective qubits form a surface code on a hexagonal superlattice. Electric and magnetic operators on the embedded surface code correspond to outer logical operators of the Floquet code. In fact, outer logical operators transition back and forth from magnetic to electric surface code operators under the measurement dynamics. Inspired by this code, stabilizer measurement circuits consisting of two-body measurements have been designed for the surface code [R. Chao et al., “Optimization of the surface code design for Majorana-based qubits”, Quantum 4, 352 (2020) arXiv:2007.00307 DOI][C. Gidney, “A Pair Measurement Surface Code on Pentagons”, Quantum 7, 1156 (2023) arXiv:2206.12780 DOI].
Both honeycomb and subsystem color codes are generated via periodic sequences of measurements. However, any measurement sequence can be performed on the color code without destroying the logical qubits, while honeycomb codes can be maintained only with specific sequences. Honeycomb codes require a shorter measurement cycle and use fewer qubits at the given code distance [M. B. Hastings and J. Haah, “Dynamically Generated Logical Qubits”, Quantum 5, 564 (2021) arXiv:2107.02194 DOI].
The Honeycomb code admits a convenient representation in terms of Majorana fermions. This leads to a possible physical realization of the code in terms of tetrons [T. Karzig et al., “Scalable designs for quasiparticle-poisoning-protected topological quantum computation with Majorana zero modes”, Physical Review B 95, (2017) arXiv:1610.05289 DOI], where each physical qubit is composed of four Majorana modes.
The Floquet check operators are weight-two, and each qubit participates in one check each round.
The Kitaev honeycomb model has a Hamiltonian which is the sum of checks of the honeycomb Floquet code [M. B. Hastings and J. Haah, “Dynamically Generated Logical Qubits”, Quantum 5, 564 (2021) arXiv:2107.02194 DOI].

Approximating the random projections through \(t\)-designs is necessary in order to make the protocol practical. Replacing with random Clifford gates is especially convenient since the Clifford group forms a unitary 2-design and produces stabilizer codes.

Local Haar-random codewords, like topological codewords, are locally indistinguishable [F. G. S. L. Brandão, A. W. Harrow, and M. Horodecki, “Local Random Quantum Circuits are Approximate Polynomial-Designs”, Communications in Mathematical Physics 346, 397 (2016) DOI].

Spacetime circuit codes are useful for constructing fault-tolerant syndrome extraction circuits for qubit stabilizer codes.
The set of measurement outcomes of a Clifford circuit can be made into a classical binary linear code. Error syndromes of the spacetime circuit code can be used to obtain the parity checks of the outcome code.
Stabilizer generators of a spacetime code are called detectors in Refs. [C. Gidney, “Stim: a fast stabilizer circuit simulator”, Quantum 5, 497 (2021) arXiv:2103.02202 DOI][N. Delfosse and A. Paetznick, “Spacetime codes of Clifford circuits”, (2023) arXiv:2304.05943].
Spacetime circuit codes can be upgraded to subsystem codes by gauging a subgroup of the logical Pauli group which causes trivial faults in the corresponding Clifford circuit.
General spacetime circuit codes can be sparsified to yield QLDPC spacetime circuit codes [N. Delfosse and A. Paetznick, “Spacetime codes of Clifford circuits”, (2023) arXiv:2304.05943].
