EA qubit codes utilize additional ancillary qubits in a pre-shared entangled state, but reduce to ordinary qubit codes when said qubits are interpreted as noiseless physical qubits.
Bosonic (fermionic) codes are associated with bosonic (fermionic) degrees of freedom.

Classical self-orthogonal codes can be used to construct Majorana stabilizer codes [S. Vijay and L. Fu, “Quantum Error Correction for Complex and Majorana Fermion Qubits”, (2017) arXiv:1703.00459]. The direct relationship between the two codes follows from expressing the Majorana strings as binary vectors – akin to the binary symplectic representation – and observing that the binary stabilizer matrix \(S\) for such a Majorana stabilizer code satisfies \(S\cdot S^T=0\) because it has commuting stabilizers, which is precisely the condition \(G\cdot G^T=0\) on the generator matrix \(G\) of a self-orthogonal classical code. A self-orthogonal classical code \(C\) with parameters \([2N,k,d]\) yields a Majorana stabilizer code with parameters \([[N,N-k,d^\perp]]_f\), where \(d^\perp\) is the code distance of the dual code \(C^\perp\).
When constructing a Majorana stabilizer code from a self-orthogonal classical code with an odd number of bits and generator matrix \(G\), a more complex procedure must be applied to ensure that the fermion code has an even number of Majorana zero modes, and thus a physical Hilbert space [S. Bravyi, B. M. Terhal, and B. Leemhuis, “Majorana fermion codes”, New Journal of Physics 12, 083039 (2010) arXiv:1004.3791 DOI][S. Vijay and L. Fu, “Quantum Error Correction for Complex and Majorana Fermion Qubits”, (2017) arXiv:1703.00459]. Rather than taking \(G\) to be the stabilizer matrix as in the even case, we take \(G\oplus G\). This is a concatenation of classical codes as in the CSS construction and it yields a mapping \([2N-1,k,d]\rightarrow [[2N-1,2N-1-k,d^\perp]]_f\). This procedure may be further generalized by concatenating two different self-orthogonal classical codes with an odd number of bits, as is often done in the CSS construction.
Cyclic binary linear codes can be used to construct translation-invariant Majorana stabilizer codes, provided that they are also self-orthogonal [S. Vijay and L. Fu, “Quantum Error Correction for Complex and Majorana Fermion Qubits”, (2017) arXiv:1703.00459].
Majorana stabilizer codes can be constructed by self-orthogonal RM codes [S. Vijay and L. Fu, “Quantum Error Correction for Complex and Majorana Fermion Qubits”, (2017) arXiv:1703.00459]. These codes have the additional property that the global fermion parity is fixed in the codespace. In this family of codes, logical measurements are reduced to parity measurements of some subset of Majorana fermions in the code.
Majorana stabilizer codes are useful for Majorana-based architectures, where the degrees of freedom are electrons, and the notion of locality is different than all other code kingdoms.
The tetron code forms the ground-state subspace of two Kitaev Majorana chain Hamiltonians.

FBQC and MBQC are both computational models in which computation is done by measuring resource states (which are qubit stabilizer states). The difference between the two is in how the states are constructed. FBQC is based exclusively on two-qubit measurements tailored to photonic platforms. These measurements require a foliation with more qubits but one which can be built by fusing smaller modules.
A resource cluster state can be constructed out of any qubit CSS code via foliation. Conversely, CSS codes can be constructed out of cluster states [A. Bolt et al., “Foliated Quantum Error-Correcting Codes”, Physical Review Letters 117, (2016) arXiv:1607.02579 DOI].
The GKP cluster-state code is a concatenation of a cluster-state stabilizer code with a single-mode GKP code.
MBQC is done using a measurement-based dynamical process.
MBQC can be achieved with dual-rail codes using linear optical elements and photon detectors [D. E. Browne and T. Rudolph, “Resource-Efficient Linear Optical Quantum Computation”, Physical Review Letters 95, (2005) arXiv:quant-ph/0405157 DOI].

Arbitrary topological codes can be created using FBQC, as can topological features such as defects and boundaries, by modifying fusion measurements or adding single qubit measurements.
FBQC resource states are concatenated with dual-rail codes to increase loss detection.
Building a fusion network is done using a measurement-based dynamical process.

The RBH code can exhibit self-correction protected by a certain symmetry.
The RBH code for a certain boundary Hamiltonian is dual to the gauge color code [S. Roberts and S. D. Bartlett, “Symmetry-Protected Self-Correcting Quantum Memories”, Physical Review X 10, (2020) arXiv:1805.01474 DOI; Sec. IV.C.1].
The RBH state encodes the temporal gate operations on the surface code into a third spatial dimension [R. Raussendorf, J. Harrington, and K. Goyal, “A fault-tolerant one-way quantum computer”, Annals of Physics 321, 2242 (2006) arXiv:quant-ph/0510135 DOI][R. Raussendorf and J. Harrington, “Fault-Tolerant Quantum Computation with High Threshold in Two Dimensions”, Physical Review Letters 98, (2007) arXiv:quant-ph/0610082 DOI]. In addition, one of possible 2D boundaries of the RBH code is effectively a 2D toric code.
The RBH code is defined on the bcc lattice.

The Movassagh-Ouyang codes overlap the CWS codes but neither family is contained in the other.
CWS codes have been considered in the context of spacetime replication of quantum data [P. Hayden and A. May, “Summoning information in spacetime, or where and when can a qubit be?”, Journal of Physics A: Mathematical and Theoretical 49, 175304 (2016) arXiv:1210.0913 DOI][P. Hayden et al., “Spacetime replication of continuous variable quantum information”, New Journal of Physics 18, 083043 (2016) arXiv:1601.02544 DOI], while STCs are designed to replicate classical data.

ETH codewords, like topological codewords, are locally indistinguishable.
Several instances of ETH codes contain permutation-invariant codewords.

Many, but not all, Movassagh-Ouyang codes are stabilizer codes.
Movassagh-Ouyang codes are constructed from classical binary codes.
MPS codes have been shown to protect against non-geometrically local noise, while ETH codes protect only against erasures on geometrically local patches.

The first and second families of binary dihedral permutation-invariant codes have distance three, and the third family has the member \(((27,2,5))\).
Binary dihedral permutation invariant codewords form error spaces of XP stabilizer codes.
The \(((2^{r-1}+3,2,3))\) family of binary dihedral permutation-invariant codes realizes the same transversal gates as the \([[2^r-1, 1, 3]]\) quantum Reed-Muller codes, but require fewer qubits in almost all cases.
The \(((27,2,5))\) binary dihedral permutation-invariant code realizes the \(T\) gate transversally, but requires fewer qubits than the \([[49,1,5]]\) triorthogonal code.
The \(((11,2,3))\) binary dihedral permutation-invariant code realizes the \(T\) gate transversally, but requires fewer qubits than the \([[15,1,3]]\) quantum Reed-Muller code.

Each XP-regular code can be mapped to a CSS code with a similar logical operator structure [M. A. Webster, B. J. Brown, and S. D. Bartlett, “The XP Stabiliser Formalism: a Generalisation of the Pauli Stabiliser Formalism with Arbitrary Phases”, Quantum 6, 815 (2022) arXiv:2203.00103 DOI].
The orbit representatives of XP codes play a similar role to the word operators of CWS codes.

TQD models for the groups \(\mathbb{Z}_2^k\) can be realized as XS stabilizer codes [X. Ni, O. Buerschaper, and M. Van den Nest, “A non-commuting stabilizer formalism”, Journal of Mathematical Physics 56, (2015) arXiv:1404.5327 DOI].
Quantum Hamming codes result from applying the CSS construction to Hamming codes.

Quantum convolutional codes can be derived from quantum Reed-Muller codes [S. A. Aly, A. Klappenecker, and P. K. Sarvepalli, “Quantum Convolutional Codes Derived From Reed-Solomon and Reed-Muller Codes”, (2007) arXiv:quant-ph/0701037].

Quantum divisible codes are constructed via the CSS construction using a divisible linear binary code.
Quantum divisible codes can be constructed out of first-order RM codes.
Quantum RM codes can be derived using a procedure that yields sufficient conditions for a CSS code to admit a given transversal diagonal logical gate. Quantum divisible codes are derived in a similar procedure, but one that yields necessary and sufficient conditions.
Triorthogonal codes can be derived using a procedure that yields sufficient conditions for a CSS code to admit a given transversal diagonal logical gate. Quantum divisible codes are derived in a similar procedure, but one that yields necessary and sufficient conditions.
A fault-tolerant \(T\) gate on the five-qubit or Steane code can be obtained by concatenating with particular quantum divisible codes.
A fault-tolerant \(T\) gate on the five-qubit code can be obtained by concatenating with particular quantum divisible codes.
A fault-tolerant \(T\) gate on the Steane code can be obtained by concatenating with particular quantum divisible codes.

Quantum Hamming codes saturate the asymptotic quantum Hamming bound.
\([[2^r, 2^r-r-2, 3]]\) quantum Hamming codes are analogues of Hamming codes in that they saturate the asymptotic Hamming bound.
\([[2^r, 2^r-r-2, 3]]\) quantum Hamming code can be obtained from the CSS construction using a first-order \([2^r,r+1,2^{r-1}]\) RM code and a \([2^r,2^r-1,2]\) even-weight code [A. M. Steane, “Simple quantum error-correcting codes”, Physical Review A 54, 4741 (1996) arXiv:quant-ph/9605021 DOI].

Bit-flip codespace is the ground-state space of a one-dimensional classical Ising model with nearest-neighbor interactions.
A quantum repetition code can be thought of as a classical \([n,1,d]\) repetition code with classical distance \(d=\left\lfloor (n-1)/2\right\rfloor\) embedded in a quantum system.

The Shor code is a concatenation of a three-qubit bit-flip with a three-qubit phase-flip repetition code.
The Shor code is a concatenation of a three-qubit bit-flip with a three-qubit phase-flip repetition code.
The \([[9,1,3,3]]\) Bacon-Shor code reduces to the Shor code for a particular gauge configuration.
The Shor code is the first quantum error-correcting code.
Smolin-Smith-Wehner and iceberg codewords are superpositions of particular bitstrings and their complements.

\([[15, 7, 3]]\) Hamming-based CSS code is perfect as a CSS code, i.e., the number of its \(Z\)-type syndromes matches the number of \(X\)-type Pauli errors up to weight one [R. Chao and B. W. Reichardt, “Fault-tolerant quantum computation with few qubits”, npj Quantum Information 4, (2018) arXiv:1705.05365 DOI].

The subcodes \(\{|\overline{10}\rangle,|\overline{11}\rangle\}\) [A. Erhard et al., “Entangling logical qubits with lattice surgery”, Nature 589, 220 (2021) arXiv:2006.03071 DOI], \(\{|\overline{00}\rangle,|\overline{10}\rangle\}\) [C. K. Andersen et al., “Repeated quantum error detection in a surface code”, Nature Physics 16, 875 (2020) arXiv:1912.09410 DOI], \(\{|\overline{00}\rangle,|\overline{01}\rangle\}\) [“Exponential suppression of bit or phase errors with cyclic error correction”, Nature 595, 383 (2021) arXiv:2102.06132 DOI], and \(\{|\overline{00}\rangle,|\overline{11}\rangle\}\) [J. F. Marques et al., “Logical-qubit operations in an error-detecting surface code”, Nature Physics 18, 80 (2021) arXiv:2102.13071 DOI] of the \([[4,2,2]]\) code are small planar rotated surface codes.
The error-detecting \([[4,1,1,2]]\) Bacon-Shor code, which reduces to a subcode of the \([[4,2,2]]\) code for a particular gauge configuration, has gauge operators \(\{XXII,IIXX,ZIZI,IZIZ\}\).
The \([[4,1,2]]\) subcode \(\{|\overline{00}\rangle,|\overline{01}\rangle\}\) is the smallest member of the sub-family of \([[m^2,1,m]]\) QPC codes.
The \([[4,2,2]]\) code can be derived from the five-qubit code using a protocol that converts an \([[n,k,d]]\) code into an \([[n-1, k+1, d-1]]\) code; see Sec. 3.5 in Gottesman [D. Gottesman, “Stabilizer Codes and Quantum Error Correction”, (1997) arXiv:quant-ph/9705052].
\([[4,1,2]]\) subcodes \(\{|\overline{00}\rangle,|\overline{10}\rangle\}\) [D. W. Leung et al., “Approximate quantum error correction can lead to better codes”, Physical Review A 56, 2567 (1997) arXiv:quant-ph/9704002 DOI] and \(\{|\overline{01}\rangle,|\overline{11}\rangle\}\) [G. Alber et al., “Stabilizing Distinguishable Qubits against Spontaneous Decay by Detected-Jump Correcting Quantum Codes”, Physical Review Letters 86, 4402 (2001) arXiv:quant-ph/0103042 DOI] approximately correct a single amplitude damping error.
\([[4,1,2]]\) subcode consisting of \(\{|\overline{00}\rangle\) and any other codeword reduces to the \(0,2,4\) binomial code when the basis labels in each codeword are written as in base-ten. Such a mapping can be generalized [Linshu Li, private communication, 2018].
Magic states prepared using the \([[4,1,2]]\) subcode can be injected into a largest heavy-hex code [E. H. Chen et al., “Calibrated Decoders for Experimental Quantum Error Correction”, Physical Review Letters 128, (2022) arXiv:2110.04285 DOI][R. S. Gupta et al., “Encoding a magic state with beyond break-even fidelity”, (2023) arXiv:2305.13581].
Concatenating \([[4,2,2]]\) code with surface code can generate 2D topological code with a reasonable circuit-based threshold [B. Criger and B. Terhal, “Noise thresholds for the [4,2,2]-concatenated toric code”, Quantum Information and Computation 16, 1261 (2016) DOI].

The five-qubit code Hamiltonian is local when expressed in terms of mutually commuting Majorana operators [Aleksander Kubica, private communication, 2019].
The five-qubit code Hamiltonian is local when expressed in terms of mutually commuting Majorana operators [Aleksander Kubica, private communication, 2019].
Every \(((5,2,3))\) code is equivalent to the five-qubit code [E. M. Rains, “Quantum codes of minimum distance two”, (1997) arXiv:quant-ph/9704043; Corr. 10].
The \([[8,3,2]]\) code can be obtained from a subset of physical qubits of the \([[15,1,3]]\) code [M. Vasmer and A. Kubica, “Morphing Quantum Codes”, PRX Quantum 3, (2022) arXiv:2112.01446 DOI].

The concatenated Steane code is one of the first codes to admit a concatenated threshold [E. Knill, R. Laflamme, and W. H. Zurek, “Resilient quantum computation: error models and thresholds”, Proceedings of the Royal Society of London. Series A: Mathematical, Physical and Engineering Sciences 454, 365 (1998) arXiv:quant-ph/9702058 DOI][A. M. Steane, “Efficient fault-tolerant quantum computing”, Nature 399, 124 (1999) arXiv:quant-ph/9809054 DOI][A. M. Steane, “Overhead and noise threshold of fault-tolerant quantum error correction”, Physical Review A 68, (2003) arXiv:quant-ph/0207119 DOI]. Randomized compiling helps reduce logical error rate for some noise models [A. Jain et al., “Improved quantum error correction with randomized compiling”, Physical Review Research 5, (2023) arXiv:2303.06846 DOI].

The TFIM code stabilizers can be expressed in terms of Majorana operators.
When written in the computational basis, the phase-flip and TFIM codewords are superpositions of qubit states of fixed total parity. The superposition is equal for the phase-flip code, whereas some states appear with a \(-1\) coefficient for TFIM code. However, the TFIM code can be encoded in constant depth.

The CPC Construction uses two binary linear codes.
Tripartite CPC codes are constructed from Hamming codes via the CPC construction [N. Chancellor et al., “Graphical structures for design and verification of quantum error correction”, Quantum Science and Technology 8, 045028 (2023) arXiv:1611.08012 DOI].

EA qubit stabilizer codes utilize additional ancillary qubits in a pre-shared entangled state, but reduce to qubit stabilizer codes when said qubits are interpreted as noiseless physical qubits.
Any linear binary code can be used to construct an EA qubit stabilizer code.
Any linear quaternary (\(q=4\)) code can be used to construct an EA qubit stabilizer code.
As opposed to CSS codes, EA qubit stabilizer codes can be constructed from any linear binary code.

The five-qubit encoding isometry tiles various holographic codes because its corresponding tensor is perfect [F. Pastawski et al., “Holographic quantum error-correcting codes: toy models for the bulk/boundary correspondence”, Journal of High Energy Physics 2015, (2015) arXiv:1503.06237 DOI].
HaPPY code Hamiltonian can be expressed in terms of mutually commuting two-body Majorana operators [A. Jahn et al., “Majorana dimers and holographic quantum error-correcting codes”, Physical Review Research 1, (2019) arXiv:1905.03268 DOI].

Bivariate bicycle codes are on par with the surface code in terms of threshold, but admit a much higher ancilla-added encoding rate at the expense of having non-geometrically local weight-six check operators.

A \([[512,174,8]]\) classical-product code performed well [D. Ostrev et al., “Classical product code constructions for quantum Calderbank-Shor-Steane codes”, (2022) arXiv:2209.13474] against erasure and depolarizing noise when compared to a member of an asymptotically good quantum Tanner code family.
SPC codes are used as component codes in classical-product code constructions.
Tensor-product codes are utilized in classical-product code constructions.

Quantum check-product codes extend the concept of a check product, which yields the dual of a tensor code, to a product between a classical and a quantum code.
Quantum check-product code constructions use distance balancing to increase distance.

The specific fiber-bundle QLDPC code achieving a distance scaling better than \(\sqrt{n}~\text{polylog}(n)\) can also be formulated as an LP code (see published version [M. B. Hastings, J. Haah, and R. O’Donnell, “Fiber bundle codes: breaking the n \({}^{\text{1/2}}\) polylog( n ) barrier for Quantum LDPC codes”, Proceedings of the 53rd Annual ACM SIGACT Symposium on Theory of Computing (2021) DOI]).
Fiber-bundle code constructions use distance balancing to increase distance.

Random homological codes are asymptotically good with high probability [M. H. Freedman and M. B. Hastings, “Quantum Systems on Non-\(k\)-Hyperfinite Complexes: A Generalization of Classical Statistical Mechanics on Expander Graphs”, (2013) arXiv:1301.1363; Thm. 1].
It is conjectured that a particular class of codes called three-dimensional product codes is single shot [A. O. Quintavalle et al., “Single-Shot Error Correction of Three-Dimensional Homological Product Codes”, PRX Quantum 2, (2021) arXiv:2009.11790 DOI].

Using one part of a quantum-code chain complex constructed with one-sided loss expanders yields a \(c^3\)-LTC [T.-C. Lin and M.-H. Hsieh, “\(c^3\)-Locally Testable Codes from Lossless Expanders”, (2022) arXiv:2201.11369].
Taking a balanced product of two-sided expanders, which are only conjectured to exist, yields an asymptotically good QLDPC code family [T.-C. Lin and M.-H. Hsieh, “Good quantum LDPC codes with linear time decoder from lossless expanders”, (2022) arXiv:2203.03581].

Ramanujan tensor-product constructions use distance balancing to increase distance.
Ramanujan codes utilize the hypergraph product with a twist, which is an automorphism on one of the complexes in the tensor product, in order to increase distance [N. P. Breuckmann and J. N. Eberhardt, “Quantum Low-Density Parity-Check Codes”, PRX Quantum 2, (2021) arXiv:2103.06309 DOI].
Ramanujan codes broke 20-year record on minimum code distance set by Freedman-Meyer-Luo codes.
The XYZ product code is based on a hypergraph product of three classical codes.

DHLV code construction yields asymptotically good QLDPC codes.
Regular binary Tanner codes are used in constructing quantum DHLV codes.
Tensor codes are used in constructing quantum DHLV codes.

Quantum Tanner code construction yields asymptotically good QLDPC codes.
Regular binary Tanner codes are used in constructing quantum Tanner codes.
Tensor codes are used in constructing quantum Tanner codes.
Quantum Tanner codes are an attempt to construct asymptotically good QLDPC codes that are similar to but simpler than expander lifted-product codes; see Ref. [A. Leverrier and G. Zémor, “Efficient decoding up to a constant fraction of the code length for asymptotically good quantum codes”, (2022) arXiv:2206.07571] for connection between the codes.
SC-QLDPC code stabilizer-generator matrices have similar block form as the parity-check matrices of SC-LDPC codes.

Binary BCH codes are used to construct a subset of qubit BCH codes via the CSS construction.
BCH codes are used to construct qubit BCH codes via the CSS construction or the Hermitian construction.
Some qubit BCH codes are CSS.
Hermitian self-orthogonal quaternary BCH codes are used to construct a subset of qubit BCH codes via the Hermitian construction.

Bacon-Shor codes reduce to QPCs for particular gauge configurations.
QPCs for \(m_1=m_2\) can be conveniantly expressed in terms of mutually commuting Majorana operators [S. B. Bravyi and A. Yu. Kitaev, “Fermionic Quantum Computation”, Annals of Physics 298, 210 (2002) arXiv:quant-ph/0003137 DOI].
Without entanglement assistance, quantum polar codes are just CSS codes constructed out of polar codes.

Classification of triorthongonal codes yields a connection to Reed-Muller polynomials [S. Nezami and J. Haah, “Classification of small triorthogonal codes”, Physical Review A 106, (2022) arXiv:2107.09684 DOI].
Ref. [S. Bravyi and J. Haah, “Magic-state distillation with low overhead”, Physical Review A 86, (2012) arXiv:1209.2426 DOI] provides a family of distance \(2\) triorthogonal codes. It also presents a \([[49, 1, 5]]\) code.

CSS codes are stabilizer codes whose stabilizer groups admit a generating set of pure-\(X\) and pure-\(Z\) Pauli strings. Additionally, any \([[n,k,d]]\) stabilizer code can be mapped onto a \([[2n,2k,\geq d]]\) CSS code, with the mapping preserving geometric locality of a code up to a constant factor [M. L. Liu, N. Tantivasadakarn, and V. V. Albert, “Subsystem CSS codes, a tighter stabilizer-to-CSS mapping, and Goursat’s Lemma”, (2023) arXiv:2311.18003] (see also [S. Bravyi, B. M. Terhal, and B. Leemhuis, “Majorana fermion codes”, New Journal of Physics 12, 083039 (2010) arXiv:1004.3791 DOI]).
The CSS construction uses two related binary linear codes \(C_X\) and \(C_Z\).
CSS codes for which \(C_X=C_Z \equiv C\) are called self-orthogonal since \(C^{\perp} \subseteq C\). The stabilizer group of such codes is invariant under the Hadamard gate exchanging \(X\) and \(Z\).
Alternant codes used in the CSS construction yield quantum codes that asymptotically achieve the quantum Gilbert-Varshamov bound [J. Fan et al., “Partially Concatenated Calderbank-Shor-Steane Codes Achieving the Quantum Gilbert-Varshamov Bound Asymptotically”, IEEE Transactions on Information Theory 69, 262 (2023) DOI].
Random CSS codes asymptotically achieve linear distance with high probability, achieving the quantum Gilbert-Varshamov bound [A. R. Calderbank and P. W. Shor, “Good quantum error-correcting codes exist”, Physical Review A 54, 1098 (1996) arXiv:quant-ph/9512032 DOI].
Algebraic geometry codes can be plugged into the CSS construction to yield asymptotically good quantum codes [A. Ashikhmin, S. Litsyn, and M. Tsfasman, “Asymptotically good quantum codes”, Physical Review A 63, (2001) arXiv:quant-ph/0006061 DOI].

Qubit stabilizer codes are the closest quantum analogues of binary linear codes because addition modulo two corresponds to multiplication of stabilizers in the quantum case. Any binary linear code can be thought of as a qubit stabilizer code with \(Z\)-type stabilizer generators [D. Bacon and A. Casaccino, “Quantum Error Correcting Subsystem Codes From Two Classical Linear Codes”, (2006) arXiv:quant-ph/0610088; Table I]. The stabilizer generators are extracted from rows of the parity-check matrix, while logical \(X\) Paulis correspond to rows of the generator matrix.
Qubit stabilizer codes are in one-to-one correspondence with symplectic self-orthogonal binary linear codes of length \(2n\) via the binary symplectic representation.
Qubit stabilizer codes are in one-to-one correspondence with trace-Hermitian self-orthogonal additive quaternary codes of length \(n\) via the \(GF(4)\) representation.
Any stabilizer code can be single shot if sufficiently non-local high-weight stabilizer generators are used for syndrome measurements. These can be obtained with a Gaussian elimination procedure [E. T. Campbell, “A theory of single-shot error correction for adversarial noise”, Quantum Science and Technology 4, 025006 (2019) arXiv:1805.09271 DOI].

Hermitian qubit codes are constructed from Hermitian self-orthogonal linear codes over \(GF(4)\) via the \(GF(4)\) representation.
Duadic constacyclic codes yield many examples of Hermitian qubit codes [R. Dastbasteh et al., “Infinite class of quantum codes derived from duadic constacyclic codes”, (2023) arXiv:2312.06504].

The 2D color code has been extended to Galois qudits.
The 2D color code is equivalent to multiple decoupled copies of the 2D surface code [B. Yoshida, “Classification of quantum phases and topology of logical operators in an exactly solved model of quantum codes”, Annals of Physics 326, 15 (2011) arXiv:1007.4601 DOI][A. Kubica, B. Yoshida, and F. Pastawski, “Unfolding the color code”, New Journal of Physics 17, 083026 (2015) arXiv:1503.02065 DOI][A. B. Aloshious, A. N. Bhagoji, and P. K. Sarvepalli, “On the Local Equivalence of 2D Color Codes and Surface Codes with Applications”, (2018) arXiv:1804.00866]. Conversely, the 2D color code can condense to form the 2D surface code in nine different ways, i.e., by adding two body hopping terms along one of its three hexagonal directions to the stabilizer group and then taking the center of the resulting nonabelian group [M. S. Kesselring et al., “Anyon condensation and the color code”, (2022) arXiv:2212.00042].
Gauge fixing can be used to switch between 2D and 3D color codes, thereby yielding fault-tolerant with constant time overhead using only local quantum operations [H. Bombin, “Dimensional Jump in Quantum Error Correction”, (2016) arXiv:1412.5079].

The 3D color code is equivalent to multiple decoupled copies of the 3D surface code [B. Yoshida, “Classification of quantum phases and topology of logical operators in an exactly solved model of quantum codes”, Annals of Physics 326, 15 (2011) arXiv:1007.4601 DOI][A. Kubica, B. Yoshida, and F. Pastawski, “Unfolding the color code”, New Journal of Physics 17, 083026 (2015) arXiv:1503.02065 DOI][A. B. Aloshious, A. N. Bhagoji, and P. K. Sarvepalli, “On the Local Equivalence of 2D Color Codes and Surface Codes with Applications”, (2018) arXiv:1804.00866].

Polytopes dual to the truncated octahedron, truncated cuboctahedron, and truncated icosidodecahedron are used to construct 3D ball color codes.
Orthoplexes are used to construct hyperoctahedron color codes.

The color code on a \(D\)-dimensional closed manifold is equivalent to multiple decoupled copies of the \(D\)-dimensional surface code [B. Yoshida, “Classification of quantum phases and topology of logical operators in an exactly solved model of quantum codes”, Annals of Physics 326, 15 (2011) arXiv:1007.4601 DOI][A. Kubica, B. Yoshida, and F. Pastawski, “Unfolding the color code”, New Journal of Physics 17, 083026 (2015) arXiv:1503.02065 DOI][A. B. Aloshious, A. N. Bhagoji, and P. K. Sarvepalli, “On the Local Equivalence of 2D Color Codes and Surface Codes with Applications”, (2018) arXiv:1804.00866].
The triangular color code is defined on a trivalent lattice such as the honeycomb lattice.

The \((5,1,2)\)-convolutional code is an infinite-qubit version of the five-qubit perfect code, with the former's lattice-translation symmetry being the extension of the latter's cyclic permutation symmetry.

The 3D color and cubic code families both include 3D codes that do not admit string-like operators.
The energy of any partial implementation of code 1 is proportional to the boundary length similar to the 4D toric code, which can potentially surpress the effects of thermal errors, but it is currently an open problem.
A GB code for the group \(G=\mathbb{Z}_3^{\times 3}\) is the cubic code [P. Panteleev and G. Kalachev, “Quantum LDPC Codes With Almost Linear Minimum Distance”, IEEE Transactions on Information Theory 68, 213 (2022) arXiv:2012.04068 DOI; Sec. III.A].
A lifted-product code constructed with coefficients in the ring \(R=\mathbb{F}_2[x,y,z]/(x^L-1,y^L-1,z^L-1)\) is the cubic code [P. Panteleev and G. Kalachev, “Asymptotically Good Quantum and Locally Testable Classical LDPC Codes”, (2022) arXiv:2111.03654; Appx. B].

Matching codes were inspired by the \(\mathbb{Z}_2\) topological order phase of the Kitaev honeycomb model [A. Kitaev, “Anyons in an exactly solved model and beyond”, Annals of Physics 321, 2 (2006) arXiv:cond-mat/0506438 DOI].
The 3D surface code is a hypergraph product of three repetition codes [L. Berent et al., “Analog information decoding of bosonic quantum LDPC codes”, (2023) arXiv:2311.01328; Exam. A.1].

The hypersphere product code family has asymptotically diminishing soundness that scales as order \(\Omega(1/\log n)\), locality of stabilizer generators scaling as order \(O(\log n)\), and distance \(\Theta(\sqrt{n})\). Application of the generalized distance balancing scheme [S. Evra, T. Kaufman, and G. Zémor, “Decodable quantum LDPC codes beyond the \(\sqrt{n}\) distance barrier using high dimensional expanders”, (2020) arXiv:2004.07935] using an asymptotically good classical code of length \(t\) yields \(O(1/(\log(n) t^2))\) soundness and \(\Theta(\sqrt{n}t)\) distance while maintaining locality scaling and at the expense of a dimension scaling as \(\Theta(t^2)\) [A. Wills, T.-C. Lin, and M.-H. Hsieh, “General Distance Balancing for Quantum Locally Testable Codes”, (2023) arXiv:2305.00689].

The hypersphere product code family has asymptotically diminishing soundness that scales as order \(O(1/\log (n)^2)\), locality of stabilizer generators scaling as order \(O(\log n/ \log\log n)\), and distance \(\Theta(\sqrt{n})\). Application of the generalized distance balancing scheme [S. Evra, T. Kaufman, and G. Zémor, “Decodable quantum LDPC codes beyond the \(\sqrt{n}\) distance barrier using high dimensional expanders”, (2020) arXiv:2004.07935] using an asymptotically good classical code of length \(t\) yields \(O(1/(\log(n)^2 t^2))\) soundness and \(\Theta(\sqrt{n}t)\) distance while maintaining locality scaling and at the expense of a dimension scaling as \(\Theta(t^2)\) [A. Wills, T.-C. Lin, and M.-H. Hsieh, “General Distance Balancing for Quantum Locally Testable Codes”, (2023) arXiv:2305.00689].

Both holographic and hyperbolic surface codes utilize tesselations of hyperbolic surfaces. Encodings for the former are hyperbolically tiled tensor networks, while the latter is defined on hyperbolically tiled physical-qubit lattices.

To create CDSCs, a dynamical process is applied on top of the surface code.
Many useful CDSCs are constructed using random Clifford circuits.
The rhombic dodecahedron surface code arranges qubits and stabilizer generators on polytopes.

XY surface code can be adapted for a heavy-hexagonal lattice [Y. Kim, J. Kang, and Y. Kwon, “Design of Quantum error correcting code for biased error on heavy-hexagon structure”, (2022) arXiv:2211.14038].

XZZX code is obtained from the rotated surface code by applying Hadamard gates on a subset of qubits such that \(XXXX\) and \(ZZZZ\) generators are both mapped to \(XZXZ\).
Subsystem symmetries play a role in finite-bias decoders for both codes [B. J. Brown and D. J. Williamson, “Parallelized quantum error correction with fracton topological codes”, Physical Review Research 2, (2020) arXiv:1901.08061 DOI].
Example of \(\mathbb{Z}_2\) topological order as manifest in the Wen plaquette model [X.-G. Wen, “Quantum Orders in an Exact Soluble Model”, Physical Review Letters 90, (2003) arXiv:quant-ph/0205004 DOI].
XZZX surface code can be adapted for a heavy-hexagonal lattice [Y. Kim, J. Kang, and Y. Kwon, “Design of Quantum error correcting code for biased error on heavy-hexagon structure”, (2022) arXiv:2211.14038].
XZZX surface code can be foliated for a noise-bias preserving MBQC [J. Claes, J. E. Bourassa, and S. Puri, “Tailored cluster states with high threshold under biased noise”, npj Quantum Information 9, (2023) arXiv:2201.10566 DOI] or FBQC [H. Bombín et al., “Increasing error tolerance in quantum computers with dynamic bias arrangement”, (2023) arXiv:2303.16122] protocol.

Implementing the honeycomb Floquet code on a non-orientable cross-cap geometry allows for a logical-\(HZ\) gate to be implemented via a measurement schedule [R. Kobayashi and G. Zhu, “Fault-tolerant logical gates via constant depth circuits and emergent symmetries on non-orientable topological stabilizer and Floquet codes”, (2023) arXiv:2310.06917].

Rotated code can be obtained from hypergraph product of two cyclic binary cyclic codes with palindromic generator polynomial ([A. A. Kovalev and L. P. Pryadko, “Improved quantum hypergraph-product LDPC codes”, 2012 IEEE International Symposium on Information Theory Proceedings (2012) arXiv:1202.0928 DOI], Ex. 7).
A rotated surface code can be mapped onto a heavy square lattice, resulting in a code similar to the heavy-hexagon code [C. Chamberland et al., “Topological and Subsystem Codes on Low-Degree Graphs with Flag Qubits”, Physical Review X 10, (2020) arXiv:1907.09528 DOI].

Bring's code and related codes listed in [J. Conrad et al., “The small stellated dodecahedron code and friends”, Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society A: Mathematical, Physical and Engineering Sciences 376, 20170323 (2018) arXiv:1712.07666 DOI; Table 1] arrange qubits and stabilizer generators on polytopes.

The Majorana mapping can be used to construct efficient algorithms for simulating rounds of error correction for the surface code [S. Bravyi et al., “Correcting coherent errors with surface codes”, npj Quantum Information 4, (2018) arXiv:1710.02270 DOI].
A quantum-double model with \(G=\mathbb{Z}_2\) is the surface code. Non-stabilizer surface-code states can be prepared by augmenting the surface code with a quantum double model [K. Laubscher, D. Loss, and J. R. Wootton, “Universal quantum computation in the surface code using non-Abelian islands”, Physical Review A 100, (2019) arXiv:1811.06738 DOI].
While codewords of the surface code form ground states of the code's stabilizer Hamiltonian, they can also be ground states of other gapless Hamiltonians [C. Fernández-González et al., “Gapless Hamiltonians for the Toric Code Using the Projected Entangled Pair State Formalism”, Physical Review Letters 109, (2012) arXiv:1111.5817 DOI].

Both Shor's code and surface-17 are \([[9,1,3]]\) codes, but they are distinct (e.g., they have different weight enumerators).
Bring's code and the surface-17 code have been numerically [J. Conrad et al., “The small stellated dodecahedron code and friends”, Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society A: Mathematical, Physical and Engineering Sciences 376, 20170323 (2018) arXiv:1712.07666 DOI].

The 2D Bacon-Shor code Hamiltonian is the compass model [K. I. Kugel’ and D. I. Khomskiĭ, “The Jahn-Teller effect and magnetism: transition metal compounds”, Soviet Physics Uspekhi 25, 231 (1982) DOI][J. Dorier, F. Becca, and F. Mila, “Quantum compass model on the square lattice”, Physical Review B 72, (2005) arXiv:cond-mat/0501708 DOI].

The BBS code construction can utilize different classical codes in different rows and columns of \(A\), while the subsystem construction does not; see [S. Bravyi, “Subsystem codes with spatially local generators”, Physical Review A 83, (2011) arXiv:1008.1029 DOI; pg. 4]
Subsystem qubit CSS codes reduce to (subspace) CSS qubit codes when there is no gauge subsystem.

The Bacon-Casaccino subsystem and hypergraph-product code constructions yield the same dimension and minimum distance, but the former does not yield QLDPC codes; see [J.-P. Tillich and G. Zemor, “Quantum LDPC Codes With Positive Rate and Minimum Distance Proportional to the Square Root of the Blocklength”, IEEE Transactions on Information Theory 60, 1193 (2014) arXiv:0903.0566 DOI; pg. 18]. Two generalized Shor codes can be gauge-fixed to yield a hypergraph product code [M. Li and T. J. Yoder, “A Numerical Study of Bravyi-Bacon-Shor and Subsystem Hypergraph Product Codes”, (2020) arXiv:2002.06257; Sec. III].
In a \([[n_1n_2, k_1k_2, min(d_1, d_2)]]\) generalized Shor code, error correction is achieved by measuring \((n_1−k_1)n_2+(n_2−k_2)\) stabilizer generators [D. Poulin, “Stabilizer Formalism for Operator Quantum Error Correction”, Physical Review Letters 95, (2005) arXiv:quant-ph/0508131 DOI]. The Bacon-Casaccino subsystem code achieves the same degree of correctability, but requires only \((n_1−k_1)k_2+k_1(n_2−k_2)\) stabilizer measurements.
Bacon-Casaccino subsystem and BBS codes have been numerically compared [M. Li and T. J. Yoder, “A Numerical Study of Bravyi-Bacon-Shor and Subsystem Hypergraph Product Codes”, (2020) arXiv:2002.06257].
Classical information can also be encoded in subsystem codes using their gauge qubits [A. Nemec and A. Klappenecker, “Encoding classical information in gauge subsystems of quantum codes”, International Journal of Quantum Information 20, (2022) DOI].

Subsystem stabilizer codes reduce to stabilizer codes when there are no gauge qubits.
BCH codes yield subsystem stabilizer codes via the subsystem extension of the Hermitian construction to subsystem codes [S. A. Aly, A. Klappenecker, and P. K. Sarvepalli, “Subsystem Codes”, (2006) arXiv:quant-ph/0610153; Exam. 1].
Primitive RS codes yield subsystem stabilizer codes via the subsystem extension of the Hermitian construction to subsystem codes [S. A. Aly, A. Klappenecker, and P. K. Sarvepalli, “Subsystem Codes”, (2006) arXiv:quant-ph/0610153; Exam. 3].

Doubled color codes are constructed using a generalization of the doubling transformation [K. Betsumiya and A. Munemasa, “On triply even binary codes”, Journal of the London Mathematical Society 86, 1 (2012) arXiv:1012.4134 DOI] that combine doubly-even codes to make triply-even codes.

A particular gauge-fixed version of this code on a 3D lattice yields a self-correcting memory protected by one-form symmetries (see Sec. IV D of Ref. [S. Roberts and S. D. Bartlett, “Symmetry-Protected Self-Correcting Quantum Memories”, Physical Review X 10, (2020) arXiv:1805.01474 DOI]). The symmetric energy barrier grows linearly with the length of a side of the lattice. When the system is coupled locally to a thermal bath respecting the symmetry and below a critical temperature, the memory time grows exponentially with the side length. The subsystem color code is not a self-correcting quantum memory if symmetry protection is removed [Y. Li et al., “Phase diagram of the three-dimensional subsystem toric code”, (2023) arXiv:2305.06389].

Surface code stabilizers are used to measure the Z-type stabilizers of the code.
Bacon-Shor stabilizers are used to measure the X-type stabilizers of the code.
The \(d=2\) heavy-hexagonal code is closely related to the \([[4,1,2]]\) subcode.

The Kitaev honeycomb model can be formulated as a qubit subsystem stabilizer code. This code can be obtained from the square-lattice surface code by gauging out the anyon \(em\) [T. D. Ellison et al., “Pauli topological subsystem codes from Abelian anyon theories”, Quantum 7, 1137 (2023) arXiv:2211.03798 DOI; Sec. 7.3]. During this process, the square lattice is effectively expanded to a hexagonal lattice [T. D. Ellison et al., “Pauli topological subsystem codes from Abelian anyon theories”, Quantum 7, 1137 (2023) arXiv:2211.03798 DOI; Fig. 12].

One version of the 3F subsystem code can be obtained from two copies of the square-lattice surface code by gauging out the anyons \(e_1m_1e_2\) and \(e_2m_2\) [T. D. Ellison et al., “Pauli topological subsystem codes from Abelian anyon theories”, Quantum 7, 1137 (2023) arXiv:2211.03798 DOI; Sec. 7.4].
The 3F model cluster-like state encodes the temporal gate operations on the 3F subsystem code into a third spatial dimension [S. Roberts and D. J. Williamson, “3-Fermion topological quantum computation”, (2020) arXiv:2011.04693]. In addition, one of possible 2D boundaries of the 3F model code is effectively a 2D 3F subsystem code.

The 3D subsystem surface code is not a self-correcting quantum memory despite being a single-shot code [Y. Li et al., “Phase diagram of the three-dimensional subsystem toric code”, (2023) arXiv:2305.06389].
The 3D subsystem surface code Hamiltonian phase diagram exhibits \(\mathbb{Z}_2\) topological order [Y. Li et al., “Phase diagram of the three-dimensional subsystem toric code”, (2023) arXiv:2305.06389].
Subsystem qubit codes reduce to (subspace) qubit codes when there is no gauge subsystem.
Construction for prime \(q=p\) uses two related \(p\)-ary linear codes \(C_X\) and \(C_Z\).

The square-lattice GKP code can be obtained from the modular-qudit code by taking the physical qudit dimension to be infinite [D. Gottesman, A. Kitaev, and J. Preskill, “Encoding a qubit in an oscillator”, Physical Review A 64, (2001) arXiv:quant-ph/0008040 DOI; Sec. II].
The modular-qudit GKP code is not a block code, but it is perfect in the sense that each correctable error maps the logical space into a distinct error space.
The rotor GKP code can be thought of as a concatenation of a homological rotor code and a modular-qudit GKP code [Y. Xu, Y. Wang, and V. V. Albert, “Clifford operations and homological codes for rotors and oscillators”, (2023) arXiv:2311.07679; Fig. 3].
Modular-qudit stabilizer codes are the closest quantum analogues of additive codes over \(\mathbb{Z}_q\) because addition in the ring corresponds to multiplication of stabilizers in the quantum case.

Three-qutrit code defines a minimal secret-sharing scheme [R. Cleve, D. Gottesman, and H.-K. Lo, “How to Share a Quantum Secret”, Physical Review Letters 83, 648 (1999) arXiv:quant-ph/9901025 DOI] that is substantially generalized by approximate secret-sharing codes.

The qudit Shor code is a small qudit surface code on a Möbius strip with smooth boundary, which is obtained from removing a face of the tesselation of the projective plane \(\mathbb{R}P^2\) [M. H. Freedman and D. A. Meyer, “Projective plane and planar quantum codes”, (1998) arXiv:quant-ph/9810055; Fig. 4].
Subsystem modular-qudit CSS codes reduce to (subspace) modular-qudit CSS codes when there is no gauge subsystem.
Subsystem modular-qudit stabilizer codes reduce to modular-qudit stabilizer codes when there are no gauge qudits.

The \(\mathbb{Z}_q^{(1)}\) subsystem code can be obtained from the \(\mathbb{Z}_q\) square-lattice surface code by gauging out the anyon \(e^{-1} m\) and applying single-qubit Clifford gates [T. D. Ellison et al., “Pauli topological subsystem codes from Abelian anyon theories”, Quantum 7, 1137 (2023) arXiv:2211.03798 DOI; Sec. 7.3]. During this process, the square lattice is effectively expanded to a hexagonal lattice [T. D. Ellison et al., “Pauli topological subsystem codes from Abelian anyon theories”, Quantum 7, 1137 (2023) arXiv:2211.03798 DOI; Fig. 12].
The anyonic exchange statistics of \(\mathbb{Z}_4^{(1)}\) subsystem code resemble those of the double semion code, but its fusion rules realize the \(\mathbb{Z}_4\) group.

The semion code can be obtained from the double-semion stabilizer code by gauging out the anyon \(\bar{s}\) [T. D. Ellison et al., “Pauli topological subsystem codes from Abelian anyon theories”, Quantum 7, 1137 (2023) arXiv:2211.03798 DOI; Fig. 15].
The semion code can be obtained from the \(\mathbb{Z}_4^{(1)}\) subsystem code by condensing the anyon \(s^2\) [T. D. Ellison et al., “Pauli topological subsystem codes from Abelian anyon theories”, Quantum 7, 1137 (2023) arXiv:2211.03798 DOI; Fig. 15].

All Abelian bosonic topological orders can be realized as modular-qudit subsystem stabilizer codes by starting with an Abelian quantum double model (slightly different from that of Ref. [T. D. Ellison et al., “Pauli Stabilizer Models of Twisted Quantum Doubles”, PRX Quantum 3, (2022) arXiv:2112.11394 DOI]) along with a family of Abelian TQDs that generalize the double semion anyon theory and gauging out certain bosonic anyons [T. D. Ellison et al., “Pauli topological subsystem codes from Abelian anyon theories”, Quantum 7, 1137 (2023) arXiv:2211.03798 DOI]. The stabilizer generators of the new subsystem code may no longer be geometrically local. Non-Abelian topological orders are purported not to be realizable with Pauli stabilizer codes [A. C. Potter and R. Vasseur, “Symmetry constraints on many-body localization”, Physical Review B 94, (2016) arXiv:1605.03601 DOI].
Subsystem stabilizer code Hamiltonians described by an Abelian anyon theory do not always realize the corresponding anyonic topological order in their ground-state subspace and may exhibit a rich phase diagram. For example, the Kitaev honeycomb Hamiltonian admits the anyon theories of the 16-fold way, i.e., all minimal modular extensions of the \(\mathbb{Z}_2^{(1)}\) Abelian non-chiral non-modular anyon theory [A. Kitaev, “Anyons in an exactly solved model and beyond”, Annals of Physics 321, 2 (2006) arXiv:cond-mat/0506438 DOI][T. D. Ellison et al., “Pauli topological subsystem codes from Abelian anyon theories”, Quantum 7, 1137 (2023) arXiv:2211.03798 DOI; Footnote 25].
Any Abelian anyon theory \(A\) can be realized at one of the surfaces of a 3D Walker-Wang model whose underlying theory is an Abelian TQD containing \(A\) as a subtheory [J. Haah, “Clifford quantum cellular automata: Trivial group in 2D and Witt group in 3D”, Journal of Mathematical Physics 62, 092202 (2021) arXiv:1907.02075 DOI][W. Shirley et al., “Three-Dimensional Quantum Cellular Automata from Chiral Semion Surface Topological Order and beyond”, PRX Quantum 3, (2022) arXiv:2202.05442 DOI][T. D. Ellison et al., “Pauli topological subsystem codes from Abelian anyon theories”, Quantum 7, 1137 (2023) arXiv:2211.03798 DOI; Appx. H].

The \(\mathbb{Z}_3\times\mathbb{Z}_9\)-fusion subsystem code can be obtained from a stack of \(q=3\) and \(q=9\) square-lattice qudit surface codes by gauging out the anyons \(m_1^{-1}e_2^3\) and \(m_2^{-1}\) [T. D. Ellison et al., “Pauli topological subsystem codes from Abelian anyon theories”, Quantum 7, 1137 (2023) arXiv:2211.03798 DOI; Sec. 7.5].
Subsystem modular-qudit codes reduce to (subspace) modular-qudit codes when there is no gauge subsystem.

The double semion phase also has a realization in terms of qubits [M. A. Levin and X.-G. Wen, “String-net condensation: A physical mechanism for topological phases”, Physical Review B 71, (2005) arXiv:cond-mat/0404617 DOI] that can be compared to the qubit surface code. There is a logical basis for both the toric and double-semion codes where each codeword is a superposition of states corresponding to all noncontractible loops of a particular homotopy type. The superposition is equal for the toric code, whereas some loops appear with a \(-1\) coefficient for the double semion.
The anyon fusion rules for the double-semion code and the \(\mathbb{Z}_4\) surface code are the same, but exchange statistics are different. The double-semion code can be obtained from the \(\mathbb{Z}_4\) surface code by condensing the anyon \(e^2 m^2\) [T. D. Ellison et al., “Pauli topological subsystem codes from Abelian anyon theories”, Quantum 7, 1137 (2023) arXiv:2211.03798 DOI] or by gauging out the one-form symmetry associated with said anyon [T. D. Ellison et al., “Pauli topological subsystem codes from Abelian anyon theories”, Quantum 7, 1137 (2023) arXiv:2211.03798 DOI; Footnote 18].

Upon gauging, a Type-III \(\mathbb{Z}_2^3\) TQD realizes the same topological order as the \(G=D_4\) quantum double model [M. de W. Propitius, “Topological interactions in broken gauge theories”, (1995) arXiv:hep-th/9511195][B. Yoshida, “Topological phases with generalized global symmetries”, Physical Review B 93, (2016) arXiv:1508.03468 DOI][L. Lootens et al., “Mapping between Morita-equivalent string-net states with a constant depth quantum circuit”, Physical Review B 105, (2022) arXiv:2112.12757 DOI].
All Abelian TQD codes can be realized as modular-qudit stabilizer codes by starting with an Abelian quantum double model along with a family of Abelian TQDs that generalize the double semion anyon theory and condensing certain bosonic anyons [T. D. Ellison et al., “Pauli topological subsystem codes from Abelian anyon theories”, Quantum 7, 1137 (2023) arXiv:2211.03798 DOI].
Classical Goppa codes are used to construct their quantum versions.

Galois-qudit BCH codes can be constructed via the CSS construction or the Hermitian construction.
Galois-qudit BCH codes can be constructed via the CSS construction or the Hermitian construction.

Some Galois-qudit GRS codes are quantum MDS [L. Jin and C. Xing, “A Construction of New Quantum MDS Codes”, (2020) arXiv:1311.3009].
Galois-qudit GRS codes can be constructed via the CSS construction or the Hermitian construction.
Galois-qudit GRS codes can be constructed via the CSS construction or the Hermitian construction.

A FQRS code with no extra grouping (\(m=1\)) reduces to a Galois-qudit RS code that is CSS.
Galois-qudit RS codes codes are CSS codes constructed from Reed-Solomon codes.
A polynomial code is a quantum MDS code when \(n-k_1=k_1-k_2\).

There exists a quantum RM code \([[q, q − 2ν − 2, ν + 2]]_q\) for \( 0\leq v \leq \frac{(q-2)}{2}\) and \([[q^2,q^2-2v-2,v+2]]_q\) for \(0\leq v \leq q-2\). Both these codes satisfy the quantum Singleton bound.
Galois-qudit RM codes can be constructed via the CSS construction or the Hermitian construction.
Galois-qudit RM codes can be constructed via the CSS construction or the Hermitian construction.

A Galois qudit for \(q=p^m\) can be decomposed into a Kronecker product of \(m\) modular qudits [A. Ashikhmin and E. Knill, “Nonbinary quantum stabilizer codes”, IEEE Transactions on Information Theory 47, 3065 (2001) DOI]; see Sec. 5.3 of Ref. [A. Niehage, “Quantum Goppa Codes over Hyperelliptic Curves”, (2005) arXiv:quant-ph/0501074]. The two coincide when \(q\) is prime, and reduce to qubits when \(q=2\). However, Pauli matrices for the two types of qudits are defined differently.

Given group algebra elements \(a,b\in \mathbb{F}_q[G]\) with weights \(W_a\) and \(W_b\) (i.e., number of non-zero terms in the expansion), the 2BGA code LP\((a,b)\) has stabilizer generators of uniform weight \(W_a+W_b\). 
Any Abelian 2BGA code can be thought of as a multi-dimensional index-two quasi-cyclic code. More precisely, any finite Abelian group can be written as a direct product of several cyclic groups, e.g., \(G=C_{m_1}\times C_{m_2}\times \ldots C_{m_D}\) for a product of \(D\) cyclic groups, which is equivalent to a representation \begin{align}
  G=\langle x_1,\ldots,x_D|x_j^{m_j}=1, x_jx_ix_j^{-1}x_i^{-1}=1, \forall 1\le i,j\le D\rangle.
\tag*{(3)}\end{align} Respectively, an element of the group algebra \(\mathbb{F}_q[G]\), where \(\mathbb{F}_q\) is a finite field, can be written as a \(D\)-variate polynomial in \(\mathbb{F}_q[x_1,x_2,\ldots,x_D]\), with the degree of the generator \(x_j\) of order \(m_j\) not exceeding \(m_j-1\). An equivalent construction in terms of Kronecker products of circulant matrices was introduced in [A. A. Kovalev and L. P. Pryadko, “Quantum Kronecker sum-product low-density parity-check codes with finite rate”, Physical Review A 88, (2013) arXiv:1212.6703 DOI]. Related higher-dimensional quasi-cyclic and convolutional quantum codes have been constructed in [S. Yang and R. Calderbank, “Spatially-Coupled QDLPC Codes”, (2023) arXiv:2305.00137].

Qubit GB stabilizer generator matrices is equivalent to a 1D SC-QLDPC code, see [S. Yang and R. Calderbank, “Spatially-Coupled QDLPC Codes”, (2023) arXiv:2305.00137; Remark 7].
Stabilizer generators of the code GB\((a,b)\) have weights given by the sum of weights of polynomials \(a(x)\) and \(b(x)\). The GB code ansatz is convenient for designing quantum LDPC codes. 
A qubit GB code \([[n,k,d]]_2\) has \(k\) non-trivial relations between the syndrome bits, which is expected to help with operation in a fault-tolerant regime (in the presence of syndrome measurement errors). See Ref. [H.-K. Lin and L. P. Pryadko, “Quantum two-block group algebra codes”, (2023) arXiv:2306.16400] for many examples of such codes.
An arbitrary GB code of length \(2\ell\) is equivalent [R. Wang and L. P. Pryadko, “Distance bounds for generalized bicycle codes”, (2022) arXiv:2203.17216] to a rotated quantum hypergraph-product code with periodicity vectors \(\vec{L}_{1}\) and \(\vec{L}_{2}\) such that \(\lvert{\vec{L}_{1}\times\vec{L}_{2}\rvert=\ell}\).

Distance balancing is used to form balanced-product subsystem codes [N. P. Breuckmann and J. N. Eberhardt, “Balanced Product Quantum Codes”, IEEE Transactions on Information Theory 67, 6653 (2021) arXiv:2012.09271 DOI].
Distance balancing is used to form balanced-product subsystem codes [N. P. Breuckmann and J. N. Eberhardt, “Balanced Product Quantum Codes”, IEEE Transactions on Information Theory 67, 6653 (2021) arXiv:2012.09271 DOI].
Distance balancing relies on taking a homological product of chain complexes corresponding to a classical and a quantum code.

Lifted products of certain classical Tanner codes are the first asymptotically good QLDPC codes.
Classical codes resulting from the expander lifted-product construction are one of the first two families of \(c^3\)-LTCs.
Expander lifted-product codes are products of regular \(q\)-ary Tanner codes defined on expander graphs [S. Hoory, N. Linial, and A. Wigderson, “Expander graphs and their applications”, Bulletin of the American Mathematical Society 43, 439 (2006) DOI].
Expander lifted-product codes are quantum CSS codes that utilize short classical codes in their construction which need to satisfy some properties (Ref. [P. Panteleev and G. Kalachev, “Asymptotically Good Quantum and Locally Testable Classical LDPC Codes”, (2022) arXiv:2111.03654], Lemma 10). It is shown that such codes exist, but they are not explicitly constructed. Such codes can be obtained by repeated random sampling or by performing a search of all codes of desired length. Nevertheless, since the length of the desired short codes does not scale with \(n\), this construction is effectively explicit.

A Galois qudit for \(q=p^m\) can be decomposed into a Kronecker product of \(m\) modular qudits [A. Ashikhmin and E. Knill, “Nonbinary quantum stabilizer codes”, IEEE Transactions on Information Theory 47, 3065 (2001) DOI]; see Sec. 5.3 of Ref. [A. Niehage, “Quantum Goppa Codes over Hyperelliptic Curves”, (2005) arXiv:quant-ph/0501074]. Galois-qudit topological surface and color codes yield Abelian quantum-double codes via this decomposition.

Construction uses two related \(q\)-ary linear codes \(C_X\) and \(C_Z\).
Galois CSS codes can be constructed using self-orthogonal \(q\)-ary cyclic codes [Y. Tang et al., “New quantum codes from dual-containing cyclic codes over finite rings”, (2016) arXiv:1608.06674].

Secret-sharing codes approximately correct errors on up to \(\lfloor (n-1)/2 \rfloor\) errors.
Polynomial codes can be used for a specific construction of this code.
The classical information in this code is encoded using a Reed-Solomon code.

Singleton-bound approaching AQECCs saturate the quantum Singleton bound.
Singleton-bound approaching AQECCs utilize FQRS codes.
Quantum secret-sharing codes have asymptotically decaying rate and require qudit dimension to increase exponentially with \(n\), while Singleton-bound approaching AQECCs have constant rate and qudit dimension.
Skew-cyclic CSS codes are constructed from classical skew-cyclic codes.

When matrices \(A\) and \(B\) have row and column weights bounded by \(W\), a two-block quantum code is a quantum LDPC code with stabilizer generators bounded by \(2W\).
LP codes can be constructed using non-square matrices and taking a hypergraph product over a group algebra, while two-block quantum codes are constructed directly using square matrices.

Recalling that \(q=p^m\), Galois-qudit stabilizer codes can also be treated as prime-qudit stabilizer codes on \(mn\) qudits, giving \(k=nm-r\) [A. Ashikhmin and E. Knill, “Nonbinary quantum stabilizer codes”, IEEE Transactions on Information Theory 47, 3065 (2001) DOI]. The case \(m=1\) reduces to conventional prime-qudit stabilizer codes on \(n\) qudits.
Galois-qudit stabilizer codes are the closest quantum analogues of additive codes over \(GF(q)\) because addition in the field corresponds to multiplication of stabilizers in the quantum case.
Galois-qudit stabilizer codes are in one-to-one correspondence with trace-symplectic self-orthogonal additive codes of length \(2n\) over \(GF(q)\) via the Galois symplectic representation [A. Ashikhmin and E. Knill, “Nonbinary quantum stabilizer codes”, IEEE Transactions on Information Theory 47, 3065 (2001) DOI]. They are also in one-to-one correspondence with trace-alternating self-orthogonal additive codes of length \(n\) over \(GF(q^2)\) via the \(GF(q^2)\) representation.

A true Galois-qudit stabilizer code is the closest quantum analogue of a linear code over \(GF(q)\) because the \(q\)-ary vectors corresponding to the symplectic representation of the stabilizers form a linear subspace.

Hermitian codes are constructed from Hermitian self-orthogonal linear codes over \(GF(q^2)\) via the \(GF(q^2)\) representation.
Hermitian self-orthogonal matrix-product codes over \(GF(q^2)\) can be used to construct quantum codes via the Hermitian construction [M. Cao and J. Cui, “Construction of new quantum codes via Hermitian dual-containing matrix-product codes”, Quantum Information Processing 19, (2020) DOI][X. Liu, H. Liu, and L. Yu, “On New Quantum Codes From Matrix Product Codes”, (2021) arXiv:1604.05823].
The Hermitian construction has been extended to subsystem Galois-qudit stabilizer codes [S. A. Aly, A. Klappenecker, and P. K. Sarvepalli, “Subsystem Codes”, (2006) arXiv:quant-ph/0610153].
Subsystem Galois-qudit CSS codes reduce to (subspace) Galois-qudit CSS codes when there is no gauge subsystem.
Subsystem Galois-qudit stabilizer codes reduce to Galois-qudit stabilizer codes when there are no gauge qudits.
Subsystem Galois-qudit codes reduce to (subspace) Galois-qudit codes when there is no gauge subsystem.

Diatomic molecular codes are supported on states with various total angular momenta, while the more practical Æ codes are supported on only one subspace of fixed total momentum. The latter codes are thus more practical and more applicable to other spin spaces.
Many well-performing Æ codes can be mapped into shifted versions of binomial codes via the Holstein-Primakoff mapping.
Many well-performing Æ codes can be mapped into GNU codes via the Dicke state mapping.
Since Æ codes are defined in a subspace of fixed total angular momentum and protect against errors linear in the momentum generators, they can also be thought of a single-spin codes.
Molecular (diatomic molecular) codes are constructed using two nested subgroups of \(SO(3)\) on the state space of a particle on \(SO(3)\) (the two-sphere).
The spin-GKP (Landau-level) code is a GKP-like encoding in (Landau-level) spin coherent states.

The Spin-cat code construction utilizes the Holstein-Primakoff mapping [T. Holstein and H. Primakoff, “Field Dependence of the Intrinsic Domain Magnetization of a Ferromagnet”, Physical Review 58, 1098 (1940) DOI] (see also [C. D. Cushen and R. L. Hudson, “A quantum-mechanical central limit theorem”, Journal of Applied Probability 8, 454 (1971) DOI]) to convert cat codes into codes for spin systems.

Spin-GKP code constructions utilize the Holstein-Primakoff mapping [T. Holstein and H. Primakoff, “Field Dependence of the Intrinsic Domain Magnetization of a Ferromagnet”, Physical Review 58, 1098 (1940) DOI] (see also [C. D. Cushen and R. L. Hudson, “A quantum-mechanical central limit theorem”, Journal of Applied Probability 8, 454 (1971) DOI]) to convert various expressions for square-lattice GKP states into codes for spin systems.

Symmetrized versions of the Bacon-Shor codes are GNU codes
GNU codes lie within the ground state of ferromagnetic Heisenberg models without an external magnetic field [Y. Ouyang, “Quantum storage in quantum ferromagnets”, Physical Review B 103, (2021) arXiv:1904.01458 DOI].
GNU codes protect approximately against amplitude damping errors.
Binomial codes and GNU codes related via the Holstein-Primakoff mapping [T. Holstein and H. Primakoff, “Field Dependence of the Intrinsic Domain Magnetization of a Ferromagnet”, Physical Review 58, 1098 (1940) DOI] (see also [C. D. Cushen and R. L. Hudson, “A quantum-mechanical central limit theorem”, Journal of Applied Probability 8, 454 (1971) DOI]). A qudit generalization of GNU codes can be obtained from qudit binomial codes [V. V. Albert et al., “Performance and structure of single-mode bosonic codes”, Physical Review A 97, (2018) arXiv:1708.05010 DOI; Appx. C].
GNU codewords for \(g=1\) reduce to the phase-flip code.
GNU codes can be used to sense signals within the permutation-invariant subspace [Y. Ouyang and G. K. Brennen, “Quantum error correction on symmetric quantum sensors”, (2023) arXiv:2212.06285].

Certain Clifford codes yield permutation-invariant qubit codes with non-trivial distance [S. Omanakuttan and J. A. Gross, “Multispin Clifford codes for angular momentum errors in spin systems”, Physical Review A 108, (2023) arXiv:2304.08611 DOI] when the single spin is treated as a collective spin of several qubits.

relations_parents_detail: Sphere-packing alphabets \(\mathbb{R}^n\) are infinite fields, which are groups under addition.
The \(\Lambda_{24}\) Leech lattice code is universally optimal [H. Cohn et al., “Universal optimality of the \(E_8\) and Leech lattices and interpolation formulas”, (2022) arXiv:1902.05438].
The bcc lattice is the dual of the \(A_3=D_3\) fcc lattice.
Niemeier lattice codes are even and unimodular.

Lattice-based codes are linear codes over \(G=\mathbb{R}^n\). Because any orthogonal matrix leaving the lattice invariant has a corresponding integer matrix (see lattice code description), integer representations of groups can be used to obtain lattices [J. H. Conway and N. J. A. Sloane, Sphere Packings, Lattices and Groups (Springer New York, 1999) DOI; Ch. 3, Sec. 4.2].
The \(D_3\) root lattice is equivalent to the \(A_3\) root lattice [T. Ericson, and V. Zinoviev, eds. Codes on Euclidean spheres. Elsevier, 2001.; Ch. 10].

The \(E_8\) Gosset lattice code is even and unimodular.
The \(E_8\) Gosset lattice code is universally optimal [H. Cohn et al., “Universal optimality of the \(E_8\) and Leech lattices and interpolation formulas”, (2022) arXiv:1902.05438].
The hypercubic lattice code is odd and unimodular.
PAM codes can be thought of as QAM codes restricted to the real line. A \(q\times q\)-QAM code is informationally equivalent to two \(q\)-PAM codes.
Bounded-energy codes are sphere packings constrained to lie on or inside a sphere.
Binary group-orbit codes are group-orbit codes in Hamming space.

The set of codewords of a binary linear code can be thought of as an orbit of a particular codeword under the translation group formed by the code [T. Ericson, and V. Zinoviev, eds. Codes on Euclidean spheres. Elsevier, 2001.; Thm. 8.4.2]. However, binary group-orbit codes do not have to be linear; see [T. Ericson, and V. Zinoviev, eds. Codes on Euclidean spheres. Elsevier, 2001.; Remark 8.4.3].
Linear binary codes are linear \(q\)-ary codes for \(q=2\).
Nearly perfect codes are quasi-perfect ([F. J. MacWilliams and N. J. A. Sloane. The theory of error correcting codes. Elsevier, 1977.], pg. 533).
Perfect binary codes are nearly perfect, and \(t+1\) divides \(n-t\) for such codes. In addition, any perfect code can be extended to a nearly perfect code.
QR codes are duadic codes of prime length satisfying certain relations [V. Pless, “Duadic Codes and Generalizations”, Eurocode ’92 3 (1993) DOI].

The Golay code is perfect.
The Golay code is a binary quadratic residue code with generator polynomial \(r(x)\) over \(GF(2)\) with length \(n=23\) ([F. J. MacWilliams and N. J. A. Sloane. The theory of error correcting codes. Elsevier, 1977.], Ch. 16).
The Golay code is equivalent to a BCH code with Bose distance 5 ([F. J. MacWilliams and N. J. A. Sloane. The theory of error correcting codes. Elsevier, 1977.], Ch. 20).
The Golay code and two of its shortened versions are \(q\)-ary sharp configurations [P. Boyvalenkov, D. Danev, "Linear programming bounds." Concise Encyclopedia of Coding Theory (Chapman and Hall/CRC, 2021) DOI; Table 12.1].

Zetterberg codes are quasi-perfect, with each \(n\)-bit string at most three bit-flips away from a codeword [S. M. Dodunekov and J. E. M. Nilsson, “Algebraic decoding of the Zetterberg codes”, IEEE Transactions on Information Theory 38, 1570 (1992) DOI].

The Hadamard code is a subcode of the long code and can be obtained by restricting the long-code construction to only linear functions.
Each Hadamard codeword has length \(2^m\) and Hamming weight of \(2^{m-1}\), making this code balanced.
Hadamard codes are locally decodable [S. Yekhanin, “Locally Decodable Codes”, Foundations and Trends® in Theoretical Computer Science 6, 139 (2011) DOI].

Binary Hamming codes are equivalent to RM\(^*(r-2,r)\).
Binary Hamming codes are binary primitive narrow-sense BCH codes [W. C. Huffman and V. Pless, Fundamentals of Error-Correcting Codes (Cambridge University Press, 2003) DOI; Corr. 5.1.5]. Binary Hamming codes are cyclic [R. Hill. A First Course In Coding Theory. Oxford University Press, 1988.; Thm. 12.22].
Binary Hamming codes and several of their extended, punctured, and shortened versions are LP universally optimal codes [H. Cohn and Y. Zhao, “Energy-Minimizing Error-Correcting Codes”, IEEE Transactions on Information Theory 60, 7442 (2014) arXiv:1212.1913 DOI].
\([7,4,3]\) Hamming code is a quadratic-residue code with generator polynomial \(1+x+x^3\) [F. J. MacWilliams and N. J. A. Sloane. The theory of error correcting codes. Elsevier, 1977.].

Since permutations preserve parity, the cyclic permutation of an SPC codeword is another codeword. The generator polynomial of the code is \(x-1\).
RM\((m-1,m)\) are parity-check codes.
Binary SPCs are two-divisible.
The SPC code is a binary sharp configuration [P. Boyvalenkov, D. Danev, "Linear programming bounds." Concise Encyclopedia of Coding Theory (Chapman and Hall/CRC, 2021) DOI; Table 12.1].

The repetition code is cyclic with generator polynomial \(1+x+\cdots+x^{n-1}\).
RM\((0,m)\) are repetition codes.
Raptor codes using a trivial pre-code are LT codes. Typically, Raptor codes have constant-sized more overhead but are faster to decode.
Justesen codes can be considered as a generalized concatenation of a Reed-Solomon outer code with \(N\) distinct binary inner codes.
Goldreich-Sudan codes resulted from what is often referred to as the first systematic study of LTCs.
Left-right Cayley complex codes yield one of the first two families of \(c^3\)-LTCs.

A systematic batch code with restricted size of reconstruction sets can recover any query of \(t\) information symbols with recovery sets of size \(r\) [V. Skachek, “Batch and PIR Codes and Their Connections to Locally Repairable Codes”, Network Coding and Subspace Designs 427 (2018) DOI][A.-E. Riet, V. Skachek, and E. K. Thomas, “Batch Codes for Asynchronous Recovery of Data”, IEEE Transactions on Information Theory 68, 1545 (2022) DOI].
Conference codes are LP universally optimal codes [H. Cohn and Y. Zhao, “Energy-Minimizing Error-Correcting Codes”, IEEE Transactions on Information Theory 60, 7442 (2014) arXiv:1212.1913 DOI].

Preparata codes are uniformly packed and nearly perfect [J. M. Goethals and S. L. Snover, “Nearly perfect binary codes”, Discrete Mathematics 3, 65 (1972) DOI]. For any word \(u\) and Preparata codebook \(C\) with \(d(u, C) > 2\), we have that \(u\) has a distance 2 or 3 to exactly floor((2^m+1-1)/3) codewords.
Vasilyev codes are perfect nonlinear binary codes and are inequivalent to any linear code.
Polar codes can be represented as generalized concatenations of their kernels.

All RM codes can be constructed via the \((u|u+v)\) construction [F. J. MacWilliams and N. J. A. Sloane. The theory of error correcting codes. Elsevier, 1977.; Ch. 13].
Binary GRM codes are RM codes.
RM codes are multivariate polynomial evaluation codes with \(\cal X\) being the entire \(m\)-dimensional affine binary space ([M. A. Tsfasman and S. G. Vlăduţ, Algebraic-Geometric Codes (Springer Netherlands, 1991) DOI], pgs. 44-46; [S. G. Vléduts and Yu. I. Manin, “Linear codes and modular curves”, Journal of Soviet Mathematics 30, 2611 (1985) DOI][T. Høholdt, J.H. Van Lint, and R. Pellikaan, 1998. Algebraic geometry codes. Handbook of coding theory, 1 (Part 1), pp.871-961.]).
An RM\((r,m)\) code is \(2^{\left\lceil m/r\right\rceil-1}\)-divisible, according to McEliece's theorem [R. J. McEliece, “On periodic sequences from GF(q)”, Journal of Combinatorial Theory, Series A 10, 80 (1971) DOI][R. J. McEliece, “Weight congruences for p-ary cyclic codes”, Discrete Mathematics 3, 177 (1972) DOI].
RM codes are group-algebra codes [S. D. Berman, “On the theory of group codes”, Cybernetics 3, 25 (1969) DOI][Charpin, Pascale. Codes idéaux de certaines algèbres modulaires. Diss. 1982.][W. Willems, "Codes in Group Algebras." Concise Encyclopedia of Coding Theory (Chapman and Hall/CRC, 2021) DOI; Ex. 16.4.11]. Consider a binary vector space of dimension \( m \). Under addition, this forms a finite group with \( 2^m \) elements known as an elementary Abelian 2-group -- the direct product of \( m \) two-element cyclic groups \( \mathbb{Z}_2 \times \dots \times \mathbb{Z}_2 \). Denote this group by \( G_m \). Let \( J \) be the Jacobson radical of the group algebra \( \mathbb{F}_2 G_m \), where \(\mathbb{F}_2=GF(2)\). RM\((r,m)\) codes correspond to the ideal \( J^{m-r} \). The length of the code is \( |G_m| = 2^m \), the distance is \( 2^{m-r} \), and the dimension is \( \sum_{i=0}^r {m \choose i} \). A similar construction exists for choices of a prime \( p\neq 2 \).

Irregular LDPC codes can be formulated as multi-edge LDPC codes [Richardson, Tom, and Rüdiger Urbanke. "Multi-edge type LDPC codes." Workshop honoring Prof. Bob McEliece on his 60th birthday, California Institute of Technology, Pasadena, California. 2002.; Sec. XI].

LDPC codes based on protographs can be formulated as multi-edge LDPC codes [D. G. M. Mitchell, R. Smarandache, and D. J. Costello, “Quasi-cyclic LDPC codes based on pre-lifted protographs”, 2011 IEEE Information Theory Workshop (2011) DOI].

ARA codes can be formulated as protograph LDPC codes [D. Divsalar et al., “Protograph based LDPC codes with minimum distance linearly growing with block size”, GLOBECOM ’05. IEEE Global Telecommunications Conference, 2005. (2005) DOI].

IRA codes can be formulated as protograph LDPC codes [D. Divsalar et al., “Protograph based LDPC codes with minimum distance linearly growing with block size”, GLOBECOM ’05. IEEE Global Telecommunications Conference, 2005. (2005) DOI].
IRA codes can be interpreted as serial concatenated codes [S. Benedetto et al., “Serial concatenation of interleaved codes: performance analysis, design, and iterative decoding”, IEEE Transactions on Information Theory 44, 909 (1998) DOI].

IRA codes for which the outer code is a 1-in-3 repetition code reduce to RA codes.
ARA codes with no pre-encoding acumulator and no post-acumulator puncturing reduce to RA codes.
RAA codes with no second permutation and acumulator reduce to RA codes.

RAA codes can be formulated as protograph LDPC codes [D. Divsalar et al., “Constructing LDPC codes from simple loop-free encoding modules”, IEEE International Conference on Communications, 2005. ICC 2005. 2005 DOI].
Regular binary Tanner codes are binary Tanner codes defined on regular sparse bipartite graphs, with the inner code being the same for all vertices.
Expander codes yield an explicit (i.e., non-random) asymptotically good LDPC code family.
GL codes are the first LDPC codes.

HA-LDPC codes can be formulated as multi-edge LDPC codes [K. KASAI and K. SAKANIWA, “Spatially-Coupled MacKay-Neal Codes and Hsu-Anastasopoulos Codes”, IEICE Transactions on Fundamentals of Electronics, Communications and Computer Sciences E94-A, 2161 (2011) arXiv:1102.4612 DOI].

MN-LDPC codes re-invigorated the study of LDPC codes about 30 years after their discovery.
MN-LDPC codes can be formulated as multi-edge LDPC codes [K. KASAI and K. SAKANIWA, “Spatially-Coupled MacKay-Neal Codes and Hsu-Anastasopoulos Codes”, IEICE Transactions on Fundamentals of Electronics, Communications and Computer Sciences E94-A, 2161 (2011) arXiv:1102.4612 DOI].
Regular LDPC codes are regular binary Tanner codes defined on sparse graphs whose constraint nodes represent parity-check codes.
SC-LDPC codes can be interpreted as protograph LDPC codes [A. Beemer et al., “A Generalized Algebraic Approach to Optimizing SC-LDPC Codes”, (2017) arXiv:1710.03619].

Any ECC can be embedded into a quantum Hilbert space, and thus passed through a quantum channel, by associating elements of the alphabet with basis vectors in a Hilbert space over the complex numbers. In other words, classical codewords are elements of an alphabet, while what codewords are functions on the alphabet. For example, a bit of information can be embedded into a two-dimensional vector space by associating the two bit values with two basis vectors for the space.

The set of codewords of a linear code over \(G\) can be thought of as an orbit of a particular codeword under the group formed by the code. However, group orbit codes do not have to be linear [T. Ericson, and V. Zinoviev, eds. Codes on Euclidean spheres. Elsevier, 2001.; Remark 8.4.3].
Group-alphabet codes whose alphabet is based on the permutation group \(S_n\) are rank-modulation codes.
Matrix-based code alphabets are fields, which are groups under addition.

Gabidulin codes over \(GF(q^N)\), when expressed as matrices over \(GF(q)\), are rank-metric codes (see Def. 14 in Ref. [A. Ravagnani, “Rank-metric codes and their duality theory”, (2015) arXiv:1410.1333]). The reverse is not always true since Gabidulin codes are not always \(GF(q^N)\)-linear [A. Ravagnani, “Rank-metric codes and their duality theory”, (2015) arXiv:1410.1333; Rm. 16].
The same construction without the constraint that the codeword matrices are orthogonal.
Spacetime codes also use spatial and temporal diversity, but do not necessarily use blocks as codewords.

Quasi-cyclic codes with \(\ell=1\) are cyclic.
Constacyclic codes with \(\alpha=1\) are cyclic.
All codewords of a cyclic code can be obtained from any codeword via cyclic shifts, meaning that the code consists of only one orbit.

Under certain conditions, there is an equivalent quasi-cyclic or cyclic code for every skew-cyclic code [I. Siap et al., “Skew cyclic codes of arbitrary length”, International Journal of Information and Coding Theory 2, 10 (2011) DOI].

All sharp configurations are universally optimal [H. Cohn and A. Kumar, “Universally optimal distribution of points on spheres”, Journal of the American Mathematical Society 20, 99 (2006) arXiv:math/0607446 DOI][H. Cohn and Y. Zhao, “Energy-Minimizing Error-Correcting Codes”, IEEE Transactions on Information Theory 60, 7442 (2014) arXiv:1212.1913 DOI], but not all universally optimal codes are sharp configurations.

Not all codes are group-orbit codes, and more generally one can classify codewords into orbits of the automorphism group [J. H. Conway and N. J. A. Sloane, “Orbit and coset analysis of the Golay and related codes”, IEEE Transactions on Information Theory 36, 1038 (1990) DOI].

Evaluation AG codes are evaluation codes of rational functions \(f\) for which \(\cal X\) is an algebraic curve, i.e., an algebraic variety of dimension one [T. Høholdt, J.H. Van Lint, and R. Pellikaan, 1998. Algebraic geometry codes. Handbook of coding theory, 1 (Part 1), pp.871-961.].

Elliptic codes are evaluation AG codes with \(\cal X\) being an elliptic curve, i.e., curve of genus one ([M. A. Tsfasman and S. G. Vlăduţ, Algebraic-Geometric Codes (Springer Netherlands, 1991) DOI], Ch. 3.2; [T. Høholdt, J.H. Van Lint, and R. Pellikaan, 1998. Algebraic geometry codes. Handbook of coding theory, 1 (Part 1), pp.871-961.]).

Hermitian codes are concatenated GRS codes [T. Yaghoobian and I. F. Blake, “Hermitian codes as generalized Reed-Solomon codes”, Designs, Codes and Cryptography 2, 5 (1992) DOI].
Hermitian codes are evaluation AG codes with \(\cal X\) being a Hermitian curve ([T. Høholdt, J.H. Van Lint, and R. Pellikaan, 1998. Algebraic geometry codes. Handbook of coding theory, 1 (Part 1), pp.871-961.], Ex. 2.74). This curve is maximal, meaning that Hermitian codes are evaluation AG codes with maximum possible length given a fixed genus.

Klein-quartic codes are evaluation AG codes with \(\cal X\) being the Klein quartic ([T. Høholdt, J.H. Van Lint, and R. Pellikaan, 1998. Algebraic geometry codes. Handbook of coding theory, 1 (Part 1), pp.871-961.], Ex. 2.75).

Plane-curve codes are evaluation AG codes of bivariate polynomials with \(\cal X\) being an affine plane curve ([T. Høholdt, J.H. Van Lint, and R. Pellikaan, 1998. Algebraic geometry codes. Handbook of coding theory, 1 (Part 1), pp.871-961.], Thm. 2.27).
Suzuki-curve codes are evaluation AG codes with \(\cal X\) being a Suzuki curve.
Polynomial evaluation codes are evaluation codes of polynomials \(f\) for which \(\cal X\) is an algebraic variety.

Evaluation codes are defined using polynomial or rational functions evaluated on a subset of affine or projective space. Given access to more general structures (i.e., morphisms of algebras), any \(q\)-ary linear code can be formulated as an evaluation code ([T. Høholdt, J.H. Van Lint, and R. Pellikaan, 1998. Algebraic geometry codes. Handbook of coding theory, 1 (Part 1), pp.871-961.], Sec. 4.1; [M. Tsfasman, S. Vlǎduţ, and D. Nogin. Algebraic geometric codes: basic notions. Vol. 139. American Mathematical Society, 2022.], Prop. 1.1.4).

GRM (PRM) codes are multivariate polynomial evaluation codes with \(\cal X\) being the entire \(m\)-dimensional affine (projective) space over \(GF(q)\) ([M. A. Tsfasman and S. G. Vlăduţ, Algebraic-Geometric Codes (Springer Netherlands, 1991) DOI], pgs. 44-46; [S. G. Vléduts and Yu. I. Manin, “Linear codes and modular curves”, Journal of Soviet Mathematics 30, 2611 (1985) DOI][T. Høholdt, J.H. Van Lint, and R. Pellikaan, 1998. Algebraic geometry codes. Handbook of coding theory, 1 (Part 1), pp.871-961.]).
Applying a special case of the matrix-product procedure yields GRM codes [T. Blackmore and G. H. Norton, “Matrix-Product Codes over ? q”, Applicable Algebra in Engineering, Communication and Computing 12, 477 (2001) DOI].
GRM codes are locally decodable [S. Yekhanin, “Locally Decodable Codes”, Foundations and Trends® in Theoretical Computer Science 6, 139 (2011) DOI].

Goppa codes are \(GF(q)\)-subfield subcode of the dual of the GRS code over \(GF(q^m)\) with evaluation points \(\alpha_i\) and factors \(v_i=G(\alpha_i)^{-1}\) ([W. C. Huffman and V. Pless, Fundamentals of Error-Correcting Codes (Cambridge University Press, 2003) DOI], pg. 523; [T. Høholdt, J.H. Van Lint, and R. Pellikaan, 1998. Algebraic geometry codes. Handbook of coding theory, 1 (Part 1), pp.871-961.]).
