Goppa codes are Cartier codes from a curve of genus zero [A. Couvreur, “Codes and the Cartier Operator”, (2012) arXiv:1206.4728].

Any residue AG code of differential forms can be equivalently stated as an evaluation AG code of functions [A. Couvreur, H. Randriambololona, "Algebraic Geometry Codes and Some Applications." Concise Encyclopedia of Coding Theory (Chapman and Hall/CRC, 2021) DOI; Lemma 15.3.10][T. Høholdt, J.H. Van Lint, and R. Pellikaan, 1998. Algebraic geometry codes. Handbook of coding theory, 1 (Part 1), pp.871-961.; Thm. 2.72]. In addition, evaluation and residue AG codes are dual to each other [T. Høholdt, J.H. Van Lint, and R. Pellikaan, 1998. Algebraic geometry codes. Handbook of coding theory, 1 (Part 1), pp.871-961.][A. Couvreur, H. Randriambololona, "Algebraic Geometry Codes and Some Applications." Concise Encyclopedia of Coding Theory (Chapman and Hall/CRC, 2021) DOI; pg. 313]).
Alternant codes are subfield subcodes of GRS codes.

Extended GRS codes can be thought of as GRS codes that include an evaluation point of zero.
GRM codes for univariate polynomials (\(m=1\)) reduce to extended RS codes [J. B. Little, “Algebraic geometry codes from higher dimensional varieties”, (2008) arXiv:0802.2349].
Folding an RS code yields a code that is no longer linear over \(GF(q)\) but is linear over \(GF(q^m)\).

GRS (RS) codes are in one-to-one correspondence with evaluation AG codes of univariate polynomials \(f\) with \(\cal X\) being the projective (affine) line [T. Høholdt, J.H. Van Lint, and R. Pellikaan, 1998. Algebraic geometry codes. Handbook of coding theory, 1 (Part 1), pp.871-961.][A. Couvreur, H. Randriambololona, "Algebraic Geometry Codes and Some Applications." Concise Encyclopedia of Coding Theory (Chapman and Hall/CRC, 2021) DOI; Thm. 15.3.24][M. A. Tsfasman and S. G. Vlăduţ, Algebraic-Geometric Codes (Springer Netherlands, 1991) DOI; Ch. 3.2].
GRS (RS) codes are in one-to-one correspondence with univariate polynomial evaluation codes with \(\cal X\) being the projective (affine) line [T. Høholdt, J.H. Van Lint, and R. Pellikaan, 1998. Algebraic geometry codes. Handbook of coding theory, 1 (Part 1), pp.871-961.][A. Couvreur, H. Randriambololona, "Algebraic Geometry Codes and Some Applications." Concise Encyclopedia of Coding Theory (Chapman and Hall/CRC, 2021) DOI; Thm. 15.3.24][M. A. Tsfasman and S. G. Vlăduţ, Algebraic-Geometric Codes (Springer Netherlands, 1991) DOI; Ch. 3.2]).
IRS codes are linear over \(GF(q)\) but not necessarily over \(GF(q^t)\).
PV codes are IRS codes with specific algebraic relations between the codeword polynomials that allow for efficient list decoding.

A GRS code for which all multipliers \(v_i\) are unity reduces to an RS code.
An IRS code utilizing one polynomial \(f\) reduces to an RS code.
An FRS code with no extra grouping (\(m=1\)) reduces to an RS code.
Tamo-Barg codes reduce to RS codes when \(r=k\).
Complete-intersection RM-type codes are polynomial evaluation codes with \(\cal X\) being a complete intersection.
Deligne-Lusztig codes are polynomial evaluation codes with \(\cal X\) a Deligne-Lusztig variety.
Flag-variety codes are polynomial evaluation codes with \(\cal X\) being a flag variety.
Grassmannian codes are flag-variety evaluation codes with the flag variety being a Grassmannian.
Hermitian-hypersurface codes are flag-variety evaluation codes with the flag variety being a Hermitian hypersurface.
Quadric codes are flag-variety evaluation codes with the flag variety being a quadric hypersurface.
Ruled-surface codes are polynomial evaluation codes with \(\cal X\) being a ruled surface.
Schubert codes are flag-variety evaluation codes with the flag variety being a Schubert variety.
Serge-variety RM-type codes are polynomial evaluation codes with \(\cal X\) being a Serge variety.
Hansen toric codes are polynomial evaluation codes with \(\cal X\) being a toric variety.
Convolutional codes for infinite block size are block codes consisting of infinite blocks.
An \(m\)-weighed covering code for \(m_j=1\) is a covering code of covering radius at most \(r\) ([G. Cohen, I. Honkala, S. Litsyn, A. Lobstein, Covering codes. Elsevier, 1997.], Ch. 13).
Perfect codes are covering codes with minimum number of codewords

A quasi-perfect code is an \(m\)-weighed covering code for \(r=t+1\), \(m_0=m_1=\cdots=m_{t+1}=1\), and \(m_t=m_{t+1}=1/\left\lfloor (n+1)(t+1) \right\rfloor\) ([G. Cohen, I. Honkala, S. Litsyn, A. Lobstein, Covering codes. Elsevier, 1997.], Ch. 13).
Locally recoverable codes protect against coordinate erasure.

The generalized Singleton bound becomes the Singleton bound for \(k=r\), so optimal LRCs with that constraint are MDS.
MDS codes are LP universally optimal codes [H. Cohn and Y. Zhao, “Energy-Minimizing Error-Correcting Codes”, IEEE Transactions on Information Theory 60, 7442 (2014) arXiv:1212.1913 DOI].

Self-dual linear codes with respect to some inner product are automatically self-dual additive under the same inner product since linear codes are additive. In addition, quaternary linear codes are Hermitian self-orthogonal (self-dual) iff they are trace-Hermitian self-orthogonal (self-dual) additive [M. F. Ezerman, "Quantum Error-Control Codes." Concise Encyclopedia of Coding Theory (Chapman and Hall/CRC, 2021) DOI; Thm. 27.4.1] ([W. C. Huffman and V. Pless, Fundamentals of Error-Correcting Codes (Cambridge University Press, 2003) DOI; Thm. 9.10.3]).
The dodecacode is trace-Hermitian self-dual additive.
The Glynn code is constructed using a 10-arc in \(PG(4,9)\) that is not a rational curve.

Columns of hexacode's generator matrix represent the six homogeneous coordinates of a hyperoval in the projective plane \(PG(2,4)\) [J. Bierbrauer, Introduction to Coding Theory (Chapman and Hall/CRC, 2016) DOI; pg. 289][A. E. Brouwer, "Two-weight Codes." Concise Encyclopedia of Coding Theory (Chapman and Hall/CRC, 2021) DOI; Exam. 19.2.1].
The hexacode is an evaluation AG code over \(GF(4) = \{0,1,\omega, \bar{\omega}\}\) with \(\cal X\) defined by \(x^2 y + \omega y^2 z + \bar{\omega} z^2 x = 0\) [T. Høholdt, J.H. Van Lint, and R. Pellikaan, 1998. Algebraic geometry codes. Handbook of coding theory, 1 (Part 1), pp.871-961.; Ex. 2.77].
The hexacode is the smallest example of an extended quadratic residue code of Type \(4^H\) [Self-Dual Codes and Invariant Theory (Springer-Verlag, 2006) DOI; Sec. 2.4.6][W. C. Huffman and V. Pless, Fundamentals of Error-Correcting Codes (Cambridge University Press, 2003) DOI; Exer. 363]. The shortened hexacode is an odd-like quadratic residue code [W. C. Huffman and V. Pless, Fundamentals of Error-Correcting Codes (Cambridge University Press, 2003) DOI; Ex. 6.6.8].
The hexacode is Hermitian self-dual and, as a result, is also trace-Hermitian self-dual additive [W. C. Huffman and V. Pless, Fundamentals of Error-Correcting Codes (Cambridge University Press, 2003) DOI; Sec. 9.10]. The hexacode and the shortened hexacode are extremal [W. C. Huffman and V. Pless, Fundamentals of Error-Correcting Codes (Cambridge University Press, 2003) DOI; Tab. 9.14][G. Hoehn, “Self-dual Codes over the Kleinian Four Group”, (2000) arXiv:math/0005266; Tm. 12].
A version of the hexacode is recovered for Dennison code parameters \(i=1\) and \(a=2\) [J. Bierbrauer, Introduction to Coding Theory (Chapman and Hall/CRC, 2016) DOI].
The hexacode is an MDS code [W. C. Huffman and V. Pless, Fundamentals of Error-Correcting Codes (Cambridge University Press, 2003) DOI; Exer. 578].
The hexacode is an extended RS code [J. H. Conway and N. J. A. Sloane, Sphere Packings, Lattices and Groups (Springer New York, 1999) DOI; pg. 82].

Hamming codes and their punctured and shortened versions are LP universally optimal codes [H. Cohn and Y. Zhao, “Energy-Minimizing Error-Correcting Codes”, IEEE Transactions on Information Theory 60, 7442 (2014) arXiv:1212.1913 DOI].

RS codes for \(k=n-1\) are parity-check codes [Rudolf Schürer and Wolfgang Ch. Schmid. “Extended Reed–Solomon Code.” From MinT—the database of optimal net, code, OA, and OOA parameters. Version: 2015-09-03. http://mint.sbg.ac.at/desc_CReedSolomon-extended.html].
Since permutations coordinate sums, the cyclic permutation of an SPC codeword is another codeword. The generator polynomial of the code is \(x-1\).

The \(q\)-ary repetition code is cyclic with generator polynomial \(1+x+\cdots+x^{n-1}\).
The \(q\)-ary repetition code is a \(q\)-ary sharp configuration [P. Boyvalenkov, D. Danev, "Linear programming bounds." Concise Encyclopedia of Coding Theory (Chapman and Hall/CRC, 2021) DOI; Table 12.1].

The ternary Golay code is a quadratic residue code over \(GF(3)\) with residue set \(Q = \{1, 3, 4, 5, 9\} \) and generator polynomial \(x^5 + x^4 - x^3 + x^2 - 1\) ([F. J. MacWilliams and N. J. A. Sloane. The theory of error correcting codes. Elsevier, 1977.], Ch. 16).
The ternary Golay code is perfect.
The ternary Golay code and one of its shortened versions are \(q\)-ary sharp configurations [P. Boyvalenkov, D. Danev, "Linear programming bounds." Concise Encyclopedia of Coding Theory (Chapman and Hall/CRC, 2021) DOI; Table 12.1].

The tetracode is equivalent to \(S(3,2)\).
The tetracode is equivalent to the \(r=2\) \(3\)-ary Hamming code.
The tetracode is Euclidean self-dual.
The tetracode is an extended RS code [J. H. Conway and N. J. A. Sloane, Sphere Packings, Lattices and Groups (Springer New York, 1999) DOI; pg. 81]
BCH codes are subfield subcodes of GRS codes.
A length-\(n\) cyclic \(q\)-ary linear code is an Abelian group-algebra code for the cyclic group with \(n\) elements \( \mathbb{Z}_n \).
QR codes are duadic codes of prime length satisfying certain relations [V. Pless, “Duadic Codes and Generalizations”, Eurocode ’92 3 (1993) DOI].

A quasi group-algebra code of index \(\ell=1\) is a group-algebra code.
A \(q\)-ary group-orbit code hosts a transitive group action. If the action is also free, then the code is a group-algebra code.

A linear code is a quasi group-algebra code for a group \(G\) and index \(\ell\) if and only if \(G\) is isomorphic to a regular subgroup of the code's permutation automorphism group which acts freely of index \(\ell\) on the coordinates [M. Borello and W. Willems, “On the algebraic structure of quasi group codes”, (2021) arXiv:1912.09167; Thm. 3.5].
Meir codes stand out in that they are based on a combinatorial construction, while other LTCs often use algebraic tools.
The ovoid code is a \(q\)-ary sharp configuration [P. Boyvalenkov, D. Danev, "Linear programming bounds." Concise Encyclopedia of Coding Theory (Chapman and Hall/CRC, 2021) DOI; Table 12.1].

Denniston codes are projective two-weight codes on maximal arcs [Rudolf Schürer and Wolfgang Ch. Schmid. “Denniston Codes.” From MinT—the database of optimal net, code, OA, and OOA parameters. Version: 2015-09-03. http://mint.sbg.ac.at/desc_CDenniston.html][A. E. Brouwer, "Two-weight Codes." Concise Encyclopedia of Coding Theory (Chapman and Hall/CRC, 2021) DOI; Sec. 19.7.3].
The Denniston code is a \(q\)-ary sharp configuration [P. Boyvalenkov, D. Danev, "Linear programming bounds." Concise Encyclopedia of Coding Theory (Chapman and Hall/CRC, 2021) DOI; Table 12.1].
Singleton bound implies the Griesmer bound.
Hill projective-cap codes are projective two-weight codes on projective caps [A. E. Brouwer, "Two-weight Codes." Concise Encyclopedia of Coding Theory (Chapman and Hall/CRC, 2021) DOI; Table 19.1].

Columns of the generator matrix of a projective linear \([n,k]_q\) code correspond to distinct nonzero points in projective space. In general, linear codes admit repeating columns or columns proportional to each other. In that case, the columns correspond to a multiset of non-distinct nonzero points, and multisets are in one-to-one correspondence to arcs in projective space ([I. N. Landjev, “The Geometric Approach to Linear Codes”, Developments in Mathematics 247 (2001) DOI], Thm. 1.1).

Columns of a simplex code's generator matrix correspond to one-dimensional subspaces of \(GF(q)^n\).
Simplex codes saturate the Griesmer bound ([J. Bierbrauer, Introduction to Coding Theory (Chapman and Hall/CRC, 2016) DOI], Exer. 5.1.11).
All non-zero simplex codewords have a constant weight of \(q^{k-1}\).
Simplex codes and their punctured versions are LP universally optimal codes [H. Cohn and Y. Zhao, “Energy-Minimizing Error-Correcting Codes”, IEEE Transactions on Information Theory 60, 7442 (2014) arXiv:1212.1913 DOI].
Additive \(q\)-ary codes are linear over \(G=GF(q)\) since Galois fields are Abelian groups under addition.
Galois fields are rings under addition.

For \(q>2\), additive codes need not be linear since linearity also requires closure under multiplication.
Linear \(q\)-ary codes are \(GF(q)\)-linear.
\(q\)-ary LDPC codes are \(q\)-ary Tanner codes on sparse bipartite graphs whose constraint nodes represent \(q\)-ary parity-check codes.

All \(q\)-ary sharp configurations are universally optimal \(q\)-ary codes [H. Cohn and Y. Zhao, “Energy-Minimizing Error-Correcting Codes”, IEEE Transactions on Information Theory 60, 7442 (2014) arXiv:1212.1913 DOI], but the converse is not true.
The \(ED_m\) code is a \(q\)-ary sharp configuration [P. Boyvalenkov, D. Danev, "Linear programming bounds." Concise Encyclopedia of Coding Theory (Chapman and Hall/CRC, 2021) DOI; Table 12.1].

The SZZ equidistant code is a \(q\)-ary sharp configuration [P. Boyvalenkov, D. Danev, "Linear programming bounds." Concise Encyclopedia of Coding Theory (Chapman and Hall/CRC, 2021) DOI; Table 12.1].

The octacode is a cyclic code over \(\mathbb{Z}_4\) with generator polynomial \(x^2+3x^2+2x+3\) extended by a parity check [Self-Dual Codes and Invariant Theory (Springer-Verlag, 2006) DOI].
The octacode is self-dual over \(\mathbb{Z}_4\).
A ring \(R\) is an Abelian group under addition.
\(R\)-linear codes are linear over \(G=R\) since rings are Abelian groups under addition.
Permutations and sign changes can be implemented on vectors by orthogonal matrices, so permutation spherical codes are Slepian group-orbit codes.

The orbit of any point under the real Clifford subgroup is a spherical 7-design [V. M. Sidelnikov, Journal of Algebraic Combinatorics 10, 279 (1999) DOI], and some are 11-designs [V. M. Sidelnikov, “Orbital spherical 11-designs in which the initial point is a root of an invariant polynomial”, Algebra i Analiz, 11:4 (1999), 183–203; St. Petersburg Math. J., 11:4 (2000), 673–686].
Slepian group-orbit codes are group-orbit codes on spheres.
The minimal \(BW_{32}\) lattice-shell code is equivalent to the real Clifford subgroup-orbit code for \(n=32\).
The minimal \(\Lambda_{16}\) lattice-shell code is equivalent to the real Clifford subgroup-orbit code for \(n=16\).

BPSK is also known as 2-PSK.
A single-bit binary code yields a spherical \((n,2,4)\) spherical code under the antipodal mapping, which is equivalent to the BPSK code for dimension \(n=2\).

The PSK constellation forms a \(q\)-gon.
A polyphase code can be thought of as a concatenation of a \(q\)-ary outer code with a PSK inner code. When the outer code is trivial, the construction reduces to a PSK code.
PSK is a modulation whose constellation consists of points arranged equidistantly on a circle.

QPSK is also known as 4-PSK.
QPSK code is equivalent to the biorthogonal spherical code for \(n=2\).

Polyphase codewords can be implemented by acting on the all-ones initial vector by diagonal orthogonal matrices whose entries are the codeword components [T. Ericson, and V. Zinoviev, eds. Codes on Euclidean spheres. Elsevier, 2001.; Ch. 8]. TLSC codes are generalizations of polyphase codes to other initial vectors and are examples of Abelian Slepian-group codes.
Constant-energy codes are bounded-energy codes constrained to lie on a sphere.
The code forms a spherical 11-design because its vertices can be divided into five 600-cells, each of which forms said design.

Vertices of a 600-cell can be split up into vertices of five 24-cells [Schoute, P. H. (1903). Mehrdimensionale Geometrie, Vol. 2 (Die Polytope).][H. S. M. Coxeter. Regular polytopes. Courier Corporation, 1973.][M. Waegell and P. K. Aravind, “Critical noncolorings of the 600-cell proving the Bell–Kochen–Specker theorem”, Journal of Physics A: Mathematical and Theoretical 43, 105304 (2010) arXiv:0911.2289 DOI].
Vertices of a disphenoidal 288-cell can be split up into vertices of a 24-cell and its dual 24-cell [L. Rastanawi and G. Rote, “Towards a Geometric Understanding of the 4-Dimensional Point Groups”, (2022) arXiv:2205.04965; Sec. 8.6].
The 24-cell code is equivalent to the real Clifford subgroup-orbit code for \(n=4\).
The 24-cell code is a spherical 5-design [H. Cohn et al., “TheD\({}_{\text{4}}\)Root System Is Not Universally Optimal”, Experimental Mathematics 16, 313 (2007) arXiv:math/0607447 DOI].

Vertices of a 120-cell can be split up into vertices of five 600-cells [H. S. M. Coxeter. Regular polytopes. Courier Corporation, 1973.][M. Waegell and P. K. Aravind, “Parity Proofs of the Kochen–Specker Theorem Based on the 120-Cell”, Foundations of Physics 44, 1085 (2014) arXiv:1309.7530 DOI].
The 600-cell is universally optimal, but it is not a spherical sharp configuration [H. Cohn and A. Kumar, “Universally optimal distribution of points on spheres”, Journal of the American Mathematical Society 20, 99 (2006) arXiv:math/0607446 DOI].
The 600-cell code forms a spherical 11-design that is unique up to equivalence [P. Boyvalenkov and D. Danev, “Uniqueness of the 120-point spherical 11-design in four dimensions”, Archiv der Mathematik 77, 360 (2001) DOI].
Cubeoctahedron codewords form the minimal shell of the \(D_3\) face-centered cubic (fcc) lattice.

Disphenoidal 288-cell codewords are the union of two 24-point shells of the \(D_4\) lattice, with each shell making up the vertices of a 24-cell.
The disphenoidal 288-cell code forms a spherical 7-design [N. J. A. Sloane, R. H. Hardin, and P. Cara, “Spherical designs in four dimensions”, Proceedings 2003 IEEE Information Theory Workshop (Cat. No.03EX674) DOI].

The CGS isotropic subspace code for \(q=2\) reduces to the Hessian polytope.
The Hessian polytope code forms a tight spherical 4-design [A. Roy and S. Suda, “Complex spherical designs and codes”, (2011) arXiv:1104.4692; Exam. 7.3].

Rectified Hessian polyhedron codewords form the minimal shell of the \(E_6\) lattice.
The rectified Hessian polyhedron code forms a spherical 5-design [P. de la Harpe and C. Pache, “Spherical designs and finite group representations (some results of E. Bannai)”, European Journal of Combinatorics 25, 213 (2004) DOI].

The icosahedron is a sharp configuration [Andreev, Nikolay N. "An extremal property of the icosahedron." East J. Approx 2.4 (1996): 459-462.][H. Cohn and A. Kumar, “Universally optimal distribution of points on spheres”, Journal of the American Mathematical Society 20, 99 (2006) arXiv:math/0607446 DOI].
The icosahedron code forms a unique tight spherical 5-design [P. Delsarte, J. M. Goethals, and J. J. Seidel, “Spherical codes and designs”, Geometriae Dedicata 6, 363 (1977) DOI][T. Ericson, and V. Zinoviev, eds. Codes on Euclidean spheres. Elsevier, 2001.; Ex. 9.6.1].

Biorthogonal spherical codewords in 2 (3, 4, \(n\)) dimensions form the vertices of a square (octahedron, 16-cell, \(n\)-orthoplex).
Biorthogonal spherical codes are the only tight spherical 3-designs [T. Ericson, and V. Zinoviev, eds. Codes on Euclidean spheres. Elsevier, 2001.; Tab. 9.3].
Biorthogonal codewords form the minimal shell of the \(\mathbb{Z}^n\) hypercubic lattice.

Simplex spherical codewords in 2 (3, 4, \(n\)) dimensions form the vertices of a triangle (tetrahedron, 5-cell, \(n\)-simplex).
Simplex spherical codes are the only tight spherical 2-designs [T. Ericson, and V. Zinoviev, eds. Codes on Euclidean spheres. Elsevier, 2001.; Tab. 9.3].
A \(q\)-gon a tight spherical \(q-1\) design.
Vertices of polytope codes typically form an orbit of the polytope's symmetry group.

Witting polytope codewords form the minimal shell of the \(E_8\) lattice.
The Witting polytope code is a sharp configuration [A. V. KOLUSHOV and V. A. YUDIN, “On Korkin-Zolotarev’s construction”, Discrete Mathematics and Applications 4, (1994) DOI][H. Cohn and A. Kumar, “Universally optimal distribution of points on spheres”, Journal of the American Mathematical Society 20, 99 (2006) arXiv:math/0607446 DOI].
The Witting polytope code forms a tight spherical 7-design [J. H. Conway and N. J. A. Sloane, Sphere Packings, Lattices and Groups (Springer New York, 1999) DOI; Ch. 14].
The Witting polytope code is equivalent to the real Clifford subgroup-orbit code for \(n=8\).
A binary balanced spherical code can be thought of as a concatenation of a constant-weight binary outer code with a shifted and scaled BPSK-like inner code.
A polyphase code can be thought of as a concatenation of a \(q\)-ary outer code with a PSK inner code.

CGS isotropic subspace codes are the only known spherical sharp configrations not derived from regular polytopes or lattices [H. Cohn and A. Kumar, “Universally optimal distribution of points on spheres”, Journal of the American Mathematical Society 20, 99 (2006) arXiv:math/0607446 DOI].

All sharp configurations are universally optimal [H. Cohn and A. Kumar, “Universally optimal distribution of points on spheres”, Journal of the American Mathematical Society 20, 99 (2006) arXiv:math/0607446 DOI], but not all universally optimal spherical codes are sharp configurations. The one known exception is the 600-cell.
Spherical sharp configurations are spherical designs of strength \(2m-1\) for some \(m\).
The Hadamard BPSK c-q code can be thought of as a concatenation of the Hadamard binary linear code with BPSK for the purposes of transmission of classical information over quantum channels.
The CFSK c-q code reduces to the \(q\)-ary PSK c-q code when \(\Delta\omega = 0\) and \(\Delta\theta = 2\pi/q\).
EACQ codes utilize additional ancillary subsystems in a pre-shared entangled state, but reduce to operator-algebra QECCs when said subsystems are interpreted as noiseless physical subsystems.

Groupoid toric-code categories are unitary multi-fusion categories based on matrix algebras [L. Chang et al., “On enriching the Levin–Wen model with symmetry”, Journal of Physics A: Mathematical and Theoretical 48, 12FT01 (2015) arXiv:1412.6589 DOI], so groupoid toric codes can equivalently be formulated as multi-fusion string-net codes.

String-net codes can be realized using Levin-Wen model Hamiltonians, which realize 2D topological phases based on unitary fusion categories [M. A. Levin and X.-G. Wen, “String-net condensation: A physical mechanism for topological phases”, Physical Review B 71, (2005) arXiv:cond-mat/0404617 DOI][R. Koenig, G. Kuperberg, and B. W. Reichardt, “Quantum computation with Turaev–Viro codes”, Annals of Physics 325, 2707 (2010) arXiv:1002.2816 DOI][A. Kirillov Jr, “String-net model of Turaev-Viro invariants”, (2011) arXiv:1106.6033]. These models realize local topological order (LTO) [C. Jones et al., “Local topological order and boundary algebras”, (2023) arXiv:2307.12552].
Walker-Wang model codes can be realized using Walker-Wang model Hamiltonians, which realize 3D topological phases based on unitary braided fusion categories.
EQ operator QECCs utilize additional ancillary subsystems in a pre-shared entangled state, but reduce to subsystem QECCs when said subsystems are interpreted as noiseless physical subsystems.

The four group-qudit code is the smallest quantum double code.
The four group-qudit code is \(G\)-covariant.
Group quantum codes whose physical spaces are constructed using either the group of the integers \(\mathbb{Z}\) or the circle group \(U(1)\) are rotor codes.

Homological rotor codes are formulated using an extension of the qubit CSS-to-homology correspondence to rotors. The homology group of the logical operators has a torsion component because the chain complexes are defined over the ring of integers, which yields codes with finite logical dimension. Products of chain complexes can also yield rotor codes.

Taking \(H_X=\begin{pmatrix}-3 & 1 & 2\end{pmatrix}\) and \(H_Z=\begin{pmatrix}4&6&3\end{pmatrix}\) yields the three-rotor code.
The three-rotor code is \(U(1)\)-covariant.
The four group-qudit code reduces to the four-rotor code for \(G= \mathbb{Z}\).
The five-rotor code is \(U(1)\)-covariant.
Rotor GKP codes correspond to the \(\mathbb{Z}_{k_1} \subseteq \mathbb{Z}_{k_2} \subset U(1)\) group construction, where \(k=k_2/k_1\).
The anyon theory corresponding to a generalized color code is a trivial-cocycle TQD associated with the group \(G \times G/[G,G]\), where \(G\) is any finite group.

Quantum-double Hamiltonians can be expressed in terms of \(X\)- and \(Z\)-type operators of group-GKP codes; see [V. V. Albert et al., “Spin chains, defects, and quantum wires for the quantum-double edge”, (2021) arXiv:2111.12096; Sec. 3.3].
The anyon theory corresponding to a quantum-double code is a TQD with trivial cocycle. These models realize local topological order (LTO) [M. Tomba et al., “Boundary algebras of the Kitaev Quantum Double model”, (2023) arXiv:2309.13440].
String-net model reduces to the quantum-double model for group categories.

String-net models reduce to TQDs for categories \(\text{Vec}_G^\omega\), where \(G\) is a finite group, and \(\omega\) is a Type III cocycle. There is also a more direct duality between a large class of string–net models and certain TQD models [Y. Hu, Y. Wan, and Y.-S. Wu, “Twisted quantum double model of topological phases in two dimensions”, Physical Review B 87, (2013) arXiv:1211.3695 DOI].
The \(2T\)-qutrit is a QSC on the two-dimensional complex sphere whose code constellation is the \(4\{3\}4\) complex polytope.

Cat codes are QSCs on the one-dimensional complex sphere.
The cat code is a bosonic rotation code whose primitive state is the coherent state \(|\alpha\rangle\) [A. L. Grimsmo, J. Combes, and B. Q. Baragiola, “Quantum Computing with Rotation-Symmetric Bosonic Codes”, Physical Review X 10, (2020) arXiv:1901.08071 DOI].
The Hessian QSC is an example of a QSC with logical constellation built from the Hessian complex polyhedron.
Coherent-state QSCs are coherent-state constellation codes constrained to lie on a sphere.

The RG cat code encoder has coarse-graining features reminiscent of holography [K. Furuya, N. Lashkari, and S. Ouseph, “Real-space RG, error correction and Petz map”, Journal of High Energy Physics 2022, (2022) arXiv:2012.14001 DOI].
The cat code reduces to its two-component version for \(S=0\).

Chuang-Leung-Yamamoto code are multi-mode Fock-state codes.
Chuang-Leung-Yamamoto codewords are constructed out of Fock states with the same total excitation number.

The Wasilewski-Banaszek code is a simple example of an Ouyang-Chao code [Y. Ouyang and R. Chao, “Permutation-Invariant Constant-Excitation Quantum Codes for Amplitude Damping”, IEEE Transactions on Information Theory 66, 2921 (2020) arXiv:1809.09801 DOI].
Homological number-phase codes are bosonic codes encoding logical qudits and/or logical rotors.

Matrix-model logical states are lie in a low-energy Fock-state subspace.
Matrix-model codes approximately protect against gauge-invariant errors in the large-mode limit.
Matrix-model codewords for simple codes are eigenstates of a matrix-model Hamiltonian.
Matrix-model codes are motivated by the Ads/CFT correspondence because it is manifest in continuous non-Abelian gauge theories with large gauge groups [C. Cao, G. Cheng, and B. Swingle, “Large \(N\) Matrix Quantum Mechanics as a Quantum Memory”, (2022) arXiv:2211.08448].

One can verify by direct calculation that the logical states are eigenstates of the discrete rotation operator. One has freedom in the exact form of the primitive state to choose; see Appendix B.2 of Ref. [A. L. Grimsmo, J. Combes, and B. Q. Baragiola, “Quantum Computing with Rotation-Symmetric Bosonic Codes”, Physical Review X 10, (2020) arXiv:1901.08071 DOI].
Single-mode Fock-state codes are typically rotationally invariant.

Number-phase codes are bosonic rotation codes with the primitive state is a Pegg-Barnett phase state [S. M. Barnett and D. T. Pegg, “Phase in quantum optics”, Journal of Physics A: Mathematical and General 19, 3849 (1986) DOI].
The physical Hilbert space of a hybrid qubit-oscillator code contains at least one oscillator.
Group quantum codes whose physical spaces are constructed using the group of the reals \(\mathbb{R}\) under addition are bosonic codes.
Oscillator-into-oscillator codes are bosonic codes with an infinite-dimensional logical subspace.
Penrose tiling codes encode information into Penrose tilings, which are non-periodic tilings of \(\mathbb{R}^n\).
Qudit-into-oscillator codes are bosonic codes with a finite-dimensional logical subspace.
Analog stabilizer codes are bosonic stabilizer codes with a continuous stabilizer group, corresponding to linear constraints on positions and momenta.

The GKP cluster-state code is a concatenation of a cluster-state stabilizer code with a single-mode GKP code. A GKP-based cluster state is a multimode GKP codeword, although other codewords are not utilized in CV MBQC.

GKP-stabilizer codes are \(n\)-mode quantum lattice codes with less than \(2n\) stabilizers, i.e., constructed using a degenerate lattice (see Appx. A of Ref. [J. Conrad, J. Eisert, and F. Arzani, “Gottesman-Kitaev-Preskill codes: A lattice perspective”, Quantum 6, 648 (2022) arXiv:2109.14645 DOI]).
GKP codes are \(n\)-mode quantum lattice codes with \(2n\) stabilizers, i.e., constructed using a non-degenerate lattice.

Quantum lattice codes are bosonic stabilizer codes with a countably infinite stabilizer group, corresponding to modular constraints on positions and momenta.
Quantum lattice codewords can be written as superpositions of coherent states lying on a lattice in phase space [D. Gottesman, A. Kitaev, and J. Preskill, “Encoding a qubit in an oscillator”, Physical Review A 64, (2001) arXiv:quant-ph/0008040 DOI][V. V. Albert et al., “Performance and structure of single-mode bosonic codes”, Physical Review A 97, (2018) arXiv:1708.05010 DOI].
Covariant codes for \(n>1\) are block quantum codes.
In a proof of principle demonstration, error-correcting codes that are finite-\(G\) covariant can be constructed from a base encoding \(U_0\).
Semidefinite-program optimization procedure for finding a metrologically optimal code holds for finite-dimensional spaces.

The W-state code approximately protects against a single erasure while allowing for a universal transversal set of gates.
The W-state code approximately protects against a single erasure while allowing for a universal transversal set of gates.
All non-trivial perfect codes have distance three.
The cyclic group of these codes is a subgroup of the \(S_n\) symmetric group used in permutation invariant codes.
Fracton codes admit geometrically local stabilizer generators on a cubic lattice.
Topological codes are block codes because an infinite family of tensor-product Hilbert spaces is required to formally define a phase of matter.
Monitored random circuits are random circuits where projective measurements are interspersed throughout the circuit and measurement results are recorded.
Constant-excitation codes are associated with a Hamiltonian governing the total excitations of the system.
Quantum LTC codespaces are ground-state spaces of \(u\)-local commuting-projector Hamiltonians.
A self-correcting quantum memory does not require symmetry for self correction.

Homological products are a primary tool for generating QLDPC codes with favorable parameters. Typically, whenever the input codes are LDPC or QLDPC, the resulting code will be QLDPC with non geometrically local stabilizer generators.
The notion of homological products arises from interpreting CSS codes in terms of chain complexes over manifolds, but some products no longer yield CSS codes.

Translationally-invariant stabilizer codes are geometrically local.
Translationally-invariant stabilizer codes are invariant under translations by a unit cell.
Codespace is the ground-state space of the code Hamiltonian, which consists of an equal linear combination of stabilizer generators and which can be made into a commuting-projector Hamiltonian.
DA code state initialization, logical gates, and error correction are done by a sequence of different (usually weight-two) stabilizer measurements.
Floquet codes are DA codes with periodic measurement sequences.
The honeycomb Floquet code is the first 2D Floquet code.

The Majorana operator algebra is isomorphic to the qubit Pauli-operator algebra via the Jordan-Wigner transformation [A. Y. Kitaev, “Unpaired Majorana fermions in quantum wires”, Physics-Uspekhi 44, 131 (2001) arXiv:cond-mat/0010440 DOI]. However, Majorana codes and the noise they are designed for are based on a different notion of locality.
Kitaev chain codewords can be obtained by restricting to only one Kitaev chain out of the two chains that define the tetron Majorana code.

The Majorana stabilizer code is a stabilizer code whose stabilizers are composed of Majorana fermion operators. In addition, any \([[n,k,d]]\) stabilizer code can be mapped into a \([[2n,k,2d]]_{f}\) Majorana stabilizer code [A. Kitaev, “Anyons in an exactly solved model and beyond”, Annals of Physics 321, 2 (2006) arXiv:cond-mat/0506438 DOI][S. Bravyi, B. M. Terhal, and B. Leemhuis, “Majorana fermion codes”, New Journal of Physics 12, 083039 (2010) arXiv:1004.3791 DOI].

When treated as ground states of the code Hamiltonian, surface codewords realize, codewords of a single Kitaev chain realize \(\mathbb{Z}_2\) fermionic topological order. The MZMs used to define the tetron code act as Ising anyons, which are non-Abelian.

SYK codes are approximately error correcting in that they satisfy certain error-correction conditions based on mutual information [G. Bentsen, P. Nguyen, and B. Swingle, “Approximate Quantum Codes From Long Wormholes”, (2023) arXiv:2310.07770].
The SYK code Hamiltonian is constructed out of non-commuting few-site terms, and every fermion participates in many interactions.
In a holographic model [G. Bentsen, P. Nguyen, and B. Swingle, “Approximate Quantum Codes From Long Wormholes”, (2023) arXiv:2310.07770], the large distance of these codes can be interpreted as being due to the emergence of a wormhole.

Cluster states are particular qubit stabilizer states defined on a graph. Conversely, any fault-tolerant scheme based on qubit stabilizer codes can be mapped into a cluster-state based MBQC protocol [B. J. Brown and S. Roberts, “Universal fault-tolerant measurement-based quantum computation”, Physical Review Research 2, (2020) arXiv:1811.11780 DOI].
The resource states in FBQC are small stabilizer states, and after fusion measurements, the outputs are stabilizers (conditioned on measurement outcomes).

The Walker-Wang model code reduces to the RBH cluster-state code when the input category \(\mathcal{C}\) is that of the surface code [S. Roberts and D. J. Williamson, “3-Fermion topological quantum computation”, (2020) arXiv:2011.04693; Sec. V.A].

Restricting the underlying classical code to be symplectic self-dual reduces the \(((n,2^k L,d))\) QSQC construction to the \(((n,L,d))\) CWS construction [J.-L. Xia, “Quotient Space Quantum Codes”, (2023) arXiv:2311.07265; Sec. IV.E].

ETH codewords are eigenstates of a local Hamiltonian whose eigenstates satisfy ETH.
ETH codes approximately protect against erasures in the thermodynamic limit.
Movassagh-Ouyang codes reside in the ground space of a Hamiltonian.

MPS codewords are low-energy excited states of a local Hamiltonian.
MPS codes approximately protect against erasures in the thermodynamic limit.
Binary dihedral permutation-invariant codes can be interpreted as Clifford single-spin codes.

The \(((7,2,3))\) permutation-invariant code can be interpreted as a spin-\(7/2\) Clifford code [J. A. Gross, “Designing Codes around Interactions: The Case of a Spin”, Physical Review Letters 127, (2021) arXiv:2005.10910 DOI].
The XP stabilizer formalism reduces to the XS formalism at \(N=4\).

Modular-qudit quantum codes for \(q=2\) correspond to qubit codes.
Galois-qudit quantum codes for \(q=2\) correspond to qubit codes.
Spin codes with spin \(\ell=1/2\) correspond to qubit codes.

\([[2^r-1, 2^r-2r-1, 3]]\) Hamming-based CSS codes are quantum Reed-Muller codes because they are formed from classical Hamming codes, which are equivalent to RM\((r-2,r)\).
\([[2^r-1, 2^r-2r-1, 3]]_p\) prime-qudit CSS code for \(p=2\) reduce to \([[2^r-1, 2^r-2r-1, 3]]\) Hamming-based CSS codes.

The \([[2m,2m-2,2]]\) error-detecting code is a 1D QMDPC.
The \([[2m,2m-2,2]]\) error-detecting code is one of the two qubit quantum MDS codes [M. GRASSL, T. BETH, and M. RÖTTELER, “ON OPTIMAL QUANTUM CODES”, International Journal of Quantum Information 02, 55 (2004) arXiv:quant-ph/0312164 DOI].
Yoked surface codes are concatenations of QMDPC codes with rotated surface codes.
A \([[m_1 m_2,1,\min(m_1,m_2)]]\) QPC is a concatenation of a \(m_1\) bit-flip and a \(m_2\) phase-flip repetition codes, reducing to a repetition code when \(m_1\) or \(m_2\) is one.

The six-qubit CWS code is a non-stabilizer qubit code [V. Arvind, P. P. Kurur, and K. R. Parthasarathy, “Nonstabilizer Quantum Codes from Abelian Subgroups of the Error Group”, (2002) arXiv:quant-ph/0210097].
The \(((9,12,3))\) qubit code is a cyclic CWS code [A. Cross et al., “Codeword Stabilized Quantum Codes”, IEEE Transactions on Information Theory 55, 433 (2009) arXiv:0708.1021 DOI].

The Shor code is part of the sub-family of \([[m^2,1,m]]\) QPC codes.
The Shor code is the smallest surface code defined on the projective plane \(\mathbb{R}P^2\) [M. H. Freedman and D. A. Meyer, “Projective plane and planar quantum codes”, (1998) arXiv:quant-ph/9810055; Fig. 4].
The \([[9,1,3]]_{\mathbb{Z}_q}\) modular-qudit code for \(q=2\) reduces to the \([[9,1,3]]\) Shor code.

The \([[15,1,3]]\) code is a 3D color code.
The \([[15, 1, 3]]\) code is a triorthogonal code [S. Nezami and J. Haah, “Classification of small triorthogonal codes”, Physical Review A 106, (2022) arXiv:2107.09684 DOI].
The \([[15,1,3]]\) code, when extended to a gauge color code, is the smallest doubled color code.

\([[4,2,2]]\) code is the smallest toric code.
\([[4,2,2]]\) code can be interpreted as a small rectangular color code on a trapezoidal patch of four qubits that makes up two-thirds of a hexagon [M. S. Kesselring et al., “Anyon condensation and the color code”, (2022) arXiv:2212.00042][R. S. Gupta et al., “Encoding a magic state with beyond break-even fidelity”, (2023) arXiv:2305.13581].
The \([[4,2,2]]\) code is a hyperoctahedron code for \(D=2\).
The four group-qudit code reduces to the four-rotor code for \(G= \mathbb{Z}_2\).
\([[4,2,2]]\) code is a small quantum polar code [Kyungjoo Noh, Leung code as quantum polar code, 2017.].

The five-qubit code is the smallest XZZX surface code [A. A. Kovalev, I. Dumer, and L. P. Pryadko, “Design of additive quantum codes via the code-word-stabilized framework”, Physical Review A 84, (2011) arXiv:1108.5490 DOI; Ex. 11][A. A. Kovalev and L. P. Pryadko, “Quantum Kronecker sum-product low-density parity-check codes with finite rate”, Physical Review A 88, (2013) arXiv:1212.6703 DOI; Ex. 3].
The five-qubit code is the smallest perfect code.
The five-qubit code is derived from the \([5,3,3]_4\) shortened hexacode via the qubit Hermitian construction.
The five-qubit code is one of the two qubit quantum MDS codes.
The \([[5,1,3]]_{\mathbb{Z}_q}\) modular-qudit code for \(q=2\) reduces to the five-qubit perfect code.
The \([[5,1,3]]_q\) Galois-qudit code for \(q=2\) reduces to the five-qubit perfect code.
The five-qubit code is the smallest known example of quantum cyclic code.

The \([[8,3,2]]\) code is the smallest non-trivial 3D color code.
The \([[8,3,2]]\) code is a hyperoctahedron color code for \(D=3\).
Steane code is the smallest triangular color code.

The HaPPY code is a stabilizer code because it is defined by a contracted network of stabilizer tensors; see Thm. 6 in Ref. [F. Pastawski et al., “Holographic quantum error-correcting codes: toy models for the bulk/boundary correspondence”, Journal of High Energy Physics 2015, (2015) arXiv:1503.06237 DOI].
Bivariate bicycle codes are Abelian 2BGA codes over groups of the form \(\mathbb{Z}_{r} \times \mathbb{Z}_{s}\).

Hierarchical codes are concatenations of constant-rate QLDPC (outer) codes with (inner) rotated surface codes. The block length of the inner code is picked to grow logarithmically with the block length of the outer code.
A yoked surface code is a concatenation of a QMDPC code (outer code) with a rotated surface code (inner code).

Quantum check-product constructions yield a sLTC code with constant soundness \(2\rho\) from a classical LTC code with soundness \(\rho\). While these are the first bona-fide QLTC code family because they admit asymptotically constant soundess, they are not practical because their distance is two.

Fiber-bundle codes can be formulated in terms of a balanced product [N. P. Breuckmann and J. N. Eberhardt, “Balanced Product Quantum Codes”, IEEE Transactions on Information Theory 67, 6653 (2021) arXiv:2012.09271 DOI].
Fiber-bundle code can be viewed as a homological product code with a twisted product.

A homological product of chain complexes corresponding to two classical codes is a hypergraph product code [M. B. Hastings, J. Haah, and R. O’Donnell, “Fiber Bundle Codes: Breaking the \(N^{1/2} \operatorname{polylog}(N)\) Barrier for Quantum LDPC Codes”, (2020) arXiv:2009.03921].
Lifted-product codes for trivial group \(G\) are hypergraph-product codes.
Hypergraph-product stabilizer generator matrices can be used as sub-matrices to define a 2D SC-QLDPC code [S. Yang and R. Calderbank, “Spatially-Coupled QDLPC Codes”, (2023) arXiv:2305.00137].

Quantum expander codes are single-shot [O. Fawzi, A. Grospellier, and A. Leverrier, “Constant Overhead Quantum Fault-Tolerance with Quantum Expander Codes”, 2018 IEEE 59th Annual Symposium on Foundations of Computer Science (FOCS) (2018) arXiv:1808.03821 DOI].
Ramanujan codes result from a tensor product of a classical-code and a quantum-code chain complex.

XYZ product codes result from a tensor product of three classical-code chain complexes.
XYZ-product stabilizer generator matrices can be used as sub-matrices to define a 2D SC-QLDPC code [S. Yang and R. Calderbank, “Spatially-Coupled QDLPC Codes”, (2023) arXiv:2305.00137].
Quantum Tanner codes facilitate single-shot decoding [S. Gu et al., “Single-shot decoding of good quantum LDPC codes”, (2023) arXiv:2306.12470].
Stabilizer generator matrices of SC-QLDPC codes on infinite-length chains or grids define a class of translationally-invariant stabilizer codes.
Galois-qudit BCH codes for \(q=2\) reduce to qubit BCH codes.
A QPC is a concatenation of a phase-flip repetition code with a bit-flip repetition code.

Quantum polar codes are CSS codes used in an entanglement generation scheme that generally requires entanglement assistance. They require assistance only to determine positions to store information which optimally protect against both bit and phase noise. Without this assistance, they are just CSS codes constructed out of polar codes. A variant of quantum polar codes exists that does not require entanglement assistance [J. M. Renes et al., “Efficient Quantum Polar Codes Requiring No Preshared Entanglement”, IEEE Transactions on Information Theory 61, 6395 (2015) arXiv:1307.1136 DOI].

CSS codes are a subset of CPC codes [N. Chancellor et al., “Graphical structures for design and verification of quantum error correction”, Quantum Science and Technology 8, 045028 (2023) arXiv:1611.08012 DOI], with the latter not requiring the two classical codes to be related.
Movassagh-Ouyang codes stem from a prescription that converts an arbitrary classical code into a quantum code.
Modular-qudit CSS codes for \(q=2\) are (qubit) CSS codes.
Galois-qudit CSS codes for \(q=2\) are (qubit) CSS codes.

If the CWS set \( \mathcal{W} \) is an Abelian group not containing \(-I\), then the CWS code is a stabilizer code.
The XP stabilizer formalism reduces to the Pauli formalism at \(N=2\).
Modular-qudit stabilizer codes for \(q=2\) correspond to qubit stabilizer codes. Modular-qudit stabilizer codes for prime-dimensional qudits \(q=p\) inherit most of the features of qubit stabilizer codes, including encoding an integer number of qudits and a Pauli group with a unique number of generators. Conversely, qubit codes can be extended to modular-qudit codes by decorating appropriate generators with powers. For example, \([[4,2,2]]\) qubit code generators can be adjusted to \(ZZZZ\) and \(XX^{-1} XX^{-1}\). A systematic procedure extending a qubit code to prime-qudit codes involves putting its generator matrix into local-dimension-invariant (LDI) form [L. G. Gunderman, “Local-dimension-invariant qudit stabilizer codes”, Physical Review A 101, (2020) arXiv:1910.08122 DOI]. Various bounds exist on the distance of the resulting codes [A. J. Moorthy and L. G. Gunderman, “Local-dimension-invariant Calderbank-Shor-Steane Codes with an Improved Distance Promise”, (2021) arXiv:2110.11510][L. G. Gunderman, “Degenerate local-dimension-invariant stabilizer codes and an alternative bound for the distance preservation condition”, Physical Review A 105, (2022) arXiv:2110.15274 DOI].
Galois-qudit stabilizer codes for \(q=2\) correspond to qubit stabilizer codes.

The generalized color code for \(G=\mathbb{Z}_2\) reduces to the 2D color code.
When treated as ground states of the code Hamiltonian, states of the color code on a torus geometry on realize \(\mathbb{Z}_2\times\mathbb{Z}_2\) topological order [M. Kargarian, H. Bombin, and M. A. Martin-Delgado, “Topological color codes and two-body quantum lattice Hamiltonians”, New Journal of Physics 12, 025018 (2010) arXiv:0906.4127 DOI], equivalent to the phase realized by two copies of the surface code [A. Kubica, B. Yoshida, and F. Pastawski, “Unfolding the color code”, New Journal of Physics 17, 083026 (2015) arXiv:1503.02065 DOI].

Quantum convolutional codes are translationally-invariant stabilizer codes on an semi-infinite or infinite lattice in one dimension [J. Haah, “Lattice quantum codes and exotic topological phases of matter”, (2013) arXiv:1305.6973]. Some notions may be extendable to non-stabilizer codes [H. Ollivier and J.-P. Tillich, “Quantum convolutional codes: fundamentals”, (2004) arXiv:quant-ph/0401134; Sec. 4].

Haah cubic codes are the first examples of Type-II fracton phases [M. Pretko, X. Chen, and Y. You, “Fracton phases of matter”, International Journal of Modern Physics A 35, 2030003 (2020) arXiv:2001.01722 DOI].

Matching codes were inspired by the \(\mathbb{Z}_2\) topological order phase of the Kitaev honeycomb model [A. Kitaev, “Anyons in an exactly solved model and beyond”, Annals of Physics 321, 2 (2006) arXiv:cond-mat/0506438 DOI].
The 3D Kitaev surface code realizes 3D \(\mathbb{Z}_2\) gauge theory with an emergent fermion.
The 3D Kitaev surface code realizes 3D \(\mathbb{Z}_2\) gauge theory.
Fractal surface codes are obtained by removing qubits from the surface code on a cubic lattice.

The generalized surface code is constructed from chain complexes arising from cell complexes of the underlying manifold. Such complexes are not necessarily products of two non-trivial complexes, but the manifolds are picked so that their homology ensures favorable code properties.

When treated as ground states of the code Hamiltonian, surface codewords realize \(\mathbb{Z}_2\) topological order, a topological phase of matter that also exists in \(\mathbb{Z}_2\) lattice gauge theory [F. J. Wegner, “Duality in Generalized Ising Models and Phase Transitions without Local Order Parameters”, Journal of Mathematical Physics 12, 2259 (1971) DOI]. Local Clifford deformations preserve this topological order.
XY code is obtained from the surface code by applying \(H\sqrt{Z}H\) to all qubits, thereby exchaning \(Z\leftrightarrow Y\).
XZZX code is obtained from the rotated surface code by applying Hadamard gates on a subset of qubits such that \(XXXX\) and \(ZZZZ\) generators are both mapped to \(XZXZ\).

The lattice of the rotated surface code can be obtained by taking the medial graph of the surface code lattice (treated as a graph) and applying a similar procedure to construct the check operators [H. Bombin and M. A. Martin-Delgado, “Optimal resources for topological two-dimensional stabilizer codes: Comparative study”, Physical Review A 76, (2007) arXiv:quant-ph/0703272 DOI][N. Delfosse, P. Iyer, and D. Poulin, “Generalized surface codes and packing of logical qubits”, (2016) arXiv:1606.07116][R. Sarkar and T. J. Yoder, “A graph-based formalism for surface codes and twists”, (2023) arXiv:2101.09349; Fig. 8].
Specializing the quantum Tanner construction to the surface code yields the rotated surface code [Nikolas P. Breuckmann, private communication, 2022][Anthony Leverrier, Mapping the toric code to the rotated toric code, 2022.].
Hierarchical codes are concatenations of constant-rate QLDPC codes with rotated surface codes.
Yoked surface codes are concatenations of QMDPC codes with rotated surface codes.

The surface-code CSS stabilizer generator prescription is extendable to higher-dimensional manifolds.
CDSC codes are deformations of the surface code via constant-depth Clifford circuits that may not be CSS.
Planar (toric) code can be obtained from hypergraph product of two repetition (cyclic) codes [A. A. Kovalev and L. P. Pryadko, “Improved quantum hypergraph-product LDPC codes”, 2012 IEEE International Symposium on Information Theory Proceedings (2012) arXiv:1202.0928 DOI; Ex. 6].
A lifted-product code for the ring \(R=\mathbb{F}_2[x,y]/(x^L-1,y^L-1)\) is the toric code [P. Panteleev and G. Kalachev, “Asymptotically Good Quantum and Locally Testable Classical LDPC Codes”, (2022) arXiv:2111.03654; Appx. B].
The modular-qudit surface code for \(q=2\) reduces to the surface code.
The surface code has been extended to Galois qudits.

The Walker-Wang model code reduces to the 3F model code when the input category \(\mathcal{C}=3F\) [S. Roberts and D. J. Williamson, “3-Fermion topological quantum computation”, (2020) arXiv:2011.04693].
When treated as ground states of the code Hamiltonian, 3F model code states realize 3F topological order, which is chiral and modular.

Subsystem CSS codes are subsystem stabilizer codes whose gauge groups admit a generating set of pure-\(X\) and pure-\(Z\) Pauli strings. Additionally, any \([[n,k,r,d]]_{\mathbb{Z}_q}\) subsystem stabilizer code can be mapped onto a \([[2n,2k,2r,\geq d]]_{\mathbb{Z}_q}\) subsystem CSS code, with the mapping preserving geometric locality of a code up to a constant factor [M. L. Liu, N. Tantivasadakarn, and V. V. Albert, “Subsystem CSS codes, a tighter stabilizer-to-CSS mapping, and Goursat’s Lemma”, (2023) arXiv:2311.18003]. Every subsystem stabilizer code can be constructed from two nested subsystem CSS codes satisfying certain constraints [M. L. Liu, N. Tantivasadakarn, and V. V. Albert, “Subsystem CSS codes, a tighter stabilizer-to-CSS mapping, and Goursat’s Lemma”, (2023) arXiv:2311.18003].
Subsystem modular-qudit CSS codes reduce to subsystem qubit CSS codes for \(q=2\).
Subsystem Galois-qudit CSS codes reduce to subsystem qubit CSS codes for \(q=2\).

Bacon-Casaccino subsystem codes are CSS subsystem codes [A. Klappenecker and P. K. Sarvepalli, “On subsystem codes beating the quantum Hamming or Singleton bound”, Proceedings of the Royal Society A: Mathematical, Physical and Engineering Sciences 463, 2887 (2007) arXiv:quant-ph/0703213 DOI].

Subsystem modular-qudit stabilizer codes reduce to subsystem qubit stabilizer codes for qudit dimension \(q=2\).
Subsystem Galois-qudit stabilizer codes reduce to subsystem qubit stabilizer codes for qudit dimension \(q=2\).

The subsystem color code is a single-shot code [B. J. Brown, N. H. Nickerson, and D. E. Browne, “Fault-tolerant error correction with the gauge color code”, Nature Communications 7, (2016) arXiv:1503.08217 DOI].

While the Kitaev honeycomb model is bosonic, a fermionic mapping is useful for solving and understanding the model. Logical subspace of the Kitaev honeycomb code can be formulated as a joint eigenspace of certain Majorana operators [A. Roy and D. P. DiVincenzo, “Topological Quantum Computing”, (2017) arXiv:1701.05052; Sec. 4.1]. Logical Paulis are also be constructed out of Majorana operators.
The Kitaev honeycomb model can be formulated as a qubit subsystem stabilizer code [M. Suchara, S. Bravyi, and B. Terhal, “Constructions and noise threshold of topological subsystem codes”, Journal of Physics A: Mathematical and Theoretical 44, 155301 (2011) arXiv:1012.0425 DOI; Sec. 3.2] based on the \(\mathbb{Z}_{q=2}^{(1)}\) Abelian anyon theory, which is non-chiral and non-modular [T. D. Ellison et al., “Pauli topological subsystem codes from Abelian anyon theories”, Quantum 7, 1137 (2023) arXiv:2211.03798 DOI; Sec. 7.3].

The 3F code is a subsystme code characterized by 3F topological order [T. D. Ellison et al., “Pauli topological subsystem codes from Abelian anyon theories”, Quantum 7, 1137 (2023) arXiv:2211.03798 DOI], which is chiral and modular.

The 3D subsystem surface code is a single-shot code [A. Kubica and M. Vasmer, “Single-shot quantum error correction with the three-dimensional subsystem toric code”, Nature Communications 13, (2022) arXiv:2106.02621 DOI][J. C. Bridgeman, A. Kubica, and M. Vasmer, “Lifting topological codes: Three-dimensional subsystem codes from two-dimensional anyon models”, (2023) arXiv:2305.06365]; see Ref. [C. Stahl, “Single-Shot Quantum Error Correction in Intertwined Toric Codes”, (2023) arXiv:2307.08118] for an alternative formulation.

Subsystem modular-qudit codes reduce to subsystem qubit codes for qudit dimension \(q=2\).
Subsystem Galois-qudit quantum codes for \(q=2\) correspond to subsystem qubit codes.
Galois-qudit RS codes for prime-dimensional qudits are quantum RS codes.

Modular-qudit CSS codes are modular-qudit stabilizer codes whose stabilizer groups admit a generating set of pure-\(X\) and pure-\(Z\) Pauli strings. Additionally, any \([[n,k,d]]_{\mathbb{Z}_q}\) stabilizer code can be mapped onto a \([[2n,2k,\geq d]]_{\mathbb{Z}_q}\) CSS code, with the mapping preserving geometric locality of a code up to a constant factor [M. L. Liu, N. Tantivasadakarn, and V. V. Albert, “Subsystem CSS codes, a tighter stabilizer-to-CSS mapping, and Goursat’s Lemma”, (2023) arXiv:2311.18003] (see also [U. Güngördü, R. Nepal, and A. A. Kovalev, “Parafermion stabilizer codes”, Physical Review A 90, (2014) arXiv:1409.4724 DOI]).
An \(n\) modular-qubit CSS code corresponds to the \(\mathbb{Z}_q^{k_1} \subseteq \mathbb{Z}_q^{k_2} \subset \mathbb{Z}_q^{n}\) group construction, where \(k=k_2/k_1\).

Modular-qudit stabilizer codes are quantum Lego codes built out of atomic blocks such as the 2-qudit repetition code, single-qudit trivial stabilizer codes, and tensor-products of the \(|0\rangle\) state.

Group quantum codes whose physical spaces are constructed using modular-integer groups \(\mathbb{Z}_q\) are modular-qudit codes.
Category quantum codes whose physical spaces are constructed using \(\mathbb{Z}_q\) as the category are modular-qudit codes.

The three-qutrit code is the smallest member of a family of \([[2m-1,1,m]]_{p}\) prime-qudit quantum Reed-Solomon codes for \(p=3\) and \(m=2\) [R. Cleve, D. Gottesman, and H.-K. Lo, “How to Share a Quantum Secret”, Physical Review Letters 83, 648 (1999) arXiv:quant-ph/9901025 DOI].
Three-qutrit code is a minimal model for holography [A. Almheiri, X. Dong, and D. Harlow, “Bulk locality and quantum error correction in AdS/CFT”, Journal of High Energy Physics 2015, (2015) arXiv:1411.7041 DOI][D. Harlow, “The Ryu–Takayanagi Formula from Quantum Error Correction”, Communications in Mathematical Physics 354, 865 (2017) arXiv:1607.03901 DOI].
The three-qutrit code is the smallest nontrivial quantum MDS code.

The qudit Shor code is a small qudit surface code on a Möbius strip with smooth boundary, which is obtained from removing a face of the tesselation of the projective plane \(\mathbb{R}P^2\) [M. H. Freedman and D. A. Meyer, “Projective plane and planar quantum codes”, (1998) arXiv:quant-ph/9810055; Fig. 4].

Subsystem modular-qudit CSS codes are subsystem modular-qudit stabilizer codes whose gauge groups admit a generating set of pure-\(X\) and pure-\(Z\) Pauli strings. Additionally, any \([[n,k,r,d]]_{\mathbb{Z}_q}\) subsystem stabilizer code can be mapped onto a \([[2n,2k,2r,\geq d]]_{\mathbb{Z}_q}\) subsystem CSS code, with the mapping preserving geometric locality of a code up to a constant factor [M. L. Liu, N. Tantivasadakarn, and V. V. Albert, “Subsystem CSS codes, a tighter stabilizer-to-CSS mapping, and Goursat’s Lemma”, (2023) arXiv:2311.18003]. Every subsystem prime-qudit stabilizer code can be constructed from two nested subsystem prime-qudit CSS codes satisfying certain constraints [M. L. Liu, N. Tantivasadakarn, and V. V. Albert, “Subsystem CSS codes, a tighter stabilizer-to-CSS mapping, and Goursat’s Lemma”, (2023) arXiv:2311.18003].

The \(\mathbb{Z}_q^{(1)}\) subsystem code is characterized by the \(\mathbb{Z}_q^{(1)}\) anyon theory [P. H. Bonderson, Non-Abelian Anyons and Interferometry, California Institute of Technology, 2007 DOI]. The anyon theory has a single generator \(a \in \mathbb Z_N\) with \(\theta(a) =e^{\frac{2\pi i}{N}a^2}\). It is modular for odd prime \(q\) and non-modular otherwise.
The semion code is a subsystem code characterized by the chiral semion topological phase.
The \(\mathbb{Z}_q^{(1)}\) subsystem code is characterized by a non-modular anyon theory with \(\mathbb{Z}_3\times\mathbb{Z}_9\) fusion rules.

When treated as ground states of the code Hamiltonian, the code states realize double-semion topological order, a topological phase of matter that also exists in twisted \(\mathbb{Z}_2\) gauge theory [R. Dijkgraaf and E. Witten, “Topological gauge theories and group cohomology”, Communications in Mathematical Physics 129, 393 (1990) DOI].

The anyon theory corresponding to Abelian quantum double codes is defined by an Abelian group and trivial cocycle. All Abelian TQD codes can be realized as modular-qudit stabilizer codes by starting with an Abelian quantum double model along with a family of Abelian TQDs that generalize the double semion anyon theory and condensing certain bosonic anyons [T. D. Ellison et al., “Pauli topological subsystem codes from Abelian anyon theories”, Quantum 7, 1137 (2023) arXiv:2211.03798 DOI]. Upon gauging, Type-I and II \(\mathbb{Z}_2^3\) TQDs realize the same topological order as certain Abelian quantum double models [M. de W. Propitius, “Topological interactions in broken gauge theories”, (1995) arXiv:hep-th/9511195][B. Yoshida, “Topological phases with generalized global symmetries”, Physical Review B 93, (2016) arXiv:1508.03468 DOI][L. Lootens et al., “Mapping between Morita-equivalent string-net states with a constant depth quantum circuit”, Physical Review B 105, (2022) arXiv:2112.12757 DOI].
The anyon theory corresponding to (Abelian) quantum double codes is defined by an (Abelian) group.

Modular-qudit surface code Hamiltonians admit topological phases associated with \(\mathbb{Z}_q\) [S. S. Bullock and G. K. Brennen, “Qudit surface codes and gauge theory with finite cyclic groups”, Journal of Physics A: Mathematical and Theoretical 40, 3481 (2007) arXiv:quant-ph/0609070 DOI].

All Abelian TQD codes can be realized as modular-qudit stabilizer codes by starting with an Abelian quantum double model along with a family of Abelian TQDs that generalize the double semion anyon theory and condensing certain bosonic anyons [T. D. Ellison et al., “Pauli topological subsystem codes from Abelian anyon theories”, Quantum 7, 1137 (2023) arXiv:2211.03798 DOI].
Abelian TQDs realize all modular gapped Abelian topological orders [T. D. Ellison et al., “Pauli Stabilizer Models of Twisted Quantum Doubles”, PRX Quantum 3, (2022) arXiv:2112.11394 DOI]. Conversely, every Abelian anyon theory is a subtheory of some TQD [T. D. Ellison et al., “Pauli topological subsystem codes from Abelian anyon theories”, Quantum 7, 1137 (2023) arXiv:2211.03798 DOI; Sec. 6.2]. Any Abelian anyon theory \(A\) can be realized at one of the surfaces of a 3D Walker-Wang model whose underlying theory is an Abelian TQD containing \(A\) as a subtheory [J. Haah, “Clifford quantum cellular automata: Trivial group in 2D and Witt group in 3D”, Journal of Mathematical Physics 62, 092202 (2021) arXiv:1907.02075 DOI][W. Shirley et al., “Three-Dimensional Quantum Cellular Automata from Chiral Semion Surface Topological Order and beyond”, PRX Quantum 3, (2022) arXiv:2202.05442 DOI][T. D. Ellison et al., “Pauli topological subsystem codes from Abelian anyon theories”, Quantum 7, 1137 (2023) arXiv:2211.03798 DOI; Appx. H].
The anyon theory corresponding to (Abelian) TQD codes is defined by an (Abelian) group and a Type III cocycle.
Goppa codes can be realized in the CSS code construction [A. Niehage, “Nonbinary Quantum Goppa Codes Exceeding the Quantum Gilbert-Varshamov Bound”, Quantum Information Processing 6, 143 (2006) DOI].
Galois-qudit BCH codes can be constructed via the CSS construction or the Hermitian construction.
Folding an quantum polynomial code on \(q\)-dimensional Galois qudits yields an FQRS code on \(q^m\)-dimensional Galois qudits.
Galois-qudit GRS codes can be constructed via the CSS construction or the Hermitian construction.
Galois-qudit RM codes can be constructed via the CSS construction or the Hermitian construction.

A Galois qudit for \(q=p^m\) can be decomposed into a Kronecker product of \(m\) modular qudits [A. Ashikhmin and E. Knill, “Nonbinary quantum stabilizer codes”, IEEE Transactions on Information Theory 47, 3065 (2001) DOI]; see Sec. 5.3 of Ref. [A. Niehage, “Quantum Goppa Codes over Hyperelliptic Curves”, (2005) arXiv:quant-ph/0501074]. Interpreted this way, Galois-qudit codes are group quantum codes whose physical spaces are constructed using Galois fields \(GF(q)\) as groups.
Category quantum codes whose physical spaces are constructed using \(GF(q)\) as the category are Galois-qudit codes.

2BGA codes are LP\((a,b)\) codes, constructed from a pair of one-by-one matrices \(a,b\in \mathbb{F}_q[G]\) in a group algebra.
2BGA codes are two-block quantum codes whose commuting matrices are constructed with the help of a group algebra.

A code GB\((a,b)\) with circulants of size \(\ell\) is a special case of a 2BGA code over the cyclic group \(\mathbb{Z}_{\ell}\). More precisely, for the cyclic group \(\mathbb{Z}_{\ell}\equiv \langle x|x^\ell=1\rangle \), any element \(a\) of the group algebra \(\mathbb{F}_q[\mathbb{Z}_{\ell}]\) can be seen as a polynomial \(a(x)\in \mathbb{F}_q[x]\) over the group generator \(x\), where the polynomial degree \(\deg a(x)<\ell\). The 2BGA code LP\((a,b)\) is then just a generalized bicycle code GB\([a(x),b(x)]\) constructed from the polynomials \(a(x)\) and \(b(x)\) corresponding to \(a,b\in \mathbb{F}_q[\mathbb{Z}_{\ell}]\). 
A code GB\((a,b)\) with circulants of size \(\ell\) is a special (degenerate) case of a lifted-product code LP\((A,B)\) code over the Abelian group algebra \(\mathbb{F}_q[\mathbb{Z}_{\ell}]\) associated with the cyclic group \(\mathbb{Z}_{\ell}\equiv \langle x|x^\ell=1\rangle\), with \(1\times 1\) matrices \(A=a(x)\), \(B=b(x)\) given by the corresponding polynomials. 
An index-\(m\) quasi-cyclic (QC) code of length \(n=m\ell\) is usually defined as a linear code invariant under the \(m\)-step shift permutation \(T_{n}^{m}\).
Balanced product codes result from a tensor product of two classical-code chain complexes, followed by a factoring out of certain symmetries.
Galois-qudit CSS codes are true stabilizer codes [D. Gottesman. Surviving as a quantum computer in a classical world].
The code required to construct this code must be a non-degenerate Galois-qubit CSS code.

A non-stabilizer code is also a stabilizer code if its Fourier description \(\mathsf{B}\) is a subgroup of some Gottesman subgroup \(\mathsf{S}\). When \(\mathsf{B}\) is just a subset, the code is explicitly not a stabilizer code.
Hermitian codes are true stabilizer codes because they are based on Hermitian self-orthogonal linear (as opposed to additive) codes over \(GF(q^2)\).
The Landau-level spin code approximately protects against rotational errors.

Single-spin codes are subspaces of a single large spin, which can be either standalone or correspond to the permutation-invariant subspace of a set of spins. A single-spin code correcting spherical tensors can be mapped into a permutation-invariant code with an analogous distance [E. Kubischta and I. Teixeira, “The Not-So-Secret Fourth Parameter of Quantum Codes”, (2023) arXiv:2310.17652; Thm. 1].
